title: Basic obsidian tutorial
content:
Obsidian is a note-taking app which is somewhat similar to Notion and OneNote, but with many more features. While I never used Notion for a long time, I find Obsidian easier to navigate and with more personalisation.
I do various things with Obsidian — note-taking, essay planning, mind-mapping, planning my day, keeping track of what I need to do, etc. There is an insane amount of things you can do with Obsidian, and it is up to you whether or not you do those things.
Anyway, let's start with the very basics.
You can make a note using the bar on the top left, or use Ctrl+N (or Command/Cmnd, for Macs. If I say Ctrl from now on, assume I also mean Command.)
Most importantly, you can link notes together by using double square brackets - [[]] - like that but with text in the middle.) You can both link to existing notes by typing in a note's title (which automatically searches your vault to show you which notes you could be asking to link to) or create a note by typing in a title and clicking the link.

You know the Wikipedia system? Where there are hyperlinks here there and everywhere linking between articles? This is that. Cool, right?

[!warning] Types of links
There are two kinds of links to a note: forwards and backwards. Forwards is a link that is in the current note going outwards to another note, and backwards links are links going into the current note from another note. They are, unfortunately, categorised separately when searching your vault using properties. You can see the forwards and backwards links in two of the tabs on the top right hand side — they should look like linked chains with an arrow.

Finally, you need to know the command Ctrl+P. This opens the command menu, which is where you can do anything — creating new notes, bases, canvases, opening certain views, plus any commands from any plugins, etcetera.
Typing in notes
You can type in these notes as usual, although there are a few shortcuts that are used in markdown format (the format that these notes are in) to use the base program.

You can, of course, use the Editing Toolbar plugin to have a word-esque toolbar to use. I personally find the hotkeys easier, though.

The basic hotkeys are as follows:

Ctrl+B / two asterisks on both sides of any text-> Bold text
Ctrl+I / one asterisk on both sides of any text -> Italic text
Two equals {=} on both sides of any text -> highlighter
using a dash {-} and then space to start a list

like this

using a number, then period, then space to start an automatic numbered list (see the current example)
using {>} to indent text slightly

Like this

using Tab to indent both text and lists

like this

Using hashtags plus a space before text to indicate a Header — one hashtag for most important, down to 6 hashtags for least

You can also do all of this by right-clicking and using the menu that appears.
Also in the menu is the table function — i.e. just a normal table, the rule function-

-which looks like the line above, and the callout function, which can create cool blocks-

[!tip] Cool block
Like this!

That's about it for inbuilt text features. There are a few plugins that I would recommend, but we'll get onto that in the Plugins section.

[!info]
Note that Obsidian doesn't have an automatic spell-checker. This goes for capital letters at the start of sentences, too! It is, however, very very easy to get a spellchecker — which I will be talking about in the Plugins section.

Other inbuilt features of Obsidian
Graph view
Graph view is where linking notes comes into play! It's a fun way of looking at the links between your notes and finding notes.
Here's a screenshot of my current graph view:

Every single dot is a note. Every single line is a link.
There are a few other things you can do with graph view — messing around with the forces, colouring the dots based on properties that the note has — but the know-how gets explained later, so I'll leave it for now.
And by later, I mean now!
Tags and properties
This is your second way of sorting notes, other than links (and the file repository on the left, but do I really need to explain how to use that?). It's incredibly useful and not complicated at all.
Essentially, each note has a list of properties. You can add to these and change these as you like. These properties include (but are not limited to):

the file name
the folder that it is in
file links (forwards and backwards are separate, remember?)
created time
modified time
file path (how does it link to your 'home note' — i.e. the origin note)
and tags!

You can change these using the properties view — which is an inbuilt plugin (you only have to turn it on from settings) or for changing tags, you can just type in the tag. It's like, so #cool <-(literally like that.)

You can also use properties view to change tags. You can find properties view in the 'core plugins' section of settings and then you can find the menu under the info button in the top-right bar.

You can search your notes by using these tags or group notes together by using these tags from graph view, if you just don't want to use links.

I use it to categorise my notes into major lessons, minor lessons, resources, essay plans, and various other things. It makes it easier to find a specific note if I am looking for it.

This leads well into-
Categorizing and searching notes
This is done using the inbuilt plugin 'Bases' — which you can find and activate in the same way as you found Properties View. It should already be enabled, but who knows.
This is one of my bases:

As you can see, bases contain all of your notes and are very searchable and customisable. Everything except the 'file name' property is something I put in through the 'properties' menu which you can see on the top right of the image.
You can search your notes in various ways. You can query by including, excluding, containing, does not contain, and apply these to the file properties. Here, I searched by the 'debates' tag — but if I wanted to only have Politics notes, I can use the 'does not contain' query looking into the 'folder' property and write 'philosophy' to exclude all philosophy notes.

Although, note that other than searching for categories of notes, it's most useful for editing the properties of categories of notes. You see those tick-boxes under 'dg-publish'? Those are what decides if certain notes go onto my site or not. And I can do it in a single click! No searching through each and every note's properties view!

Yes, I will give a basic explanation of how to publish notes online for free.

[!important] On graph view
You remember graph view? Using properties is how I colour the nodes in graph view — you can colour them in the graph view menu using properties and then assigning a colour to nodes with a certain property.

Finally,
Canvas
Canvas is the final core plugin which needs an explanation. It's essentially just a mindmap.
Here's one I made earlier-

It's zoomed out, so you can't see the text, but you see what it is, right? It's quite useful — especially in understanding lines of argument and forcing you to make links between ideas. It's good for redo-ing messy notes from a lesson — it helps in understanding and remembering the content by making you interact with your notes properly.
You won't see it in this website though, because it's an incompatible format, and these were made before I started working on this website. Nowadays, I use (and you will see) the Excalidraw plugin which is similar in it's features, but looks quite different — and it's in a compatible format for posting.
To be continued...

title: Kingdom of God essay plan
content:
#unfinished #debates

[!question]
"Liberation theology misunderstands the Kingdom of God."

For
Theme
Against
Evaluation

If the Kingdom of God is only in the city of God, then liberation theology is misunderstanding it, because it acts in the city of man
Cities of God and man
Where is this justification for the city of God/man? Jesus acted in the city of man; why shouldn't we?
There is only one example of the Bible separating the city of man and God- 'My kingdom is not of this world.' That, however, does not discourage the idea that we should act on Earth in the image of Christ, just that heaven is above/better than Earth.

Some argue that Liberation theology misunderstands the Kingdom of God by misunderstanding the separation of the cities of man and God. A weak point in support of this is proposed by Augustine: that since the city of man is inherently sinful and doomed to fail, we should not involve ourselves with it- i.e. in acting in a political manner and being involved in the state, Liberation Theology is acting in an un-christian manner. A stronger point against this is that Augustine's views have no basis in the Bible. Jesus himself acted in such a way that would fit Augustine's own definition of acting in the city of man- he was an inherently political figure who not only did political acts, but encouraged those around him to do so: by spreading his message ("Have you heard the good news/gospel?") and behaviours. To say that Christians should not be involved in the city of man is a viewpoint with no basis in the Bible- to go so far as the evidence going against the ideas of the separation of the city of man and God. Overall, Liberation Theology does not misunderstand the Kingdom of God as Augustine would argue- because Augustine's viewpoint that one should not act politically is an idea that is entirely his own, with basis in the Bible that disproves his own views- and so it cannot be a successful argument for Liberation Theology misunderstanding Christianity.

title: Liberation and Marx- speech
content:
#homework #debates

Speech (refined)
Ultimately, if Liberation theology aligned too closely with Marxism, it would compromise christian faith. However, it does not align too closely with Marxism.
These two are fundamentally different ideas- even in their own definitions. Marxism is a political system, which expressed methods of overthrowing and then running a country. In comparison, Liberation Theology is just an ideology- an ethics system: but not one that is comprehensive or consistent across the people who propose it. Sure, it's core ideology: that society causes sin (aka structural sin) and that one must tackle these problems at the core is one taken from Marxism. But to say that these ideas are closely intertwined is ignorant.
To pretend that LT is incredibly closely aligned with Marxism ignores the major proponents of LT. Both Boff and Gutierrez warn against adopting all of Marx's ideas- Boff says 'that marx is a useful companion on the way, but there is only one teacher; jesus christ.'
The first point brought up by critics of Liberation theology is that the church should not be political. If you encounter anyone who brings up this point, you should first ask if they have read the Bible, and second if they have been living under a rock.
Both Jesus Christ and the church have been and are political. It is fundamental to their nature- no matter how you think about politics. Jesus told the rich that, unlike the poor who were blessed, they would face woes. He criticised the King as a fox. He spoke harsh words to leaders of the nations when they were uncaring of the needy. He rode into Jerusalem on a donkey as a way of declaring himself king. The character of Jesus Christ is inescapably political. Just because he was never political as in involving himself in a political party, does not in any way mean that he wasn't political.
Then, some may argue that the church itself shouldn't be political- because it has set precedent to do so. If you haven't already asked if the proponent has been living under a rock, please do so now.
The church has been political in England for a long, long time.
The welfare system, (part of which you may know as the NHS- but containing most of the social care we know today) was set up by a man named William Beveridge, who was friends with the at the time Archbishop William Temple.
They reimagined post war Britain with the ideals of God in mind, and through that have saved and improved the lived of millions.
If you want a more recent example- how about the previous Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby- who has explicitly written that the church should get involved in politics. In an article he wrote in 2018, he says:
"There will be great changes in our country through technology and science, through changes abroad and at home. We may base change in good values. We may just let things take their course.
But if it’s the latter, then the consequences for the poor, the sick and those on the margins will be dire. Our pride will be diminished, and our contribution to the world stifled."
So yes, the church should be and is political- and this idea, reminiscent of Liberation Theology (which comes from Marxism)- cannot be argued in any way shape or form to compromise christian faith.
On the other hand, some have argued that Liberation theology compromises Christianity by being too closely aligned with action. Richard McBrien argues that liberation theology is so concerned about action that it has not paid sufficient attention to christian theology. In starting from action it cannot determine which actions might be right or wrong.
I.e. one should be more focussed on prayer than action.
Again, one should ask any proponent of this question if they have read the bible, and if they say yes, ask if they a) are very sure, and b) did they do it with their eyes open? Does jesus spend the majority of his time praying? Does he? Really? I rest my case.
Then, some flip that and say that Liberation theology is too focussed on structural sin rather than individual sin- which is not in the path of Jesus. Kloppenburg argues that jesus reached into people's personal lives and spoke of the individual coming back to God through forgiveness- and that ultimately, it is only God that brings salvation.
This argument is, frankly, baffling. Jesus called for people to follow in his path, of kindness and uplifting the meek. To argue that because only God can bring large-scale salvation- we should not try and do that, is a lazy, evil viewpoint. To decide to not try and help people on a systemic scale because it will

Unrefined
'Laws are threats by the dominant socioeconomic power in any given region [...] the police are just an occupying army. '
"When I give food to the poor, they call me a saint. When I ask why the poor have no food, they call me a communist." -Brazilian Archbishop Camara
Was it not political when Jesus rallied against the occupying romans? Was it not political
Justin welby's article about being political because that is how we make a better world for our children. https://www.archbishopofcanterbury.org/church-gets-involved-politics-because-thats-what-jesus-did
He was never party political. No wing of politics – left or right – can claim God as being on its side.
But Jesus was highly political. He told the rich that, unlike the poor who were blessed, they would face woes. He criticised the King as a fox. He spoke harsh words to leaders of the nations when they were uncaring of the needy.
He did this because God cares for those in need and expects those who claim to act in his name to do the same. That means action - and words.
1942 Archbishop William Temple was old friends with William Beveridge, a top civil servant and another Christian, who wrote his great report that designed the welfare system, the health service and much of what we now take for granted in social care. They were friends with R.H. Tawney, a social philosopher, and again a Christian.
Drawing on Christian understandings of justice, generosity and human dignity, they described the kind of country that they felt reflected God’s values better.
There will be great changes in our country through technology and science, through changes abroad and at home. We may base change in good values. We may just let things take their course.
But if it’s the latter, then the consequences for the poor, the sick and those on the margins will be dire. Our pride will be diminished, and our contribution to the world stifled.
If we all take part in forming our values, if we base them in what is good and precious in our heritage, then our future can be better than our past. Our children and grandchildren can remember us as a generation that gave them hope and purpose.
For me, that is worth risking one’s head for. It justifies the church not only speaking about Jesus Christ, but also, like him, calling for – as well as working for – the society that God calls us to pursue.

Structure

summary of my line of argument: Yes, if Liberation theology aligned too closely with Marxism, it would compromise christian faith, but in the manner it aligns in now it does not compromise christian faith, but complement it.
Should the church even be political?

Should the church focus on one individual group? Isn't that unfair?

What about spiritual poverty?

Shouldn't the church focus on spirituality/theology rather than action?
Structural sin

Does structural sin exist? (yes)
should the church tackle it?
how does liberation theology suggest we tackle it? How does it differ from Marxism?

Violence

Should the church be violent in it's aims to do liberation theology (no)
however, political violence does not count

and Jesus was politically violent. be honest with yourselves.

title: Checks and balances on the SC
content:
#debates
The extent and effectiveness of checks and balances both on and from the Supreme court.
This can be broken down into several question areas:

Effectiveness of checks and balances on the Supreme court
Effectiveness of checks and balances from the Supreme court
Overall power of the Supreme court.

Powerful
Theme
Weak.
Evaluation

Several times the Supreme court has upheld habeas corpus for immigrants, directly- such as in Boumediene v Bush, or the two v Rumsfeld cases.
Enforcement
The deportation of Kilmar Abrego Garcia in 2025 was ruled against per curiam and ordered that he be brought back. This was completely ignored by the Trump administration. They have also ignored orders not to send troops to Chicago.
While the courts used to support habeas corpus and rights for immigrants, in more recent years these have been ignored by the Trump administration- demonstrating that the SC has very little power to enforce it's decisions.

Bostock v Clayton county (2020)- or the upholding of the ACA, or Trump v Casa Inc. (First- upholds rights, second and third uphold government actions. )
Federalism
Overall upholds federalism on more minor laws. such as Dobbs v Jackson, United States v Skremetti, and Rucho v Common cause, and Murphy v NCAA.
While the court has had some major rulings that directly create/uphold policy nationwide, these examples are generally rare, and mostly limited to constitutional rights. On anything not in the constitution, the SC almost always gives power to the states.

The court's independence means it is functionally immune to political pressure. The SC has gone against Trump many times- such as ordering that $2 billion in foreign aid be unfrozen, or Bostock v Clayton county (2020)
Politicisation
The conservative balance of the court has clearly led to more decisions in Trump's favour, making it weaker in its partisanship. For example- Trump v CASA inc., Trump v Hawaii, and Trump v United States all being ruled in his favour.
While the SC can go against Trump, it often doesn't. Of course, this can change after justices retire/die, but this will take a while, and will have a strong affect on american politics for at least 2 decades being a republican SC majority.

The court's decisions tend to be based on legal principles (Dobbs v Jackson) rather than politics. Also, ~50% of decisions are 9-0 or 8-1, despite the political split.
Judicial activism
The court shows willingness to interfere in controversial political areas, such as in United states v. Skrmetti, claiming it was a matter of state authority despite claims that it went against equal protection rights.
Overall, if judicial activism was more prevalent, one would expect less court decisions to be per curiam or close to. However, recent events- such as Justice Clarence Thomas' signalling to revisit Obergefell v Hodges, demonstrates that these judges are more political than previous.

title: Compulsory voting- debate
content: The Franchise #debates Here is the table of debate. Turnout Stats sheet, for referencing. Point Counter-point Evaluation Voting is a civic duty- in the same way that jury duty is a civic duty. Jury duty may be a civic duty, but we still acknowledge that some cannot participate- i.e. being at university If the government forces the public to vote, that is coercion. The government forces people to do shit all the fucking time. Also, just have a 'none of the above' option- see Belgium: turnout over 88% in the last 12 years Low turnout decreases the legitimacy of every election. Turnout has been decreasing since fucking forever Legitimacy decreases anyway is the ballot gets spoiled, or if politically illiterate people make random decisions. It's not a mandate if people were forced to vote. Some people are not well educated. "All voices should be heard", well what happens when those voices don't want to be heard? If you don't plan to vote, your voice doesn't get a say. Polls say that political participation is highest among the upper classes and anyone above the age of 25. The voices that are heard aren't equal and so politicians target those who are most likely to vote- so not young people. If we want things to get better, we want to force politicians to truly represent everyone Mandatory voting encourages political awareness Mandatory voting increases turnout among underrepresented groups- such as the youth, POC, and the working class. How do you enforce compulsory voting? Through fines- which is an inherent disadvantage to the poorest: who may not be able to afford to skip work. Paid time off exists. Plus, if the government wants compulsory voting, they can fund it.

title: Do opinion polls affect voting behaviour
content:
#debates
Unorganized Table

Yes
No

Polls can create a bandwagon effect. For instance, in the 2019 GE, polls predicting a significant Tory lead may have convinced undecided voters to back them, or convinced opposed voters to not vote, convinced a Tory victory was inevitable.
Many voters make decisions based on things other than polls. The 'Red Wall' shift in 2019 was caused by long-term dissatisfaction with Labour's stance on Brexit and economic policies.

Media coverage amplifies poll's importance — take Reform's current showing in the polls and showing in Media.
Polls are only paid attention to by those who follow politics and elections closely. For instance, polls in 2024 showing shifts in younger voter turnout became focal on social media — and young voter turnout dropped from ~47%->~37%.

Polls can mobilise voters who fear that their preferred party is trailing. For example, in the 2019 GE, polling data suggested a possible hung parliament, potentially motivating Tory voters to turn out.
The majority of voters have a preference before campaigns begin, so polls have little impact. In 2019, Scotland continued to back the SNP despite polling trends.

Strategic voting can be influenced by polls, especially in marginal constituencies. For example, in the 2024 GE, polling data highlighted tight races in the South East, leading calls for Lib-Dem voters to vote for Labour in key constituencies to unseat Tory MPs.
Inaccurate or poorly conducted polls can be misleading. In 2024, a widely shared (but flawed) poll underestimated Labour's performance in the Midlands, creating false expectations of a conservative hold in marginal seats.

title: Do parties help or hurt democracy
content:
#debates

[!question]
Do political parties help or hinder representative democracy?

Help
Theme
Hinder
Evaluation

They make sure that unsuitable candidates don't stand for public office- that only reputable candidates stand.
Voter choice
Since candidates have to associate themselves with the manifesto of their party, even if it might not fully represent their views- but whipping means that MPs will do what is required of them, not what is best for their county.

Without parties, it would be incredibly difficult to establish a government and get anything done.
Freedom of MPS
Party whips expect them to support the program because of the government mandate. That can suffocate genuine debate.

It associates a candidate with a party's manifesto, making it easy to understand what individual candidates stand for.
Understanding
It makes government confrontational and negative. Also, a candidate may not fully agree with the manifesto that they are standing with, and will act against it after the election against their constituent's wishes.

Opposition parties can make an organised effort to hold the government to account, in a way which would be impossible for individuals
Democracy
Parties give excessive power to their membership; we had multiple PMs which 95% of the country didn't vote for because of the Tory leadership.

Parties are vital in organising the government
Funding
The main political parties disproportionately benefit from government funding, which ensures that they can monopolise political decision making.

title: Should 16 year-olds have voting rights- debate
content: The Franchise, Turnout Stats sheet #debates Point Counter-point Evaluation 16 year-olds are irresponsible. They aren't allowed to get married, buy alcohol or cigarettes, or leave school. That doesn't mean that they don't deserve a say in society. Also, they can join the army, have sex, and pay taxes. also, imposing adult responsibilities is not a right (bull) Ultimately, it is true that teens cannot exercise full adult responsibility. This, however, is unrelated to if they should have the right to vote. 16-year-olds will end up just voting as an extension of their parents- which means the groups in society who have kids will be overrepresented in the electorate. Voting is secret. While yes, many will vote as an extension of their parents- so do many people vote as an extension of their family/friends. Nobody can be coerced into voting in a certain manner. Also, citizenship lessons. Just because one will vote irresponsibly, does not take away the fact they should have the right to vote. Even shitheads deserve rights. 16-year-olds can pay taxes- many have part-time jobs, and that means they contribute to society- therefore, they should have a say in how their money is being spent. Paying taxes is not a precursor to voting. Also, most 16-year-olds don't earn enough money to pay taxes anyway. This doesn't apply to the majority. The fact that some do- even a minority- is enough. Plus- some adults don't pay taxes, and they can vote. Why not 16-year-olds? teens don't have the necessary life experience to make proper decisions. Voter turnout amongst 18-24s is typically under 50%. Also, 18s are significantly more likely to be active members of society. The same could be said for 18s, though. Policy decisions now will affect teens much more than adults- like the environment. They should have a say in their future. Just because turnout is low, and that will decrease legitimacy- does not mean that they don't deserve the right to vote. Remember: even shitheads have rights. There isn't only one way (voting) to be involved in politics. Joining a pressure group or political party, signing a petition, or contacting your local MP are actions that all are capable of. This doesn't mean they shouldn't have the right to vote.

title: Political v Judicial
content:
#debates

Political
Themes
Judicial
Evaluation

The appointment process is inherently political since the nominees are from the sitting President- who appoints judges based on ideology. This is clear in that Trump appointed three justices and the SC swung right in it's decision making.
Political pressure
The position is designed to be independent- as judges are appointed for life and not obviously venerable to political pressure. The current SC has voted against Trump multiple times (ordering the release of federal aid, ordering troops to withdraw from Chicago.)
While judges don't face political pressure, this doesn't mean that they cannot choose to be political.

The SC has been more political in the last half-decade: overturning Roe v. Wade with Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health, or the many cases ruled in Trump's favour (Trump v CASA/United States/Hawaii), or in United states v. Skremetti, upholding Tennessee's ban on gender-affirming care for minors. They have clearly chosen to be more political in recent years.
Ideologies
Judges practice judicial restraint, and choose not to interfere in political matters. This is clear in ~50% of decisions being per curiam or 8-1, which wouldn't be expected if the judges were acting politically. They often use stare decisis or judge based on precedent- such as in Bostock v Clayton County: extending civil rights protections to Queer employees based on the Civil Rights Act- or in June Medical services v. Russo (2020)- which struck down an anti-abortion Louisiana law.
If this was 2015, it could be argued that the SC do practice Judicial Restraint. However, they have clearly become more political in recent years- going so far as Justice Clarence Thomas signalling that they would re-look over Obergefell v Hodges.

Because they directly affect other branches, it's impossible for them not to be political. Either ruling on Trump v. United States would have unavoidably and significantly affected the relationship between the white house and congress- which are inherently political branches.
Relationships between branches
The SC rules only on the constitution, and any affect they have on the branches of government is coincidental. They make decisions not based on public opinion- such as in Admissions v Harvard (2023), in which their ruling was very unpopular. Or in California v Texas, which upheld Obamacare, despite it being a right-leaning court.
While one can point to exceptions upon exceptions of the SC being unbiased, the reality is that the court is inherently political, no matter the leaning, because it affects political institutions. This is unavoidable, no matter how partisan they are.

title: Primaries pros and cons
content:
#debates

Good thing
Bad thing
Mini-conclusions

Voter choice and democracy
Voters are given a choice of president rather than only the party doing it. Voters can choose from a range of competing policies and ideologies within a political party.
Voting in different states on different dates means voters in earlier states have a much greater level of influence. -unbound delagates are free to vote however they want, regardless of public opinion.
Overall, it's clear that primaries are a bad thing for voter choice and democracy- because although they can vote for their president, in reality very few Americans will be able to affect the choice of candidate properly, because of primaries taking place on different days.

voter education and participation
Throughout the primaries, issues with the candidate get aired. This means that the strongest candidate wins, and then has better chance of winning the election. - People develop better awareness of policies and issues. Then, because people are more aware, they are more likely to vote and vote effectively.
Closed primaries restrict participation. Voting in different states on different dates means voters in late states are often left unable to vote.
Overall, it's clear that primaries are a good thing for voter education and participation, because it directly involves them in the process and brings it to state-wide attention- and the higher awareness means that people are more likely to vote, increasing participation.

benefit for parties
primaries put candidates to the test in real elections. This helps the party select a candidate with the proven ability to win elections. Personal issues and political concerns can be dealt with during this time.
The eventual winner might be politically damaged by the process. Primaries do damage to a party by exposing infighting.
Overall, it's clear that primaries benefit parties- because it brings their policies and personalities to national attention- and the winner does have a proven ability to persuade people to vote for them.

In conclusion, primaries play a negative role in US democracy to a small extent- because although it benefits parties by making sure their candidate is strong on the national stage, and it increases the political awareness in the general public- ultimately these don't matter in the face of the unfairness in the process. Having increased awareness or a better candidate does not matter if the later states have significantly less say in the candidate- sometimes even being functionally worthless if the candidate becomes presumptive before the later states have even voted.
Various evidence
o In the 2024 Republican primaries prominent candidates Ron DeSantis and Vivek Ramaswamy dropped out after Iowa, the first state to vote. DeSantis, one of the favourites to win the whole primary process, dropped out after coming second to Trump. Voters in Iowa had greater levels of choice (four candidates) than voters in later states who only had a choice of Trump and moderate Republican Nikki Haley. This political inequality contradicts the basic principles of democracy.
o In 2016 the Republican establishment would almost certainly have chosen an established insider such as Ted Cruz or Jeb Bush. The primaries instead led to a clear winner in Trump who was arguably better equipped to win the presidency for the Republicans than either of the former candidates. The primaries quickly showed that whilst Bush has huge fund-raising capacity he lacked resonance with voters.
o Whilst Bush defeated McCain in a closely fought primary race in 2000, McCain's policy of campaign finance reform gained attention and popularity and was passed into law.

title: Significance of parties in congress
content:
Examine the extent to which political parties are significant in congress.
Conclusion:
Overall, parties have a significant effect on Congress because of member's reliance on parties to get elected due to an overwhelming amount of 'safe seats', meaning most must follow party leadership and decisions in order to keep their seats. This is supported by the unitary nature of the parties — which demonstrates that members will vote on party lines, especially when necessary, such as in both of Trump's impeachment charge votes. In the face of this, any individual member's power — whilst significant — cannot compare in the face of a unitary party, of which is necessary to pass legislation in the partisan american political system.

Significant
Theme
Insignificant
Evaluation

Party disciple is still evident. Despite overwhelming pressure to release the Epstein files, only 4 republicans defected. A large number of 'Never Trumpers' Republicans fell in line with Trump policies — such as tax cuts.
Unity
Internal factionalisation means that party unity is weakened. After the Jan 6th riots, 10 House Republicans voted to impeach Trump. Some Republicans have voted for the release of the Epstein files — or been publically against Trump (MTG)
Parties are incredibly unitary on controversial issues — such as on Trump's impeachment charges in 2019 and 2021, party lines were largely adhered to, demonstrating that on more controversial issues, parties will be unitary and so will have more effect.

One member voting against a legislative agenda won't work: it's necessary for parties to vote in unison to block or pass bills because of the often close majorities in house and senate.
Individual power
Individual members can have more power. Senator Joe Manchin had a pivotal role in the Biden agenda, such as blocking parts of the Build Back Better plan in 2021.
While individual members often don't have power, the existence of the few that do and their power in shaping agenda and law demonstrates that an individual's power matters more than the party.

Parties still play a crucial role in candidate success. Most seats are safe seats for one party — that there are only 7 swing states in the USA, the rest are 'safe seats' and very rarely change, demonstrating that party loyalty is more important than candidate's qualifications. In 2024, only 17/435 house seats flipped party.
Loyalty in elections
Party loyalties are weak because of the constitutional separation of powers, and Parties don't provide many resources insofar as fighting campaigns, or finances. Many political adverts don't even mention the name of the candidate's party at all. Many news stations focus on individuals — like AOC or Mamdani.
While candidates do campaign on individual platforms, the existence of safe seats demonstrates that people in elections mostly vote on party lines, not on if they like the candidate. Take Gavin Newsome, the Democratic governor of California, who before 2025 was incredibly unpopular within California but still was governor.

The President still has incredible power of persuasion — many of Trump's endorsements in 2022 largely secured nomination due to his influence. The ability of the President to endorse or attack candidates overrides any local importance.
Local politics
Politics is often local. Congress members have a much deeper connection to their constituencies because they don't rely on party affiliation to get elected — congress members are more aware of how their constituents will react to their voting record (which is made very public) than the leader of their party.
Senators are more likely to have their voting record get more attention, but they are only elected every 6 years — which leaves a long time for constituents to forget individual votes. However, many Republican senators have fallen in line with Trump despite not agreeing with him, partly due to Trump's popularity, especially in their own Republican constituencies.

.container {font-family: sans-serif; text-align: center;} .button-wrapper button {z-index: 1;height: 40px; width: 100px; margin: 10px;padding: 5px;} .excalidraw .App-menu_top .buttonList { display: flex;} .excalidraw-wrapper { height: 800px; margin: 50px; position: relative;} :root[dir="ltr"] .excalidraw .layer-ui__wrapper .zen-mode-transition.App-menu_bottom--transition-left {transform: none;} (function(){const InitialData={"type":"excalidraw","version":2,"source":"https://github.com/zsviczian/obsidian-excalidraw-plugin/releases/tag/2.17.0","elements":[{"id":"ad1lUX72","type":"text","x":-342.8610297309026,"y":-76.21737331814234,"width":800.5878228081597,"height":1350,"angle":0,"strokeColor":"#1e1e1e","backgroundColor":"transparent","fillStyle":"solid","strokeWidth":2,"strokeStyle":"solid","roughness":1,"opacity":100,"groupIds":[],"frameId":null,"index":"a0","roundness":null,"seed":1881726185,"version":161,"versionNonce":181335047,"isDeleted":false,"boundElements":[{"id":"4AyJ5rIAyQ7BRW2fgdEFv","type":"arrow"},{"id":"2Xkf-xFUhWpstVaMaH48-","type":"arrow"},{"id":"s-7CvfYbhjhzSEkyn9eAy","type":"arrow"}],"updated":1763543740843,"link":null,"locked":false,"text":"The song of songs, which is Solomon's.

Let thou kiss me with the kisses of thou mouth: for thy love is better than
wine. Because of the savour of thy good ointments thy name is as ointment
poured forth, therefore do I love thee.

Draw me, we will run after thee: the king hath brought me into his chambers: we
will be glad and rejoice in thee, we will remember thy love more than wine: the
upright love thee.

Thy cheeks are comely with rows of jewels, thy neck with chains of gold.

We will make thee borders of gold with studs of silver.

My beloved is unto me as a cluster of camphire in the vineyards.

Behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair; thou hast doves' eyes.

Behold, thou art fair, my beloved, yea, pleasant: our bed is green.

The beams of our house are cedar, and our rafters of fir.

I am the rose of Sharon, and the lily of the valleys.

As the lily among thorns, so is my love among the rushes.

As the apple tree among the trees of the wood, so is my beloved among the
cedar. I sat down under his shadow with great delight, and his fruit was sweet
to my taste.

He brought me to the banqueting house, and his banner over me was love.

Stay me with flagons, comfort me with apples: for I am bursting of love.

For, lo, the winter is past, the rain is over and gone; 

The flowers appear on the earth; the time of the singing of birds is come, and
the voice of the turtle dove is heard in our land;

Set me as a seal upon thine heart, as a seal upon thine arm: for love is eternal;
the coals thereof are coals of fire, which hath an everlasting flame.

Many waters cannot quench love, neither can the floods drown it: if a man would
give all the substance of his house for love, he would utterly be content.

Let us get up early to the vineyards; let us see if the vine flourish, whether the
tender grape appear, and the pomegranates bud forth: there will I give thee my
loves.

The mandrakes give a smell, and at our gates are all manner of pleasant fruits,
new and old, which I have laid up for thee, O my beloved.

Make haste, my beloved, and be thou like to a roe or to a young hart upon the
mountain of spices.","rawText":"The song of songs, which is Solomon's.

Let thou kiss me with the kisses of thou mouth: for thy love is better than wine. Because of the savour of thy good ointments thy name is as ointment poured forth, therefore do I love thee.

Draw me, we will run after thee: the king hath brought me into his chambers: we will be glad and rejoice in thee, we will remember thy love more than wine: the upright love thee.

Thy cheeks are comely with rows of jewels, thy neck with chains of gold.

We will make thee borders of gold with studs of silver.

My beloved is unto me as a cluster of camphire in the vineyards.

Behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair; thou hast doves' eyes.

He brought me to the banqueting house, and his banner over me was love.

Stay me with flagons, comfort me with apples: for I am bursting of love.

For, lo, the winter is past, the rain is over and gone; 

The flowers appear on the earth; the time of the singing of birds is come, and the voice of the turtle dove is heard in our land;

Set me as a seal upon thine heart, as a seal upon thine arm: for love is eternal; the coals thereof are coals of fire, which hath an everlasting flame.

Many waters cannot quench love, neither can the floods drown it: if a man would give all the substance of his house for love, he would utterly be content.

Let us get up early to the vineyards; let us see if the vine flourish, whether the tender grape appear, and the pomegranates bud forth: there will I give thee my loves.

The mandrakes give a smell, and at our gates are all manner of pleasant fruits, new and old, which I have laid up for thee, O my beloved.

Make haste, my beloved, and be thou like to a roe or to a young hart upon the mountain of spices.","fontSize":20,"fontFamily":5,"textAlign":"left","verticalAlign":"top","containerId":null,"originalText":"The song of songs, which is Solomon's.

title: Should the state fund political parties
content:
⚠ Switch to EXCALIDRAW VIEW in the MORE OPTIONS menu of this document. ⚠ You can decompress Drawing data with the command palette: 'Decompress current Excalidraw file'. For more info check in plugin settings under 'Saving'
Excalidraw Data
Text Elements
Should the state fund political parties?
Parties have an important role to play in society- they ensure a functioning government. They need funding to help develop policy and be effective opposition.
Funding can level the playing field, particularly for smaller parties who don't have a backup of resources or many donations.
State funding can help to limit the influence of big donors.
Parties receiving state funding may lose their independence
Funding political parties is how someone can show their support- it's a sign of a pluralist democracy.
Deciding how much parties are funded can cause problems. If parties are funded for their size, it just entrenches the status quo.
All main parties (2 or more MPs) get £2 million so that they can employ political advisors.
The conservatives have received ~£5 million pounds in 25-26 in short money, more than double second place (the Lib-dems)
The conservatives received 60% of the total donations leading up to the 2019 general election. They received the same amount in corporation donations as Labour got in total (~£5 million)
The minimum for registering a donation changed from ~£7000 to ~£11,000 in 2023.
The leader of the opposition gets £800,000
The Mp's expenses scandal in 2009
Clearly, the state funding that we have is ineffective at it's job.

Text Elements
Does natural law provide a helpful method of decision-making?
Absolute and deontological
It's easy to understand; certain things are either right or wrong.
It has no room for change- it's outdated and too closely linked to church morality (motherhood, eg)
Theoretically, everyone has access to it.
But people have different levels of reasoning.
What about the doctrine of double effect?
Universality
It is universal; everyone knows it.
Morality changes across cultures.
Aquinas said it was based on scripture, but not everyone has access to scripture.
So is God evil for sending people to hell when they had different access to resources?
Human nature
But what about the Fall? If we can all access reason, what was the point of JC dying on the cross for humanity's sins?
We all have reason so we can all access goodness: which is accessible to all and doesn't require God's grace.
Then what is the point of God if we don't need His grace? Also, we are sinful, so how can we get grace without God?
It argues that there is a universal human nature, which is not fully true.
Not everyone would benefit from reproducing, following all of society's laws, worshiping God, or being educated (with the current education system.)
Just because he isn't 100% correct, does not mean that NML isn't a helpful decision-making tool.

title: Correcting Caricatures - Women in the Bible
content:
Link to the website
https://www.cbeinternational.org/resource/correcting-caricatures-women-and-bible-translation/
Transliterated article
When lecturing on women and Bible translation, I often see people Google facts they’ve never heard before. Few know Paula (347–404) led one of the great translation efforts—the Latin Vulgate. Nearly invisible in its history, Paula purchased the ancient manuscripts, guided the translator teams, and made linguistic edits. Jerome—her colleague on this project—acknowledged her leadership and so should we.
Other women translators include Julia Evelina Smith (1792–1886), Louise Swanton Belloc (1796–1881), Elizabeth Cady Stanton (1815–1902), and Pandita Ramabai (1858–1922)—who led the first all-women Bible effort, from translation to printing, binding, and distribution. The first woman to lead a denomination, Helen Barrett Montgomery (1861–1934) produced the Centenary Bible, citing doctor-missionary, anti-trafficking activist, and biblical scholar Katharine Bushnell (1855–1946).
After decades of anti-trafficking advocacy that included confronting Christian men for their impunity and collusion in abusing women, Bushnell was compelled to address ways Scripture was used to view women as lesser than men. Theologically astute, she insisted that a correct interpretation as it relates to “women status” should be assigned in the same manner as “man’s status, [based] on the atonement of Jesus Christ.”1
Exposing biblical misrepresentations, Bushnell’s groundbreaking book, God’s Word to Women, shows how Scripture has been weaponized to demean women and fuel their abuse. Like other female translators, Bushnell considered the impact of accuracy in translation on women. Yet she was the first translator to critique every passage addressing women. To see how unjust some translators’ choices have been, here are a few significant examples from Bushnell’s God’s Word to Women.
Beginning in Genesis, Bushnell insisted the text stresses not Eve’s failures and need of male authority, but their shared dignity and authority, Genesis 1:26–29. She challenged translating tsela as rib since (42 times in Scripture) it’s translated as “side” to evoke a mitosis process—of one whole organism becoming two complete organisms. “Side” is more accurate and dignifying to women.
Equally, Bushnell noted how the word chayil, used over 200 times as “strength, force, or capacity,” is translated as “virtue” or “chastity” when referring to a woman.2 Likewise, teshuqah was translated as “lust” rather than “desire” in Genesis 3:16: “Your lust will be for your husband, and he will rule over you,” insinuating women are sensual and corrupt—a trend Bushnell also found in researching New Testament passages.
Consider how kosmios was rendered “well-ordered” for men but “modest or pure” for women in 1 Timothy 2:9. Similarly, hagnos is translated as “holy” for men, but “pure” for women in  Titus 2:4–5.3  Tragically, the parable holding men and women to the same sexual ethic—the woman caught in adultery (John 7:53–8:11)—was missing in several translations, including Bushnell’s 1880 Chinese Bible and also key Syriac and Coptic manuscripts.⁴
For Bushnell, each of these examples of translation bias (and others noted in her book) may be “straws,” but “they all point in the same direction.”⁵  To depict women as innately immoral and lesser-than leads to immoral actions toward them.
So while translators depicted women as immoral and promiscuous, Bushnell’s systematic examination of Bible passages that address women elevated their redemption. Through Calvary, all receive a Christ-identity and Gospel purpose—to lead with spiritual authority as Christ’s new creation, just as man and woman shared governance in Eden. Correcting sexist caricatures through accurate Bible translations was for Bushnell crucial in upending women’s exploitation. For “nothing is of more importance to the Christian woman today than to understand that God did not Himself subordinate woman to man.”⁶ Women’s strength of character, glowing on the pages of Scripture, was needed to give the gospel power to dismantle male dominance and abuse. What began for Bushnell as solidarity with women enslaved in the global sex trade ended with exposing flawed Bible translations.
We stand united in Christ to proclaim women’s dignity and purpose through accurate Bible translations, remembering that dehumanizing ideas about people lead to dehumanizing actions. Correcting sexist translations and interpretations will have a redemptive impact on the global exploitation of women, as Bushnell’s life and research make clear.
This article appears in “Gendered Language and the Church,” the Autumn 2021 issue of Mutuality magazine. Read the full issue here.
Notes

Katharine Bushnell, God’s Word to Women, (Minneapolis, Minn.: Christians for Biblical Equality, 2003), 169.
Bushnell, God’s Word to Women, 633.
Bushnell, God’s Word to Women, 644.
Cyprian as quoted in Corpus Scriptorum Ecclesiasticorum Latinorum, Academia Litterarum Vindobonensis, vol. iii, p. 638.
Bushnell, God’s Word to Women, 644.
Bushnell, God’s Word to Women,  450.

To learn more about CBE’s Bible translation project, click here.
https://www.cbeinternational.org/resource/correcting-caricatures-women-and-bible-translation/

title: Criminalisation & Consent -- R. V. Brown
content:
Link
Introduction
Consensual sadomasochism(SM) constitutes criminal assault in the United Kingdom.1 This comes from R v Brown,2 a House of Lords case in which a group of men were convicted for their involvement in consensual sadomasochistic sexual acts. The key issue facing the Court was whether consent was a valid defence to assault in these circumstances. The Court answered in the negative. Within the judgement Lord Templeman stated this question can only be answered through consideration of policy and public interest”.3 The aforementioned judgement has been called “autonomy-constricting moralism”4 while justified as an act to protect society by criminal sanctions against a cult of violence which potentially fostered proselytisation of young men”.5 This critique will focus on key aspects of; the potential miscategorisation of the sadomasochistic acts therein as ‘violent’ as opposed to ‘sexual’, the consensual element at play, the dissenting judgements’ arguments on the acts’ illegality under existing laws on violence, and the level of harm issue in the ratio decedendi. With those in mind this critique will aim to highlight the potential legal weaknesses of this House of Lords decision.
The Facts, Judgement, and Ratio Decedendi of R v Brown [1993] UKHL 19
In this case, a group of men (appellants) willingly participated in the commission of sadomasochism against each other, including genital torture, for the sexual pleasure it evoked.6 Passive partners consented to the acts committed and suffered no permanent injury.7 The activities occured in private; albeit recorded solely for the delectation of the group.8 The appellants were tried on charges of assault occasioning actual bodily harm, contrary to s 47 of the Offences against the Person Act 1861, and unlawful wounding, contrary to s 20 of that Act. The initial trial judge held that the consent of the victim afforded no defence to the charges, the appellants then pleaded guilty and were sentenced to terms of imprisonment.9 The appellants appealed against their convictions, contending that a person could not be guilty of assault of that nature in respect of consensual acts conducted in private. The Court of Appeal dismissed their appeals.10 The appellants appealed to the House of Lords who held, with Lord Mustill and Slynn dissenting, that consensual sadomasochistic encounters which occasion actual bodily harm to a victim is an assault. They held this in the interests of public policy. It thus followed that the appeals would be dismissed.11 The law following Brown seems to be that consensual assault causing ‘harm’ above the level of assault (such as in sadomasochism) is prima facie unlawful unless such behaviour falls within one of the exceptional categories grafted by the common law, which would subsequently legalise the conduct in question.12
Sadomasochism: Sex or violence?
In Brown the sadomasochistic acts were misguidedly characterised as ‘seriously violent’ and not ‘sexual’ thereby making them incapable of being ‘ratified’ by the concept of consent.13 Hence the judgement assumed: ‘that sex and violence are distinct and easily separable’ and that ‘consent to one is not necessarily consent to the other’.14 So, if the law insists upon mutual exclusivity, ‘is Brown about sexual practices between consenting adults in private, or is it about deviant, legally unprotected ‘violent’ sexual practices’?15 To support the former statement, it must be established that SM is legitimate sexual expression albeit involving violence, if so, then consent should and does play a role determining the criminalisation of any resulting harm. In Brown the ‘violent’ categorisation was founded on the infliction of pain within the acts. Yet what if pain is a subjective experience intrinsically linked with pleasure within the human nervous system? Hence, pain in a sadomasochistic context may not constitute ‘pain’ but sexual pleasure. Recent studies shed light on this phenomenon.  In one study, researchers used fMRI to visualise the brains of women as they stimulated themselves to climax, found that more than 30 areas of the brain were active, including those involved in pain.16 Another found cancer survivors, who had spinal nerves severed to relieve chronic pain, lost the ability to have orgasms.17 If their pain returned, so did the orgasms. Then a study into paracetamol affecting emotions18 found the painkilling drug relieved emotional pain, but blunted feelings of pleasure. The drug levelled-off highs as well as lows – an indicator that pain and sexual pleasure operate on shared biological pathways. For human beings, then, it appears that pain and pleasure are intertwined.19 Nafsika Athanassoulis communicated how this relates to Brown quite eloquently with the words “sadomasochism is sex expressed through violence”.20 Hence the characterisation of Brown as ‘violent’ is debunked and it is now asserted that sadomasochism is better characterised as ‘sexual’.
Consent in Brown
If accepted that Brown sadomasochism is sexual then it is subject to the general rules of sexual consent and examined alongside the exceptional category of HIV transmission. If consent means ‘factual expressive consent’ 21, this was achieved in Brown. The conditions of freedom, knowledge, capacity, and motivation that are deemed necessary to ‘transmute X’s factual (expressive) consent into legal consent’,22 were fulfilled so the participant’s consent was not ‘legally defective’ due to coercion, deception or incompetence.23 Hence in Brown sadomasochism was sexually consensual. Robin Mackenzie criticised that only isolated acts of apparently sudden violence were exhibited on video to the judges, because ‘were the actions placed in the context of on-going negotiations and gradually increased stimulation (as seen in other parts of the video), a more empathetic understanding of such practices as [sexually consensual] might be, and indeed should be fostered’.24 However there is the element of harm occurring within Brown but a common law exceptional category exists which allows for informed consent to the risk of serious harm for sexual ends.
This is R v Dica.25 Dica concerned the transmission of HIV, which the law defines as grievous bodily harm (GBH) - a significantly more serious level of consensual harm than Brown allows for. Dica stated that parties can consent to the risk of transmission, which can be construed to mean that one can consent to the risk of serious harm for the sake of sexual gratification. Brown, by contrast, states that parties cannot consent to the risk of actual bodily harm (ABH) and ‘wounding’ for the sake of sexual gratification.26 Cowan observes that Dica allows for consensual harm within a sexual context, which justifies its derogation from Brown on the assumption the acts therein were ‘violent’. However this distinction from Brown is highly questionable if it is ‘sexual’ as our previous critique asserted. Furthermore the ‘harm’ in Brown came nowhere near the level of harm which was permissible in Dica, as HIV infection is an enduring life-long condition to manage27 whereas in Brown there was no lasting injury. The Dica ratio itself states there is a realm of private sexual relations in which the criminal law should not interfere,28 such logic which is clearly applicable to Brown. Therefore there is little evidence to justify this exclusion of Brown from the Dica exception. If sadomasochism, in the absence of permanent injury, constitutes the infliction of violence, it is illogical that HIV infection resulting from consensual risk-taking does not.29
Dica emphasises the severity of HIV infection to distinguish it from the ‘ordinary’ risks of unprotected sexual intercourse, such as unwanted pregnancy or common STIs. One can implicitly consent to these ‘lesser’ risks without an exceptional category. It is asserted that while Dica is right to distinguish HIV from the relative less considerable ‘ordinary’ sexual risks, it is misguided in its attempts to contrast SM with the ‘ordinary risks’, by equating it with HIV infection.30 This is questionable as Dica can seem to implicitly propose that one, if fully informed, ‘can expressly consent to the risk of HIV infection but not SM, because the risk of HIV is still one of those risks that (‘ordinary’) heterosexual intercourse incurs’31 which can be construed to evidence the court’s normative approach to sexually deviant homosexual practices. It is problematic if the law perceives the heterosexual transmission of a fatal disease more positively than impermanent/superficial injury caused by homosexual sadomasochism.
Inclusion of sadomasochistic behaviour as an offence under assault
Henceforth this critique shall proceed assuming that the courts are not in a position to accept sadomasochism as a legitimate means of sexual expression. It will focus on the legal content of the judgements in R v Brown, with an emphasis on the rationale of those dissenting. As previously outlined, the decision in Brown was made with public policy at its core, to protect society through criminal sanctions from a ‘cult of violence’ which could convert young men to it.32 Yet, Lord Mustill outlines in his dissenting judgement, ‘corruption of youth is already catered for by the existing legislation’ ‘if there is a gap in it which needs to be filled the remedy surely lies in the hands of Parliament, not in the application of a statute which is aimed at other forms of wrong-doing’.33 Therein lies two important statements that reference other aspects of this judgement. That the public policy concern was addressed within pre-existing legislation, hence the Brown ratio is undermined and that there was not sufficient ground for declaring the Brown activities to be criminal under the Offences against the Person Act 1861.34 The later matter is debatable with contentions that the majority focused on the wrong legal idea,35 they fixated on establishing the sadomasochistic acts were criminal and did not adequately consider ‘Were they criminal under the Act of 1861?’. Lord Mustill stated the statute was “intended to penalise conduct of quite a different nature” and ponders “should in this new situation be interpreted so as to make it criminal”.36 Furthermore, Lord Slynn in his dissenting judgement in response to the DPP’s submission that it was a matter of policy; should the courts “adopt a paternalistic attitude as to what is bad or good for subjects, in particular as to deliberate injury”? He established it was an area of policy where social and moral factors were extremely important and changeable, hence “it [was] a matter of policy for the legislature to decide.”37 He further asserted it was not for the courts “to introduce into existing statutory crimes, concepts which did not properly fit there”. In his eyes it was the duty of Parliament to amend the Act of 1861 or the Sexual Offences Act 1967 for the Brown activities to be criminal under them.38 Hence it becomes apparent that the House of Lords, in their revulsion and eagerness to sanction the behaviour in Brown, may have extended the Offences Against the Persons Act 1861 to cover actions distinctly outside of its legal remit.
Level of harm
Aside from its inclusion under assault, there is another legal issue in Brown: the level of harm. In Brown the Lords heard from Mr. Purnell Q.C. that the appellants were liable under general law because the harm was to a degree where it went from non-criminal consensual violence to criminal.39 Hence the court sought to establish a border between the two, thus the level of harm appears in Brown’s ratio.40 Lord Slynn raised his concerns on this matter stating if a line is drawn “to be workable, it cannot be allowed to fluctuate within particular charges”.41 This has been evoked in recent works which ask ‘are the courts to start evaluating the validity of consent on the basis of some undeclared judicial barometer of the severity of harm?’42 Perhaps the qualifying level of harm is arguably determined by judicial creativity on a case by case basis?43 If we look to preexisting examples of applying the level of harm principle the negative answer becomes arguably more concrete. The Brown practices have been equated with those in R v Emmett,44 where a man tied a plastic bag over the head of his partner and on another occasion poured lighter fluid over her and set it alight in the pursuit of sexual gratification, and was therefore deemed to cause harm of too high a level to be legal. But this is debatably wrong, because the risks posed and harm caused in the latter were arguably much higher than those in Brown, including loss of consciousness and serious burns.45 The European Court of Human Rights subsequently distinguished R v Wilson,46 which concerned the branding of a woman by her husband for sexual gratification but was deemed legally exempt under assault due to the exceptional category of body modification (specifically tattooing), because the injuries in that case were considered ‘not at all comparable in seriousness’47 with those in Brown or Emmett. Yet in Wilson the injuries themselves amounted to ABH namely the level of harm incurred in Brown. Hence if we are to look at how the precedent of Brown has been interpreted it solidifies the argument that Brown is an inherently poor judgement with respect to the factors considered in its determination.
Conclusion
R v Brown and the subsequent criminalisation of the sadomasochistic behaviour therein under the Offences against the Person Act 1861 coupled with the legal precedents it created are inherently flawed. As established within this critique the Court’s characterisation of Brown as ‘violent’ is questionable given the compelling evidence and arguments that is is better understood in a ‘sexual’ context. Had it been viewed within this context the consensual nature of the sadomasochistic behaviour could have absolved the appellants of criminal culpability. Furthermore, if accepted as ‘sexual’, then Brown’s potential inclusion under Dica becomes notably less objectionable and thus the question of allowing one to consent to GBH but not ABH sheds light on the Court’s normative approach to Brown. Additionally, the dissenting judgements in Brown present insight into the Court’s potential manipulation or misconstruing of the Act of 1861 in their efforts to criminalise the aforementioned actions and express a notable concern over the usage of a ‘level of harm’ principle in a legal setting. As evidenced by the subsequent case examples provided they were undoubtedly and assuredly correct to voice such worries. Hence the legal weaknesses in Brown are apparent and it is my assertion, with these in mind, that the criminalising of sado-masochistic activities in this case was plainly wrong.
