title: She’s Not a Whore - Translation Bias in Ezekiel 16
content:
Link to the article
When I was eight years old, one of my teachers was named Mrs. Moorehouse. After school one day, I was talking to my mum and accidentally referred to her as Mrs. “Hoorehouse.” While I was merely surprised at the slip, my mum was shocked. But then, she thought I’d said “whorehouse.”
Growing up with gospel stories read from the 1984 NIV English translation, it’s possible that I had a growing awareness of the word “prostitute.” But the word “whore” was, evidently, unknown to me. Neither it nor any of its derivatives are used once in the NIV. They are, however, used ninety-one times in the ESV.
I discovered this as I was studying Ezekiel 16.
Ezekiel 16: A Difficult Passage to Say the Least
Likely written around the time of the southern kingdom’s exile to Babylon, the chapter describes the history of the people of Judah’s relationship with God using an extended metaphor. Judah, or more specifically Jerusalem, is depicted as a foundling who grows up to become a sexually unfaithful wife to God. The whole story is saturated with graphic descriptions of nakedness, sex, and violence.
Very broadly, responses to the text lie somewhere between two extremes. A full embrace of this passage sees God acting in unmerited compassion and generosity, only to be grossly betrayed; he responds to Jerusalem’s unfaithfulness in righteous anger and just punishment, culminating in a merciful promise of restoration.1 On the other hand, full resistance to the text frames God as an absentee benefactor who abandons Jerusalem until she’s old enough for him to make her his arm candy. When she acts out, this view would say God behaves like a textbook abuser,2 giving Jerusalem no voice whatsoever, at any time.3
Clearly, there are serious questions about the purpose of Ezekiel’s rhetoric and how much this passage is intended to reveal the character of God. It is also no small task to consider how the text should be presented and discussed within the church, bearing in mind that many readers will be women and/or survivors of domestic and sexual abuse.
What I want to explore is how this conversation is likely to be influenced by translation choices, particularly in the case of the ESV and its use of the word “whore.”
“Whore” in the ESV
The Cambridge Dictionary offers two definitions for whore. One is archaic and refers to a female prostitute. The other more modern usage is offensive and refers to “a woman whose behaviour in her sexual relationships is considered immoral.”4
At a glance, the ESV seems to use “whore” mainly in its archaic sense. Phrases like “you lavished your whorings” from Ezekiel 16:15 certainly look old-fashioned (and show up in a spell check). But there’s more going on here.
Officially, the use of “whore” reflects reliance on the KJV tradition.5 But if the translators thought “whore” was still preferable over a modern term, then why just this term? For example, in 1 Samuel 25:22, David swears that he won’t leave a single male person alive from Naboth’s household. The ESV uses the word “male” even though the KJV says “any that pisseth against a wall.” Why use “whore” but not “piss”? Given that both are now offensive terms, I can’t help but think this is an example of translation bias.
Meanwhile, whether intended or not, it’s hard for a modern reader to read “whore” without its negative connotations. And in the context of Ezekiel 16, that matters. We’re led to believe that either:

pejorative use is justifiable and righteous, or
pejorative use is not justifiable and the text is deliberately (and provocatively) depicting God as unrighteous.

Given the troubling narrative as a whole, we shouldn’t immediately rule out the second option. However, it’s very unlikely the ESV translators believed the text was presenting an unreliable portrait of God. Even if they did, that doesn’t explain all the uses of “whore” in the ESV outside of the book of Ezekiel.
It seems more likely that the translators were willing to ignore, or even embrace, the misogynistic overtones the word “whore” now has.
But there’s more.
Metaphor Upon Metaphor
Modern readers might not realize it, but there are two levels of metaphor at work in this chapter. The more obvious one is the wider depiction of the spiritual unfaithfulness of the inhabitants of Jerusalem through the image of the woman’s sexual immorality.
But metaphor also operates within individual phrases that use the Hebrew root znh. In Old Testament culture, married and betrothed women were expected to have sex with one man only, for as long as he was alive. If this norm was violated, a married woman might be described as “prostituting” herself, but the intended meaning was not that she worked as a prostitute. It was that she was being sexually immoral.6
In other words, most of the phrases in Ezekiel 16 about the woman’s “prostitution” are metaphorical. We misread the text if we think the author is telling us this woman’s behaviour is that of a sex worker; the narrative even labors how the woman was unlike a prostitute (verses 31 and 34).
Once we realize this, we can see that translators have a choice about what they do with each individual phrase. They can preserve the original image used in the Hebrew or state the intended underlying meaning without using a metaphor.7
The ESV and NIV tend to take the first option, but the CEB, an ecumenical translation that aims to be comfortably readable for most English readers, takes varied approaches depending on context.
For example, if we look at the Hebrew root znh (meaning to act as a prostitute), it occurs eighteen times in verses 15–34, fifteen of which are metaphorical.8 The ESV translates it with derivatives of “whore” all fifteen times. The NIV recognizes when the Hebrew is using particular turns of phrase, so it uses “prostitute” eight times, “promiscuity” three times, “favors” three times, and leaves it untranslated once. Meanwhile, the CEB uses “prostitute” only five times, leaves it untranslated once, and uses other phrases including “traded,” “seduce,” “promiscuity,” and “favors.”
We can see this trend in the rest of the Old Testament too.
To be clear, directly translating the original Hebrew metaphor is a valid translation choice. But metaphors carry different overtones and emotive effects depending on the reader’s context. If a translation chooses to preserve a particular image, we need to ask whether that’s down to a more literal translation style or actually reflects a convenience for the translator’s ideology.
Put another way, when metaphorical use of the root znh is translated into English terms associated with prostitution, does that reflect a willingness on the part of the translator to stigmatise sex workers and/or women who exercise sexual agency?
If so, we have a problem.
Why All of This Matters for Readers
My point here is not to put forward a defence of sex work. However, given the many complex reasons why women (and men) can take up prostitution, it’s important to resist using this Hebrew metaphor without appropriate justification. And we definitely shouldn’t be adding to it in a chapter as rhetorically loaded as Ezekiel 16.
This is where the ESV translation choices become even more strange. As I mentioned, the ESV preserves the metaphorical use of the root znh all fifteen times in verses 15–34; this is consistent with the ESV’s more literal translation style. However, in the three times the Hebrew refers to a sex worker (verses 30, 31, and 33), the ESV uses “prostitute,” not “whore.” In other words, “whore” isn’t just being used because it’s archaic.
The effect of this shouldn’t be underappreciated in such a highly complex and emotive passage. The strange mix of the archaic and modern puts a veneer of authority and respectability over the pejorative intent behind “whore.” It discourages modern readers from resisting the text and collapses the complexities of Ezekiel’s rhetoric and prophetic purpose. It encourages us to believe, as feminist scholar Peggy Day so bluntly puts it, “the bitch had it coming to her.”
Leaving aside how this dangerously steers toward victim blaming, such an interpretation is also deeply flawed. As Day argues, the text is not about sex, but apostasy, about abandoning God. If we read it as about sex and marital relationships, then it doesn’t portray a measured judicial process for infidelity, but a vicious and absurd sexual revenge fantasy; after all, the male adulterous lovers do not share the woman’s punishment but participate in inflicting it.9
In contrast, if we read the chapter as inescapably about apostasy, then the text becomes a deliberately distressing description of the foreign conquests of Jerusalem. It may even be inviting us to identify with Jerusalem.10
Concluding Thoughts
There is much, much more that could be explored on this topic, particularly in the books of Hosea, Nahum, and Proverbs. And there are definitely questions to be asked of other translations, including the NIV and CEB—the latter uses “whore” four times in the Old Testament, three of which are in a single verse (Nahum 3:4).
But we should question what purpose is served by the sheer volume of times “whore” is used in the ESV, not just in Ezekiel 16 but throughout the Old Testament. Because this didn’t happen by accident. It reflects deliberate translation choices—firstly, to preserve the metaphorical use of the root word znh (both in its own right and within turns of phrase), and secondly, to use an English word which, when we hear it today, almost always carries derogatory intent.
As for Ezekiel 16, we need to remember that it’s not about sex, but apostasy. It stacks up as a description of Jerusalem’s failed alliances with foreign nations, but it breaks down if read as a picture of marital relations.
Ultimately, we will each have to decide for ourselves how much we resist or embrace the rhetoric force of this highly complex passage of Scripture. I first read it when I was eighteen, as I was working my way through the book of Ezekiel. I won’t lie, even with the graphic content of this chapter (and chapter 23), the book enlivened my faith in a way that surprised and inspired me, and I’m never going to forget that. However, I was thirty-seven before I heard anyone in my church community acknowledge the violence of this particular passage. If I’m honest, that left me angry.
It is my hope that if we can talk about Ezekiel 16 better, then we will, in time, translate it better too. That won’t stop readers from being unsettled by it, but it will give them more space to ask critical questions of the text and wrestle to find their own answers.
This article appears in “Gendered Language and the Church,” the Autumn 2021 issue of Mutuality magazine. Read the full issue here.
Notes

Peggy Day gives a review of scholars who explicitly or implicitly interpret the chapter this way. See Peggy L. Day, “The Bitch Had It Coming to Her: Rhetoric and Interpretation in Ezekiel 16,” Biblical Interpretation 8, no. 3 (2000): 231–54.
The passage follows the “three-stage cycle of abuse”: tension-building, acute violence, followed by kindness and contrite behaviour. Linda Day, “Rhetoric and Domestic Violence in Ezekiel 16,” Biblical Interpretation 8 (2000): 205–30, quoted in Bryan D. Bibb, “There’s No Sex in Your Violence: Patriarchal Translation in Ezekiel 16 and 23,” Review & Expositor 111, no. 4 (December 2014): 339.
See in particular Carol J. Dempsey, “The ‘Whore’ of Ezekiel 16: The Impact and Ramifications of Gender-Specific Metaphors in Light of Biblical Law and Divine Judgment,” in Gender and Law in the Hebrew Bible and the Ancient Near East, edited by Victor H. Matthews et al. (Sheffield: Sheffield Academic, 1998), 57–78; and Aaron Koller “Pornography or Theology?: The Legal Background, Psychological Realism, and Theological Import of Ezekiel 16,” The Catholic Biblical Quarterly 79, no. 3 (July 2017): 402–21.
Cambridge Dictionary.
Bibb, “There’s No Sex in Your Violence,” 342.
See Day, “The Bitch Had It Coming To Her,” 236. In Peggy Day’s discussions about the structure and impact of metaphors, she cites Julie Galambush’s argument around the metaphorical use of znh. Julie Galambush, “Jerusalem in the Book of Ezekiel: The City as Yahweh’s Wife,” SBLDS, 130 (Atlanta: Scholars Press, 1992), 25–88.
A third translation choice would be to use a different image to convey a similar emotive effect to today’s readers. For example, the US phrase “kick the can down the road” could be translated in the UK as “kick the ball into the long grass.” However, this kind of translation would be difficult to achieve in a complex and layered passage like Ezekiel 16, and I don’t know of an English translation that attempts to do so with this passage.
As Carol Dempsey observes, the root znh occurs in verse 15 (twice), 16, 17, 20, 22, 25, 26, 31, 33 (twice), and 34 (twice). See Dempsey, “The ‘Whore’ of Ezekiel 16,” 68.
See Day, “The Bitch Had It Coming To Her,” 231–54.
See Koller, “Pornography or Theology?” 412–414.

title: Dualism
content:
Plato on Dualism

[!QUOTE] Plato, ‘Phaedo’
“The body is the source of endless trouble to us… takes away from us all power of thinking at all”

Plato is the original dualist. He believes that the body and soul are separate, and that the soul lives on after the death of the body.
Plato's principles on body and soul

body and soul are opposites — material and imperfect versus spiritual and perfect. They are two separate substances that interact.
Changing — the body is constantly changing so cannot be a source of truth. The soul is immortal, in the world of forms, unchanging, and a source of truth
The soul is the real identity of a person — we have a body, but we aren't a body: our inner mental life is the most important part of ourselves.
In conflict — soul seeks intellectual pleasure. Monkey brain want physical pleasure. Conflict.
Charioteer — reason is the highest thing and allows us to know the world of forms, emotion inspires us but can make us reckless, appetites ensure we look after our bodies but can lead us into hedonism. A good person is one with reason in charge.
Forms — soul is in a higher reality and wants to return to the world of forms. We have knowledge because our soul has experienced it in the world of forms.
Mortality — anything material cannot be everlasting, permanence is part of the 'true essence' and the soul is immortal, so it's purer, cannot be broken down, and must carry on living.

Plato's actual arguments
The cyclical argument — if birth leads to death, then death must lead to birth.

This is 'begging the question' (fallacy)
Also, this is cum hoc ergo propter hoc: correlation does not equal causation. Just because life is linked to death, does not mean death is linked to life.

The recollection argument — all knowledge is just stuff you remember.

How can a child learn so quickly? They must know it from a previous life.

This is a non sequitur fallacy, or a faulty generalisation fallacy: the conclusion doesn't logically follow from the premises/ the conclusion is based on weak premises.

The affinity argument — The soul survives death. Since the body is mortal and composed of many parts, the soul — which is not composed of many parts — must be immortal.

This is a false dilemma, (the soul and body are opposites) into affirming the consequent (if A then B; B, therefore A — if death (A) follows from life (B), then life must follow from death)

The argument from opposites — since death is the opposite of life, and opposites are mutually exclusive, when the body dies life must go on. This is just the cyclical argument part 2.

again, begging the question

Descartes
Descartes believes that the mind is interdependent, the mind and soul (which he does not make distinction between) are where all thoughts/sensations/ideas occur.

[!QUOTE]
The soul has "thought but not extension" and the body has "extension but not thought."

He believes that the mind/soul interact with the body through the 'pineal gland' in the brain. This is, of course, complete crap. He called this complete crap Cartesian Dualism.

For more info, read this article, it goes more into depth on his position. It's quite short and a good read.

Property dualism

[!SUMMARY]
The body and soul are different but interact as part of the same substance — i.e. when the body dies, the soul dies.

Aristotle

the body is matter and the soul is the form

the soul shapes the body, gives it it's qualities/purpose; the soul is the Formal, Efficient, and Final cause.

The soul cannot act without a body, and a body cannot act without a soul.

the soul and body are inseparable because they interact so closely.

The eye and axe analogies

The eye is simply an object. It's Formal cause is 'sight.' There is no 'eye' without the action of sight

What makes up an axe is not only it's materials, but it's 'capacity to chop.' This is it's Formal cause

The soul is the Formal cause of the body

Aquinas

bro just agrees with Aristotle but adds Christianity onto it.
- He uses Aristotle's arguments for the existence of a soul but then completely ignores the ones which indicate that the soul does not survive death.

the soul is united with it's resurrection body to enjoy heaven/the kingdom of God after death.

Although he adds that the soul operates independently, and so can survive death.

The 'G' in Gilbert Ryle stands for 'Goat'
Ryle criticises Descartes' substance dualism using the analogy of "ghost in the machine"

i.e. they can't be separate if they interact.

If you read the article on Descartes above, it provides a lot more depth to these arguments.

He also uses the idea of a 'category error'

A category error is like when - after being shown around one building in a university, you say 'can I see the university now?'
actions have to be of both the body and mental state — they cannot be separated and categorised into different things because they are sub-elements of the same thing

this links back to Aristotle's ideas

Finally, he uses the Holistic argument: i.e. looking at a person as a whole; he thinks that the body and soul are one thing.

This is the weakest argument. Don't use it unless you agree with dualism and want a bad argument on the opposite side to counter.

Various other philosophers on mind-body-soul
John Hick

the soul is a gift from God (Aquinas)
"my soul is not me" — without the physical body, you wouldn't be identifiable, you need both parts (Aristotle)
the body has a spiritual dimension: the soul (???)

Elizabeth Anscombe

purpose influence — we have reasons behind our actions, reasons behind our thought processes.

"bodily is an act of man qua spirit."

The body and soul relate to each other in order to make a human being

Skinner and Behaviourism
Behaviourism is a type of materialism.

it posits that thoughts are just learned behaviours: mental acts are explainable at a physical level which would direct to not believing in a soul that directs us.

see the Pavlov's dogs experiments for examples of learned mental behaviours
also see that our brain takes a lot of shortcuts to function. It is a tad crazy how much we work on assumptions.

Why do we need to have a soul?
Hard problem of conciousness
This was created by David Chalmers. He argues that bodily function alone cannot explain the depth of human conciousness — so therefore there must be a soul/ some separate substance.

You could, if you wanted to, counter this with the argument from ignorance fallacy: just because you can't prove it, doesn't mean it isn't true.

Other philosphers
Daniel C. Dennett

humans can't be reduced to learned behaviours, Skinner's reasons would only be correct if Dennett's explanation of something stopped at having a desire — but our thinking goes much further.

Skinner oversimplifies human conciousness — to him there is no difference between human or pigeon

John Cottingham

If we are just mind and body, no soul — it doesn't make sense: the human experiences of passion, emotions, and sensations cannot be reduced to either category.

Summary of strengths and weaknesses
Plato's substance dualism

Strengths
Weaknesses

mental and physical are very different realms — certain mental things cannot be reduced to something physical, like emotions
Why not? Physical things often cause mental things.

gives hope and purpose for another life
appeal to emotion

Could solve the problem of evil — i.e. Buddhist idea of karma, (you are suffering now because you were evil in a past life)
This is reliant on the world of forms.

explains deja vu and other strange human experiences — like intuition
argument from ignorance

It's obvious that there is no physical evidence for a soul — the idea of physical evidence for something immaterial is nonsensical.
There is no physical evidence for a soul (Dawkins)

we have different physical perceptions — if we all experienced the world of forms then surely that... wouldn't be the case?

Why do things have to have opposites? Why does death have to lead to life? Hunger doesn't bring about fullness, etc

we see ourselves as unified — not a separate soul operating a machine. Our bodies are often core parts of our identities.

it makes the physical world seem pointless. Why not just kill ourselves to get to the world of forms?

there is absolutely no evidence for the multiple assumptions Plato uses to argue for dualism (world of forms, argument from opposites, etc)

how does a spirit interact with a body? They are two different substances.

if all souls came from the world of forms, wouldn't everyone be as clever as each other/ have access to the same intuition/knowledge?

Aristotle's property dualism strengths and weaknesses

Strengths
weaknesses

we are a unified whole
still the same case of how can a spiritual thing and material thing interact

no empirical evidence for an afterlife -> so there isn't one!
why, since spirit and body are opposites, is it not the case that the soul lives on?

title: Mind, body and soul
content: Dualism Spec on mind, body and soul Questions • materialist critiques of dualism, and dualist responses to materialism • whether the concept of ‘soul’ is best understood metaphorically or as a reality • the idea that any discussion about the mind-body distinction is a category error Content Content Key knowledge The philosophical language of MBS in the thinking of Plato and Aristotle Plato's view of the soul as the essential and immaterial part of a human, temporarily united with the body Aristotle's view of the soul as the body; the way the body behaves and lives; something which cannot be separated from the body the metaphysics of consciousness, including: substance dualism The idea that the mind and body are distinct substances Descartes' proposal of material and spiritual substances as a solution to the mind-body-soul problem materialism the idea that the mind and consciousness can be fully explained by physical or material interactions the rejection of a soul as a spiritual substance Extra reading from the spec Blackmore, S. (2010) Consciousness; an introduction, Routledge, Chapters 1, 2 and 17 • Ryle, G. (1949 – many editions available) The Concept of Mind, Chapter 1 • Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (2003 rev. 2009) Ancient Theories of the Soul mind-body-soul summary notes Fun articles Descartes and the mind-body-soul problem The rise and fall of the mind-body-soul problem Freud on consciousness Christian perspective on the mind-body-soul problem Full books magical thinking and dualism

title: Anselm's theories
content:
(ew) #lessonminor
Anselm's four dimensional approach to the timelessness of God

he uses Boethius
develops the idea of seeing "all moments" of time at once at all times
But he sees human existence like this:
For us humans, only the present moment exists; the past is gone; the future hasn't happened; the only reality is the present. We cannot go back to change something and we cannot know what will happen next week because it doesn't exist.

Four dimensionalist

height
width
depth
time (different to how you would hear people talk about the 4th dimension now: instead they would use the word duration.)

Yesterday, the past, next week and the future are relative terms for the person who is doing the perceiving at any given moment.
Our imagination struggles with past/present/future existing at the same time

For Anselm, the eternal present of God is not the same thing as "our present"
eternity is a non-temporal concept which in Anselm's understanding is in the Fourth dimension

Humans exist in a particular place in space and time. We have a different view of if something is near or far depending on where we are.

ITS THE FUCKING EPISTEMIC GAP YOU MOTHERFUCKER
God is unlimited by space and time- he is limitless

do other work here babes
Katherine Rogers
-> Although the points of a circle's circumference are all in different places relative to one another, they all share the same relationship with the centre of the circle; likewise, God shares the same relationship with each and every point in time
Second analogy

is between a mountain climber surveying a landscape and God surveying time: just as a mountain climber can see the entire landscape from the summit of the mountain, so can God see each and every moment in time stretched out before him from his vantage point.

Free will?

does God's foreknowledge of our actions allow free will?

God's eternity is the 4th dimension: he knows our future as unchanged whereas we inside time see the future changing because of our choice
this means Anselm does not deny the reality of our temporal world but God is in a non-temporal world

God can justifiably judge us because we are morally responsible

we have chosen freely and God can see at all times. This is all happening, "at the same time, it exists simultaneously in an eternal presence"

Watch your language!

since we have no other vocabulary, it means we find it difficult to grasp God's knowledge and action so it is difficult for us to talk about the fourth dimension
One question might be- how can God be part of our world if the eternity of God is in another dimension?

consider:

the significance of Jesus
what happens when we pray
is God a personal God if he is in another dimension?

Swinburne's criticisms
"the worst person you know just made a great point." :(
Summary of key points

it's unbiblical
logically incoherent
makes no sense in light of worship and prayer

Hezekiah (Bible story)
In those days, Hezekiah became ill and was at the point of death. The prophet Isaiah son of Amos went to him and said, "This is what the Lord says; put your house in order, because you are going to die; you will not recover."
Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to the Lord "remember Lord, how I have walked before you faithfully and with wholehearted devotion and have done what is good in your eyes." And Hezekiah wept bitterly.
Then the word of the Lord came to Isaiah. "Go and tell Hezekiah, 'this is what the Lord, the God of your father David, says: I have heard your prayer and seen your tears; I will add 15 years to your life."

Often in the Old testament, God pronounces judgement and then forgives people and allows them a fresh start. This judgement culminates in Jesus' death and resurrection.

Swinburne points out that when Christians worship and pray they are interacting with God and speak of a personal relationship

"A totally immutable God is a lifeless God."
However, in this verse, God has perfect knowledge of what he will do and his intentions are fixed or his views are fixed.
'Does he speak and then not act? Does he promise and not fulfill?'
This verse suggests divine timelessness:

'"I am the Alpha and the Omega," says the Lord God, "who is, and who was, and who is to come, the almighty."'

A loving God cannot be immutable (even is he loves unconditionally.) A loving relationship responds to the subject of their love as a process and sequence of events.

#intro
https://whsat.sharepoint.com/:w:/r/sites/Section_27011/_layouts/15/Doc.aspx?sourcedoc={7078AC24-67A7-4C22-9F54-D495AD400AA9}&file=Philosophy-topic-8-Attributes-of-God-table.docx&action=default&mobileredirect=true (this is the summary doc.)
What does it mean when philosophers call God simple?
Augustine: God=unchangeable... therefore he can't lose or gain characteristics, because he is perfect.
Aquinas meant by saying God is simple means he is just 'being/existing'

God is immaterial
he has no body with no characteristics
God is simply God

God's nature and his existence are the same thing: so to talk of God is to talk of a being that exists
God is not a kind of thing
Davies
. God is not a thing like a human being but God is a thing in the same sense that one might talk about 'the human race' as a whole.

anything that changes is part of the world and not distinct from it, as God is. If something changeable accounted for there being a world where change occurs, it would be part of that world and couldn't therefore account for it
God is the source of change.

Anselm says that existence is a predicate

Terminology
The discussion of eternal v. everlasting is important because it defines how God views time.
Eternal is existing outside of time
Everlasting is existing as long as time exists

The difference between philosophy and theology is that theology is specifically studying from inside the religion, and philosophy is from outside, or: God can exist outside of Christianity (philosophy), but Christianity cannot exist without a God.

Existentialism is a philosophy that emphasizes individual existence, freedom and choice. It is the view that humans define their own meaning in life, and try make rational decisions despite existing in an irrational universe.
Simple (definition)- God is God, and cannot be explained in terms of parts or characteristics.
What does this mean? The traditional understanding of God is as unchanging, not having parts or characteristics.
Apaphatic- saying what something is by describing what it is
Cataphatic- saying what something is by describing what it is not

title: Omnipotence
content: = #lessonmajor Omnipotence - canvas What can God not do? We need to know the various ideas of God as omnipotent- i.e. divine power and self limitation We need to answer the question of 'whether it is possible or necessary to resolve the apparent conflicts between divine attributes. Logical problems can God create a stone too heavy for himself to lift, or a knot which he cannot untie? is God's omnipotence compatible with his omni-benevolence? For example, would it be illogical for God to be able to do evil (as he can do anything) and unable to do evil (as he is perfectly good) Problem of evil problems In an example raised by Michael Dummett : 'You hear the news that the ship your loved ones were on, sank two hours ago, with few survivors.' Does it make sense to pray in this situation? could God change what happened, or is your loved one safe because God knew that you would pray? How would a religious believer answer this question? God's omnipotence in theodicies Both Anselm and Descartes rely on God's omnipotence for their theodicies Anselm says that God is 'that which nothing greater can be conceived'- and that God has all perfections, including existence. If God was anything less than omnipotent then we could conceive of a greater, more powerful being; so God, by definition must be omnipotent Descartes says that yes, God can do absolutely anything Aquinas God is immaterial, he has no body with characteristics- 'God is God' Anselm says that God's nature and his existence are the same thing- to talk of God is to talk of a being that exists (also, God can only do what is logically possible) he says that to do the logically impossible is meaningless It adds nothing to God's power to do the logically impossible 'Meaningless combinations of words do not suddenly acquire a meaning because we prefix them two other words: 'God can"' Davies God is not a think like a human being but God is a thing in the same sense that one might talk about 'THE human race' as a while anything that changes is part of the world and not distinct from it, as God is. If something changeable accounted for their being a world were change occurs, it would be part of that world and couldn't therefore account for it. But I am the devil from the ~Bible~ the bible has no support for God not being able to do the logically impossible Scholar Summary Example Weakness Anselm God is TWNGCBC problem of evil Aquinas God can only do what is logically possible. Vardy God's ability to act is limited- if God acted in any other way, everything would not be able to exist the way that it does. Why can I never escape the epistemic gap? Macquarrie God's power is very different from our own- God's nature will always be partly unknowable to us. WHY CAN I NEVER ESCAPE THE EPISTEMIC GAP!!!!!! Kenny 'the possession of all logically possible powers for a being with the attributes of God to have' Platinga God limits his powers to preserve free will. (Epistemic gap!) Geach God's omnipotence is power over everything rather than power to do everything Descartes Agrees with Anselm- God can do absolutely everything. Then why can't he stop suffering but create free beings? (i.e. problem of evil. Again)Also- if he can do the logically impossible, how can we trust him?

title: Omniscience
content: Omniscience LoA Problem of free will if God knew you were going to eat cornflakes tomorrow morning, could you be free to choose differently? could you have toast instead? if God knows everything, does this include events in the future as well as the past? If he does, then it suggests that the future is fixed and we have no free will. ==If we have free will, then we cannot be blamed or praised for our actions ==Religion teaches that God gave us free will, so that we may make our own decisions, decide our own futures, with no coercion from God If God knows all things throughout time (as he must if he is omniscient) then he knows every action I perform, every decision I make throughout my life, before I have done them. If God knows everything, then he must know what I am going to do before I do it. For example, that I am going to drink this glass of water. If God knows it, then it must be true that I drink the water. If it's true that I drink the water, then it can't be false that I drink the water. That means |I have no choice, I will drink the water. This means either God is omniscient but we lack free will or we have free will but God is not omniscient (and therefore not God) one response to this is to argue that God's omniscience extends to all things that are possible to know, but free will makes it impossible to know the future Also- a God that makes a soul that is guaranteed to go to hell and suffer for eternity is evil. If God knows everything, how do we know he hasn't also predetermined those things? Problem of evil yippee if god is 'eternal' and our behavior is predetermined or foreseen, then is God partly responsible for evil actions brought about by our free choices? Can he be omni-benevolent? If he can foresee evil then why does he not prevent it? Boethius (the bitch) In his book 'The Consolation of Philosophy'- Lady Philosophy states God's foreknowledge isn't the cause of future events happening God is eternal but we still have freedom- he says that God's knowledge is causal- he sees the future but in doing so is simply foreseeing the actions that humans choose out of free will Augustine if you have a friend that you know very well, you may know that he is about to sin. But your knowledge does not cause him to sin. Similarly God doesn't cause someone to sin but sees beforehand those who are going to sin by their own will. BUT this analogy is unfair; the foreknowledge of the friend and of God are different. The former cannot be wrong, whereas human foreknowledge can Aquinas built upon Boethius- God takes in all history as a whole, he has a 'birds-eye' perspective. God looks down from above at what choices will be made but this knowledge of the choices that will be made isn't casual- free choices can still be made Anselm's theories #lessonmajor

title: Philosophy questions
content:
Nature and attributes of God
Aquinas speaks of two Analogies, what are these? $line{"Proportion", "Attribution"} and $line{"Proportion", "Attribution"}
Give an example for both: for A- $input{"analogy of the baker", "analogy of the bull"}, for Pr- $input{"analogy of the guitarist", "analogy of the dog"}

Brummer is critical about analogy because we cannot make claims about $input{God}.

Barth is critical about analogy because it suggests that we can't come to God through experience. What do we need? $input{"revelation", "revalation"}.

How can we refer to positive language? Via $input{affirmativa} or the $input{cataphatic} way.

How can we refer to negative language? Via $input{negativa} or the $input{apophatic} way.

#intro If God is transcendent and ineffable, how can we describe God in any meaningful way? I.e. how do we overcome the epistemic gap? Checklist Exam board both the via negativa and via positiva ways considered whether language can be used in any adequate or meaningful sense to talk about God evaluated uses of symbol, analogy and myth, language as a game; to help communicate human understanding of God are conversations about God meaningful/intelligible if we use symbol? reflected on the Views of Aquinas, Views of Paul Tillich, and the views of Ludwig Wittingstein Useful definitions Univocal: words mean the same things in different situations (like colours.) Equivocal: words which have totally different meanings depending on the context (dining table, periodic table) Cognitive language: language based on facts, facts that are known to be true through knowledge. (e.g. The cat is asleep on the chair.) Non-cognitive language: language that cannot be proven to be true or false through knowledge (emotive, moral, and ethical language. Like saying "yippee!") What do we mean by religious language? Specialist terms- life 'Eucharist, 'messiah', etc. Old fashioned words from acts of worship: 'thou art', and 'blessed be he' Truth-claims- i.e. statements about what is or is not the case ('Jesus is alive today) Expressing feelings/emotions: 'we are truly sorry and repent for all our sins' used to announce something has happened or is about to happen: "I baptize you in the name of the Lord" is using Religious language performatively Prescriptively: encouraging people not to act certain ways ("Honour your father and mother... you shall not murder.") Terminology (again) A MYTH is a story that has deep explanatory or symbolic resonance for a culture and one that is believed to be true by those who tell it. The term is sometimes used pejoratively in reference to common beliefs of a culture or for the beliefs of a religion to imply that the story is both fanciful and fictional. A PARABLE is a story that is told to illustrate a religious, moral or philosophical idea. In rhetoric, a PARABLE ('comparison' or 'similitude') was originally the name given by Greek rhetoricians to any fictive illustration introduced in the form of a brief narrative. A SYMBOL is a representation of an idea, thing, concept, or quality. A word, for example, is a SYMBOL of language, which references its own definition. That is, it "stands for" some idea, thing, concept, or quality, as defined by its given language. A METAPHOR is a figure of speech that is used to paint one concept with the attributes normally associated with another. An ANALOGY is a comparison between two things. ANALOGIES are often used to introduce new concepts, by comparing them to something familiar, or to support political and philosophical arguments. A PROPOSITION is what is asserted as the result of uttering a sentence. In other words, it is the meaning of the sentence, rather than the sentence itself. Different sentences can express the same PROPOSITION, if they have the same meaning. A SIMILIE is a figure of speech that expresses a resemblance between things of different kinds (usually formed with 'like' or 'as') Via affirmativia (the cataphatic way) in religious language it is assumed that God can be spoken of in the affirmative- that we can make positive claims about him. We do this by using positive qualities of human experience and applying them to God For example, there is qualities such as 'goodness', 'truth' and 'love' which we understand in our own lives and experiences. These can also be applied to God- it makes sense to speak of God as 'good' or 'just' etc adherents include Aquinas, Augustine, and Anselm Weaknesses to this approach "The first time when you seek God, you only find darkness: and as it were a cloud of unknowing... This darkness and this cloud is, whatever you do, between you and God, and... you may not see him clearly by the light of your understanding in your reason... for if ever you shall feel him or see him... it is right always to be in this cloud in this darkness." Literally just the epistemic gap. I am fucking sick of this shite. God is infinite and wholly immaterial and transcendent- so how can 'God talk' tell us real facts about God if he is not a being to which the human language of nouns, adjectives and verbs can apply? IT'S THE FUCKING EPISTEMIC GAP Language is subjective. People have different concepts of justice, love, kindness, etc It's misleading- if we say God is a father or a shepherd, then many people may think that God has a body, or is male, or has faults. What about 'God is love' or 'God is good'? some argue that it is better to accept the mysteries of God than try to pin God down using human/flawed concepts. Via negativa (the apophatic way) literally means the 'negative way' because God can only be described in terms of what God is not. - apophatic comes from the Greek word 'apophasis'- which means 'negation.' It argues that God is transcendent so you cannot say what God is. However you can clearly say what God is not; God is not a human being because God is transcendent, so God cannot have a body. Equally, when Christians say God is good they may not know exactly what they mean, when they use the word 'good' but they know for sure that God is not evil. Arguably, speaking about God in negative terms avoids the problem of misrepresenting God. Ultimately, language cannot describe God. people who believe in the apophatic way are not saying that you cannot say things about God- such as 'God is /omniscient/omnibenevolent etc', but that this language does not actually tell us about God because our knowledge of goodness is that of a human being. OUR LANGUAGE IS CREATED BY US, AND SO IS FLAWED IN THE SAME WAYS THAT WE ARE ==ITS THE FUCKING EPISTEMIC GAP!! If we talk about God being all-knowing then we can debate what this means, but in the end we cannot know for certain what it is to be all knowing. Many religious people have maintained that philosophy and talk about God are misleading and that instead of bringing us closer to an understanding of God, language may have the opposite effect. The way to know God is to remove language itself- since it places God in the limits of human language. Instead emphasis should be given to mysticism, spirituality & prayer, as paths to a deeper understanding of God. Supporting scholars Fake Dionysius The apophatic way was developed by the early church writer Pseudo Dionysius, or Dionysius the Aeropagite. His writings originated much later than the time of the apostles- because he is not the Dionysius of the Acts of the Apostles. This is why he is called 'pseudo' If we say God is good then we have to say God is not good, because we do not really know what it means to say God is Good. In 'The mystical theology'- the fake god stated that God is 'beyond assertion' and 'beyond denial' - whatever you say about God ultimately does not tell us anything about God, and you cannot say absolutely what God is not. In 'Divine names' and 'the mystical union'- he develops the view that through prayer an individual could be united with God through abandoning senses, images and language. Influenced by Plato, he argued that the soul's search for God was held back by the demands of the body and the mind's desire for understanding. => stop trying to use logic and arguments! Allow God to speak in the stillness- accepting God will remain a mystery. Maimonides He is a Jewish 12th century philosopher. He argues that human beings can know that God exists but not anything about God, because God is not like human beings he finds support in Jewish scriptures where God is described as being 'i am who i am'- literally called Yawhey (I am)- he is beyond any description. he speaks about the dangers of anthropomorphising God allows man to compare himself to God based on characteristics such as with sex, race, etc The hand and mouth of God Rather we come nearer to knowledge of God through negative attributes, for example God is not limited, and so on. He gives the example of a ship to illustrate what he meant. Essentially, you learn about something by describing what it is not. i.e. the process of elimination. THIS IS THE ONENOTE FOR THIS LESSON IF YOU WANT TO SEE IT. https://whsat.sharepoint.com/sites/Section_WHS14021/_layouts/15/Doc.aspx?sourcedoc={36aa2c81-36fa-44cc-b896-64f426a01bf5}&action=view&wd=target(Leah Johnston%2FPaper 1.one|c6a694ad-780f-4fce-a139-4a1cdca2eca1%2FRel Lang via affirmativa\%2Fnegativa|81e2f779-ea97-4544-9285-1ff6064f3234%2F)&wdorigin=NavigationUrl St. John of the Cross; a famous mystic God is neither material, not the vital, nor the mental, nor the personal soul. He is nothing created. He is not within creation. Background to the apophatic way It came from the philosophy of Plotinus in the second century CE. Plotinus was at the centre of a movement that reviewed interest in the philosophy of Plato. He linked Plato's Form of the Good with God. Because of this link God is seen as completely separate and beyond this world, just as the Form of the Good is the highest Form and separate from the other forms. Weaknesses of the apophatic way Anthony Flew argues that if we say that God is invisible, soundless, incorporeal, and so on, there is little difference between our definition of God and our definition of nothingness. you could say everything via negativa and it ends up being via positiva. it is a way of recognising that we have to go beyond our normal everyday experiences

title: Analogy
content: Analogy Worksheet questions According to Aquinas, we can say positive/affirmative things about god. Under what condition? Aquinas says that via positiva can be used when it is expressly analogy. Aquinas was opposed to using univocal and equivocal language when talking about God Why did he reject this? Univocal language is too limiting of an infinite God, equivocal language does not allow us to gain knowledge of God through reason because of subjectivity. Example of equivocal language Table, punch, illness, etc The same word when applied to God means something totally different when applied to human beings. Why did Aquinas reject this? Because it doesn't allow us to gain knowledge through reason Instead, Aquinas recommended analogical language. What assumption does Aquinas make? That God can be understood/that human language can understand God Aquinas distinguished between two types Analogy of attribution - we ascribe a quality to one thing because it is caused by another. For example, a skilled baker makes loaf of bread. We ascribe that the bread is good because the baker is skilled. What is Aquinas' Analogy of the Bull? If the bulls urine is healthy then the bull is healthy, and if the bull is healthy then the urine must be healthy. Similarly, God produces everything in the world. What do we mean when we say God is 'good, wise and loving.' God is the source of 'good, wise and loving' — he is perfectly all of these things all of the time. This is basically Plato's idea of forms. ALTHOUGH, just because he has those attributes, doesn't mean he is the source of those attributes Analogy of proportion We ascribe a quality to one thing because it points towards another thing which has that quality. The words that relate to objects are different in proportion. Give an example> The dog is clever, but only as clever as dogs go — and the scientist is clever (which is compared to other people.) How can a mother's love for her daughter point to divine love? Human love points to divine love, like how dog's cleverness points to human cleverness Is analogy a clear way of understanding God? A more modern version of the idea of speaking about God with analogy comes from Ian Ramsey. He tried to explain the way that religious language could usefully describe God, by using 'models and qualifiers.' A model assists us to understand the thing that it represents, it is an analogy to help us express something about God. 'God is good' contains the model 'good.' We understand the human concept of goodness, and we apply it as a model to understand the nature of God. Why do we need to adapt the model? Because God is infinite, and humans are finite What does the qualifier do? The qualifier is how we adapt the model- to make it infinite. (model can also be caused 'ideal/idea') Model Qualifier Cause God is uncaused, God is the causer () Wise Omniscience Good Perfect and unending — God is the source of goodness Creation Created everything, including non-physical things The model is our understanding of a word. It is like a toy plane to a toy man — the toy man can understand the concept of a plane, but cannot comprehend the scale of a real plane — the qualifier is what the toy man uses to explain that there is an uncomprehend-able difference in scale. We use qualifiers to apply our human concepts to God. what are the strengths of using analogy? Acknowledges the flawed and unnuanced nature of human language. Allows us to gain knowledge of God through reason, using language as the tool. What are the weaknesses of using analogy? It's still using human language. It can explicitly never be a perfect description, and so can never be accurate. Epistemic gap Still using equivocal language Test of knowledge Aquinas speaks of two Analogies, what are these? Attribution and proportion. Example for each analogy — analogy of the Bull for attribution, analogy of the dog for proportion. Brummer is critical of this was because he says we are not entitled to make claims about God. Barth is critical of analogy because it suggests we can't come to God through experience. What do we need? Revelation. Positive language can also be called cataphatic or via affirmativa Negative language can be called apophatic or via negativa Name someone connected to the apophatic way. Maimonides or Pseudo Dionysus If one realises the transcendence of God, one will realise the limitations of expressing anything about God, so one might liken this way to the via negativa. All that encounter the mystery of God will realise the limitations of language and this will apply to both the cataphatic and apophatic way.

title: Kantian ethics
content:
Principles of Kantian ethics
Note that chapters 9 and 10 (p.125-141) in The Elements of Moral Philosophy are absolutely fantastic reading for discovering the nuances of Kant's arguments

Principle
Explanation
Misc

Duty
Kant believed that there was nothing good except good will. Nothing else matters: not the consequences of an action, not your emotions about an action, etc. We must be ethical because it is our duty to be ethical.
> This makes his theory deontological and absolutist.

Reason
Acting by feelings will lead to inconsistent morality — especially when acting for/against specific people.Acting teleologically is wrong because we do not know the effects our actions will have.> Therefore we must always act with reason and with accordance of our duty.
Teleologically is in accordance with purpose — telos=purpose.Also see the article below — it is good reading for Kant. To understand how he would respond is to understand many of his ideas.

The categorical imperative
1. Universal law: a maxim must be able to be universalized. If you are not willing for anyone to do an action, you should not do it.2. Means to an end: one must never treat a person as a means only, always as an end. People should never be used for the sake of others to support some abstract ideal.3. Kingdom of ends: treat everyone as people for whom good must be done.4. Legislating member: you have to imagine that you create the rules and everyone will follow them.
Note that the means to an end doesn't mean you can't use someone as a means — otherwise society wouldn't function. It's just that you must also treat them as an end at the same time.For understanding Kant's 'legislating member principle', read this article on the prisoner's dilemma. TLDR: Kant always picks the most virtuous option, no matter the opponent.

the hypothetical imperative
'if you want to do well in your exams, you must study'. Hypothetical imperatives aren't on the same level as categorical imperatives.
You shouldn't really mention these in exams: they don't matter.

Immortality and God
Kant noted that in order for there to be a reason for us to do our duty, we must be rewarded for our actions.>This is through the summum bonum the place where all our happiness and virtue come together.>> This is not something achievable on earth — so it must be the afterlife.
This argument is then how he argues for the existence of God: a being who can arbitrate this reward.

Three postulates of pure reason
Kant said that there were three conditions on reality that are necessary for his theory to work.1. We must have free will in order to make our own decisions2. There must be an afterlife so that we can achieve the summum bonum3. There must be a God in order for there to be a fair judge on who should achieve this.
This is a moral argument for the existence of God

title: Natural Moral Law
content:
#lessonmajor #unfinished

Specification

Content
Key knowledge

Telos
Origins of the concept of telos in Aristotle and it's religious development from Aquinas.

The four tiers of law
The eternal law, the divine law, natural law, and human law

The precepts
The key precept (do good and avoid evil), the five primary precepts, and secondary precepts

Thomas Aquinas
Objective morality

Found in Aristotelian and Stoic ethical thought;

"The law that is written on men's hearts." -St. Paul

Natural law appeals to the sense that certain things can be known — by anyone — to be right or wrong.

There is an absolute and universal good and evil.
This means that eternal and universal justice applies to everything.
It is deontological and absolutist

Aquinas' four tiers of law

Eternal law — the mind or reasoning of God, only seen through natural law
Divine law — eternal law written down/shown in scriptures such as the Bible, allows us to use natural reason to access what is right or wrong.
Natural law — rational exercise of working out what is good for human flourishing; "right reason in accordance with human nature." Follows the direction of eternal law.
Human law — human ability to interpret the Natural Law and set rules for society so that people can flourish.

Phronesis

[!info]
Phronesis is practical reasoning, judgement and conscience.

Aquinas rejected divine command theory — arguing that what God commands is right.
He believed that morality could be accessed through reason alone; morality rooted in reason, justified and developed in scripture.
Theoretical law is just intellect, whereas practical knowledge allows us to make the right decisions according to natural law, in order to achieve our telos and not be swayed by out passions.
Conscience guides us to act with reason.
God gave us conscience in order to access natural law.
Virtuous habits also direct us towards good acts.

[! tip] Aquinas' thinking;
REASON + VIRTUE + CONSCIENCE = PRACTICAL JUDGEMENT = DO GOOD AND AVOID EVIL = EUDAMONIA/PURPOSE

title: Situation ethics
content: Principles Agape For example; The four working principles The six fundamental principles Questions on Situation ethics Principles Agape Agape= love. it is drawn from Jesus saying that the 'greatest commandment' is to 'love your neighbour as yourself.' Fletcher interprets this as being love is all that matters in ethics. so the rest of the 10 commandments do not matter. Only love does. For example; Fletcher gives the example of a family hiding from bandits when their baby starts crying- which would reveal where they are hiding. Fletcher says that the most loving thing to do is to kill the baby, otherwise everyone else will die; including the baby. Isn't this just the trolley problem? The four working principles These are how to apply situation ethics/agape to ethics. Pragmatism; an action must take into account the reality of the situation Relativism; all absolutes become relative to love. Not absolutizing the relative means that it is not total relativism where any moral claim could be justified. It is always relative to love which means that only moral claims which are valid when relative to love will be justified for Fletcher' Positivism; ethics has to have faith in love Personalism; put people above the rules 'The sabbath was made for man, not man for sabbath.'- Jesus. The six fundamental principles love is the only thing that is intrinsically good love is the ruling norm in ethical decision making and replaces all laws love and justice are the same thing: justice is love distributed love wills the neighbour's good regardless of whether the neighbour is liked only the end justifies the means; nothing else Love decides on each situation as it arises without a set of laws to guide it Fletcher's views on Conscience Fletcher thought that conscience was what enabled one to figure out how to apply agape in any situation. He says that conscience is a verb, not a noun; indicating that he disagrees with the view that conscience is an internal moral compass/ the intuitive ability to tell right from wrong. Strengths and weaknesses of situation ethics Strengths Weaknesses Personal — respects individuals and communities and what they value. Avoids detached ways of thinking. Interpretation — because it has no moral truths, morals are up to interpretation, which could lead to conflict. Flexible — able to adapt per situation Inconsistent — changes on the situation so people don't have a easy way to know how to act. Love-based — love is great and tends to bring about happiness. What is love? — this is up for interpretation and further muddies the pot People-focussed — because it's based on love, it's focussed on the wellbeing of others Human nature — people do not naturally act with love all the time Guidelines — still provides a framework for making moral choices Consequences — since it's teleological one has to consider all outcomes before acting: which can be very impractical. Evil — permits a person to carry out evil acts for a good result Conscience — Fletcher's definition of conscience is reductionistic: most people review their actions afterwards to consider if they acted correctly Good isn't always right — sometimes 'bad' acts must be committed because they are the right thing to do. Unchristian — doesn't go by fundamental biblical principles. Questions on Situation ethics • whether or not situation ethics provides a helpful method of moral decision-making • whether or not an ethical judgement about something being good, bad, right or wrong can be based on the extent to which, in any given situation, agape is best served • whether Fletcher’s understanding of agape is really religious or whether it means nothing more than wanting the best for the person involved in a given situation • whether or not the rejection of absolute rules by situation ethics makes moral decision-making entirely individualistic and subjective

title: Utilitarianism
content: Table of contents Philosopher's backgrounds Jeremy Bentham John Stuart Mill Act utilitarianism The hedonic calculus Strengths and weaknesses of Act Rule utilitarianism Higher and lower pleasures Rules Strengths and weaknesses of Rule Overall strengths and weaknesses [!info] Principle of utility "The greatest good for the greatest number." Utilitarianism has 3 major branches: Act, Rule, and the irrelevant one. They all agree on the principle of utility, but they disagree on how they define 'good', and therefore they disagree on how to achieve it. If you are going to use Utilitarianism in any essay, you are probably going to have to mention both, because they are quite different. Our two philosophers for this are Bentham and J.S. Mill Philosopher's backgrounds Jeremy Bentham Bentham campaigned for legal and social reform in the late 1700s to early 1800s — specifically on slavery and women's rights. He came up with the principle of utility and the hedonistic calculus. He believed that humans are psychological hedonists: i.e. we always seek our own pleasure John Stuart Mill J.S. Mill was a liberal politician and social philosopher. He posited that all knowledge is based on experiences, and desires/beliefs are products of psychological laws. for him, ethics was based on the desire of humans to be happy. He also came up with the harm principle. This comes from his liberal ideas: it is that as long as one isn't doing harm, Act utilitarianism This was Bentham's utilitarianism. it's teleological 🡺 whatever will bring about the most good He had to define what good was. Because Bentham was a hedonist, he believed that pleasure=good/happiness for him, the two are interchangeable. The hedonic calculus He then creates the hedonic calculus to determine how good an act is. It uses various variables: intensity duration certainty propinquity (how soon) fecundity (follow-on pleasure) purity of pleasure extent Strengths and weaknesses of Act Strengths Weaknesses Gives a solid, repeatable method for evaluating situations No type of action is ruled out if it's satisfying for a lot of people (Tyranny of the majority) hedonic calculus helps rationalise our decisions — it also accounts for pleasure in the long run over short term oain takes too long to work out and is too subjective and how tf are you making ethics into maths it isn't dictatorial: allows for individual complexity in ethics not everybody is a competent judge: allows for perception to cloud ethics too much only thinks of the outcome pleasure can be bad The utility monster critique This is directly copied from this web article by Jiajia Huang on the utility monster critique. The Utility Monster theory is a hypothetical situation involving a hypothetical being called the Utility Monster and some cookies. From consuming each cookie, the Utility Monster produces much more “happiness” than the average person, thus being able to provide more happiness to the populace than the average person. So, following the tenets of utilitarianism, one would give the Utility Monster more cookies than the rest of the humans to produce the greatest output of happiness. However, the amount of cookies —a metaphor for human resources in this problem— is limited, which means that if the Utility Monster were to receive more cookies, cookies would have to be taken away from everyone else; thus reducing the happiness output of others. This is obviously unfair as there is an imbalance between the cookies being doled out to the Utility Monster and any other person. Despite this act of unfairness, giving more cookies to the Utility Monster would still produce the greatest amount of utility for the populace and net happiness would be maximized. Still, others would lack resources —or in this case, cookies— and would have to suffer in exchange for greater net happiness. In order to increase net happiness, more people would have to suffer. This is a drawback of utilitarianism. This philosophy of maximized happiness and utility will always be subject to those “utility monsters.” This raises the question, is net happiness and utility representative of true happiness and utility? You could say that a group’s utility is directly correlated to the utility of the least happiest person in said group. But what is happiness and how can it be measured? Can it even be measured in the first place? Happiness varies from person to person and there is no concrete way to quantify the amount of happiness in an individual or a group. This is why utilitarianism does not work as either a concept or a method of action. Utilitarianism centers around the maximization of happiness, something that can’t be properly measured and has no concrete unit. Furthermore, utilitarianism even goes so far as to contradict its own philosophy as seen with the example of the Utility Monster. Rule utilitarianism Mill disagreed with hedonism — he thought good is something other than pleasure. he reformulated utilitarianism to reflect that good =/= pleasure, and that pleasures aren't all of equal value He introduced the theory of utility — which replaced pleasure for happiness. He defined happiness as something which is cultural and spiritual, and not just physical He also distinguished between lower and higher pleasures. Higher and lower pleasures He took a qualitative approach compared to Bentham's more quantitative approach. He divided pleasures into higher and lower higher pleasures were things such as poetry and music lower pleasures were things such as eating and drinking [!QUOTE] "it is better to be a human satisfied than a pig dissatisfied." His line of thought was similar to Epicureans: a group of intellectuals that thought mental pleasure > bodily pleasure Rules Note that Mill used the principle of utility not for individual situations, but to come up with rules for all of society: which are then followed. Mill is using the principle of utility as a method for discovering the best way of government: essentially just setting the goal as the principle of utility. Strengths and weaknesses of Rule Strengths Weaknesses Less relative: we won't have extremists doing things because their perception of pleasure is different to ours Decides which is higher and which is lower pleasures, when that is relative higher pleasures do enrich life more than lower quality pleasures Elitist: higher pleasures favour intellectuals: which is historically the upper class. always know if you are being moral because it is deontological Rule fetishism: prevents us from considering our actions because we just accept the rules- regardless of complexity of situations. Overall strengths and weaknesses Strengths Weaknesses A system which aims to create greater happiness for individuals/groups is attractive: and provides a simple aim to work for and unite around.> This is the basis of liberalism: which was absolutely revolutionary at the time of it's creation It's teleological 🡺 but we don't always know what will happen from an action. universal principle is important because we should go beyond our point of view we can't judge whether people have acted morally or not. It's an easy system to understand and implement. allows immoral actions for the sake of utility — like treating people as means not ends. It wouldn't work if everyone was utilitarian (?)

title: BDSM and homosexuality
content: Table of contents Introduction There is a landmark case called R. V. Brown on if consensual acts are always morally justifiable. [!QUOTE] "It is not clear to me that the activities of the appellants were exercises of rights in respect of private and family life. But assuming that the appellants are claiming to exercise those rights I do not consider that Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights invalidates a law which forbids violence which is intentionally harmful to body and mind. Society is entitled and bound to protect itself against a cult of violence. Pleasure derived from the infliction of pain is an evil thing. Cruelty is uncivilised. I would answer the certified question in the negative and dismiss the appeals of the appellants against conviction." [!QUOTE] "That proposition can be expressed as follows: an assault intended or which is likely to cause bodily harm, accompanied by indecency, is an offence irrespective of consent, provided that the injury is not 'transient or trifling'." Criminalisation & Consent -- R. V. Brown Using ethical systems to examine BDSM Natural moral law Utilitarianism From a utilitarian perspective, BDSM is okay when it produces more pleasure than harm. this implies that all people involved are fully consenting, because a non-consenting person 'participating' in BDSM would produce more harm than pleasure. This is a good example of a way to use the utility monster critique Situation ethics Kantian ethics The major thing to focus on here is the conditions of the categorical imperative Universalization of laws Theoretically, yes, BDSM can be universalized. If one defines consent as: full knowledge of what will occur capable of rationalizing this (i.e. adults/non-animals) free from the pressure to agree or disagree free to withdraw consent without pressure at any time Then you could definitely argue that — as long as all people involved have full consent — then yes, any BDSM act is perfectly fine. of course, one could argue that this allows for grievous/lasting bodily harm; however, I think anything with such lasting consequences is an event which is hard to have full knowledge/rationalise, then it still fits the definition Of course, you could argue that I am cherry picking — and that is a fair counter argument. However, I do think my definition can be applied universally, so I don't care. means to an end Treating everyone as an end in themselves? Easy! As long as one respects their partner and is not having sex: a) entirely for their own sexual pleasure, and b) whilst treating their partner only as a means and not as an end (which would disrespect their consent — as if you are treating someone as a means you don't care if they consent) then any sexual act is fine. Kingdom of ends legislating member This one is only for use in actually acting out Kant's principles. If you've heard of the prisoner's dilemma, then Kantian ethics demands that one chooses the most virtuous option, no matter if your opponent is guaranteed to choose the option which hurts you. here is an article on the prisoner's dilemma Homosexuality introduction It's likely that people at the time of the Bible thought about homosexuality in a completely different manner: the relationships between men and what was considered homosexuality wold have been completely different. Key terms both of these words appear in the Bible, so it's important to know of them and their context. If you want more info, look at Ben Wardle's dissertation on Biblical Exegesis/Hermeneutics terms for homosexuality Arsenokoitai this can be translated as homosexual relations, or it could be referred to as exploitative/paedophilia relations. It's unclear what it means, although it is definitely sexual Malakoi this literally translates to 'soft/fine' (as in fine clothing.) In the New Testament, it can be interpreted in various ways. sometimes moral weakness sometimes a form of effeminacy some have argued that it's a passive partner in homosexual relations Other terms [!info] Exegesis 'to explain' or 'to interpret' — specifically/especially an interpretation of the Bible. Bible reading Thousands of people have read/translated/transcribed/interpreted and used the Bible in countless ways the Bible is a major source of authority for some Christians. For Theonomous Christians, it is the only source of authority (synoptic link to Christian Moral Principles.) We have fragments of Greek Bibles from the first 400 years and the Latin remains afterwards Misquoting Jesus by Bart Ehrman is good reading for this. There's a YouTube playlist of the podcast recordings here Theology goes through many changes. The current age of academic theology is Postliberal Theology — which accepts exegesis, demythologisation, and narrative theology Different translations of the Bible have very different meanings; of which is often defined by the translator's own theology. Mistranslations On homosexuality Other mistranslations She’s Not a Whore - Translation Bias in Ezekiel 16 Correcting Caricatures - Women in the Bible

title: Sex ethics contextual texts
content: Important texts to reference Song of songs The text Guiding questions Augustine: concupiscence and the shadow of lust Text Analysis Guiding questions Kant: sex, objectification, and the moral law The text Analysis Biographical gossip Guiding questions Important texts to reference Song of songs The text Song of solomon.excalidraw Guiding questions Why is erotic celebration shocking in scripture? Because this is explicitly from the woman's perspective (although in the whole story, it switches back and forth, but still!) and talking about sexual pleasure and sexual acts, with little mention of doing this for pregnancy. The focus on the woman's pleasure here —and the fact that these people are clearly having sex because they love each other — is revolutionary. Does this text support a positive theology of sex — or is it still symbolic? It's quite explicit. I'd have a hard time imagining how this is symbolic. You can't really symbolically suck someone's dick. How might Song of Songs challenge Augustine or Kant For Augustine, it's explicit sexual joy without need of procreation — sex for the sake of sex — which completely challenges his worldview. It's a touch more complicated for Kant, because he comes at it from an ethical perspective, but given how these two people clearly aren't just using each other as means to an end, I think Kant would be fine with it. Augustine: concupiscence and the shadow of lust Text “(I) ran wild in the shadowy jungle of erotic adventures.” “Clouds of muddy carnal concupiscence filled the air; the bubbling impulses of puberty befogged and obscured my heart; I could not tell the difference between lust and love.” Analysis Concupiscence: the post-lapsarian disordering of desire after The Fall. Sex becomes linked to loss of rational control, moral instability, and misdirected love. For Augustine, sexual desire is tainted not because bodies are bad, but because the will is damaged. Only sex within marriage, ordered toward procreation, is morally tolerable — and even then tinged with the “sting of lust.” His view underpins the traditional Christian suspicion of sex: sexual pleasure can enslave the will, obscure reason, and distract from God. Possible links: Natural Moral Law, ordo amoris, virtue/vice, telos, fallen nature. Guiding questions What is Augustine actually afraid of? Loss of reason? Misusing love? Disordered desire? He is afraid of loss of control to his own desires, which are — according to him — inherently sinful after the Fall. Falling prey to his own desires undermines his relationship with God Does Augustine's pessimism about lust undermine the possibility of positive Christian sexual ethics? Abso-fucking-lutely. How does concupiscence explain Christian teachings around chastity, celibacy, and marriage? since we are sinful because of the fall, especially around our desires for relationships (aka concupiscence), we must stay away from sex as much as possible so as to keep as close a relationship with God — however, marriage is safe because it is blessed by God, so one no longer needs to keep to chastity and celibacy. This is also why marriage is so important to Christians, because they want to fuck but can't unless they are married. Kant: sex, objectification, and the moral law The text “In loving from sexual inclination, they make the person into an object of their appetite. As soon as the person is possessed, and the appetite sated, they are thrown away, as one throws away a lemon after sucking the juice from it… Sexual desire drives us to ignore the humanity of our partners and to use them for our own purposes… Only monogamous marriage can make people formally committed to each other’s ends.” Analysis Sex is morally dangerous because it objectifies and treats people as mere means, violating the Categorical Imperative. Kant believes sexual desire is so powerful that we will even consent to being treated as objects in exchange for our own gratification. Only lifelong, monogamous marriage can create a relationship where both partners are committed to treating the other as an end in themselves. This is one of the most negative accounts of sex in Enlightenment philosophy. Biographical gossip Kant was obsessively routine-driven; locals joked they could set their clocks by his afternoon walk. He wrote that sex is morally corrupting yet was rumoured (not proven) to have: fathered an illegitimate child with a servant; had an unusually close relationship with his house-maid; lived with two bachelors known for libertine social lives in his youth. Historical gossip, yes — but useful for debate: does Kant’s personal life destabilise his abstract ethics? Guiding questions Is Kant right that sexual desire is inherently objectifying? This is false correlation. Just because sexual desire is often objectifying, does not mean that it is inherently objectifying. Can consent prevent objectification, or is Kant correct that reciprocity isn’t enough? It's complicated. I objectification can't be retconned by the object consenting to being objectified. Is marriage the only context where sexual desire becomes morally permissible? I think this is just Kant being a product of his time, not because he has actual reasoning behind this.
