title: Rosemary Radford Reuther
content: #lessonmajor [!WARNING] Many of the notes in this topic are mostly unfinished as of 26.11.2025. They will be finished eventually, but they aren't right now. Revolutionary Feminist theology wants to totally revolutionize Christian theology; it advocates worship of Goddess and woman centred culture among other things. A male centred God is problematic and Christianity is irredeemable. Reformist feminist theology advocates modest changes in the current church structure, usually believes in the more traditional aspects of Christian theology but oppose gender bias and unequal power Jesus' challenge to the male warrior Jesus was not the traditional warrior who was expected. Jesus does not bring the expected military victory of the male Messiah. He reflects nationalist revenge mythology of the Davidic Messiah and envisions a time when all human needs are met and people live in harmony without the need for a strong, domineering leader to protect them. "He is expected to win, not to suffer and die." Jesus is a servant kind. He focuses on serving, not ruling He is critical of reigning powers he calls local religious lawyers hypocrites he warns disciples about lording power over others he washes the feet of the disciples Jesus as the incarnation of wisdom Reuther says; Theologically, 'Logos' (the word before he was made man in Jesus) plays the same cosmological roles as Sophia as the ground of creation, revealer of the mind of God, and reconciler of humanity to God

title: Simone De Beauvoir
content: #lessonminor Feminism to become woman is to become 'Other', considered second to men, and systematically blocked from pursuing freedom. (She wrote a book called 'the second sex', it is considered a foundational feminist work) Her live remains controversial, because while she was a teacher, she was accused of sexual misconduct and was fired. Her work does not discuss race, class, and intersectionality. Homework: Comparing Simone de Beauvoir and Butler Task: Read the following extracts from Beauvoir’s The Second Sex (1949) and Judith Butler’s Gender Trouble (1990). Annotate each passage and make notes on: How each writer understands gender and its formation. Points of similarity and difference. How these ideas challenge traditional views of gender. Extracts Woman as “Other” Beauvoir – The Second Sex “One is not born, but rather becomes, a woman. No biological, psychological, or economic fate determines the figure that the human female presents in society; it is civilization as a whole that produces this creature, intermediate between male and eunuch, which is described as feminine.” Butler – Gender Trouble “Gender is the repeated stylization of the body, a set of repeated acts within a highly rigid regulatory frame that congeal over time to produce the appearance of substance — of a natural sort of being.” Social Construction Beauvoir – The Second Sex “Thus humanity is male, and man defines woman not in herself but relative to him; she is not regarded as an autonomous being. … He is the Subject, he is the Absolute — she is the Other.” Butler – Gender Trouble “When the constructed status of gender is theorized as radically independent of sex, gender itself becomes a free-floating artifice, with the consequence that man and masculine might just as easily signify a female body as a male one, and woman and feminine a male body as easily as a female one.” The Problem of Identity Beauvoir – The Second Sex “Representation of the world, like the world itself, is the work of men; they describe it from their own point of view, which they confuse with absolute truth.” Butler – Gender Trouble “There is no gender identity behind the expressions of gender; … identity is performatively constituted by the very ‘expressions’ that are said to be its results.” Reflection Questions What does Beauvoir mean by “One is not born, but rather becomes, a woman”? How does this relate to Butler’s idea of gender as performative? Beauvoir means to say that society as a whole creates gender and enforces it onto women. Butler's is similar- but is more the idea that 'femininity' isn't real- it is women trying to express themselves through a rigid framework. Although Beauvoir's idea's are more signifying the 'second sex', meanwhile Butler says that gender identity isn't real in the first place. How do both writers challenge the idea that gender is natural? both writers put forward the idea that gender is created and not inherent- Beauvoir in that women are 'the second sex', which is a completely different idea to Christo-centric ideas of man and woman as two halves of the same whole. Butler goes further to say that gender is entirely constructed, and not inherent. Where do you see Beauvoir laying the groundwork for Butler? Where does Butler go further? Beauvoir mostly talks about the oppression of women through our gender, that being oppressed is an inherent characteristic of being a woman. Butler goes further in fully saying that gender does not exist in the slightest, that it is nothing but a tool for oppression. How might these ideas connect to debates today about gender identity and social roles? they are both, quite radically, saying that gender does not exist at all AND that it is used as a tool for oppression. This is especially pertinent to the TERF ideology: of gender essentialism and anti-transgender rhetoric, which is (although not obviously, but still very strongly) related inherently to Butler's and Beauvoir's ideas. Because TERF's are 'protecting' gender essentialism, they are essentially the anti-feminists, and it is a misnomer to call them feminists at all, because they clearly do not understand Feminism's ideas.

title: General notes
content:
#lessonminor
"it is essential nor forget the reply of Jesus to the Tempter: "It is not on bread alone that man lives, but on every word that comes from the mouth of God"
"it is a fatal error to separate these two and even worse to put one before the other."_
The main criticism of Liberation Theology is that it is too focussed on the Kingdom of Man and not the more spiritual aspects of Christianity.
Liberation Theologians need to recognise that evil structures come from evil people, not the other way round.
Gutierrez responded to critiques of LT not focussing on spiritual/ personal salvation by arguing that:

"sin is not only an impediment to a break with God in the afterlife, but sin is also a historical reality." a breach of communion, individuals turning in on themselves.
Because sin is both personal and structural
Sin is a social and historical fact, a breach of friendship with God
Sin is most evident in oppressive structures
Sin is both personal and collective.
The work of Christ is a new creation, but he focusses on the structural dimension of sin.
We are the human beings that produce these sins, but for Boff, they don't talk much about moral sin/personal sin. They assume a notion of a baptized continent, original sin is eradicated from your life, so they don't preach conversion.

Most Liberation Theologians are actually social democrats, not communists. Capitalism is inherently reliant on greed, and it rewards greed — if greed is down, then the economy and therefore society suffers.
Capitalism is not interested in religion — it only matters that the system keeps working.
The old testament is VERY interested in economics. It has many positive commandments. Hard work is valued (10-12 hours a day, 6 days a week working), but if people couldn't work, they were expected to be supplied for. They had checks and balances on someone being too greedy.
Liberation Theologians do not ask for an actual system, just one that will prioritize human flourishing. We need to pay much attention to our discourse — and how they still affect the majority of people.
There is so much concentration of sin which separates you from God's law, from your neighbour. The structural dimension of salvation is necessary (see the freedom of the Jewish people in Egypt)- this was not from personal sin, but from structural sin.
There are three main denominations of LT- the one working within the Church, the ones that are still Christian but not beholden to the Church, and the post-christian.
Need to emphasize both personal and structural sin- Gutierrez believes in both but he does not elaborate on it.
Liberation theologians emphasize the kingdom of God as inaugurated — but they put the now over the not yet.
Pope Francis I's first papal letter (the joy of the gospel) was a thorough critique of capitalism. 'how is it news when the stock market lowers by 2 points, but not when an elderly homeless person dies of exposure.' he also said 'this kind of economic system kills'
Ratzinger did not critique LT to justify not helping the poor. He explicitly said that it must not be taken as approval of 'those who keep the poor in misery, who profit from their misery, who notice it and do nothing about it, and those who are indifferent'.
'the church, guided by the gospel of mercy and love for mankind hears the cry of justice, and intends to respond with all it's might

title: Kingdom Theology
content: Augustine's opinions The Kingdom of God Different views of the Kingdom of God Mentions of the Kingdom of God in the Bible Boff Two cities We have the city of man, and the city of God- Augustinian concepts. The city of man is those who love themselves and hate God. It's inherently sinful, and doomed to failure. The city of God is those who love God and forsake themselves. For Augustine, politics is only in the city of man; which is imperfect. We should always aim to be members of the city of God/not involved in politics. Augustine's opinions Because of this, he thinks that one should not interact with politics at all, because it is only in the city of man; which is sinful. The city of man is doomed to fail. He believes that we can only do good through God's grace and acting as God's will on Earth. This is useful for Bonhoeffer, who arguably interacted a lot with both the cities of man and God. The Kingdom of God In Christianity, the kingdom of God is one of Jesus' central but most debated ideas. It can mean God's rule over creation, or a meditative state, or just when one obeys the law of God. Some believe that the kingdom of God is a meditative state. Different views of the Kingdom of God View Description Key thinker When Eschatological The kingdom is in the future, realised at the end of time. Augustine, Barth Not yet Realised The kingdom began with Jesus' ministry. C.H. Dodd Now Inaugurated The kingdom began with Jesus but will be completed in the future. Oscar Cullman Now and not yet Political/Ethical The kingdom is built through justice on Earth. Liberation Theologians Now Mentions of the Kingdom of God in the Bible [!example] Mark- the kingdom is near/at hand "The time has come. The kingdom of God has come near. Repent and believe the good news!" [!example] Luke - the kingdom belongs to the poor "Blessed are you who are poor, for yours is the Kingdom of God" Note that there is another interpretation: "Blessed are the poor in spirit..." in Matthew. [!EXAMPLE] Luke - The kingdom is among you "The kingdom of God is not something that can be observed, because [it is] among you/within you." This is a key text for Augustinian theology- that the Kingdom is an inner reality. Liberation theologians reinterpret "among you" as social presence [!EXAMPLE] Matthew- the kingdom is both now and future "When the son go Man comes in his glory... he will say... 'I was hungry and you gave me something to eat.'" Saying that the final judgement is based on practical acts of mercy. -> For LT, this passage unites social justice and salvation: the future kingdom is judged by present action -> for Augustine, these are fruits of grace within the elect, not conditions for a utopian society on earth. [!EXAMPLE] John- the kingdom is not of this world "My Kingdom is not of this world." Used by the Catholic Magisterium (notable Ratzinger and John Paul II) to caution against political ideology. [!example] Luke 4:16-21 "The Spirit fo the Lord is upon me, because he has anointed me to proclaim good news to the poor. He has send me to proclaim freedom for the prisoners and recovery of sight to the blind, and to set the oppressed free, to proclaim the year of the Lord's favour." Note that the word 'poor' means something else in Greek, of which this is translated from. It doesn't necessarily mean the economically poor but also the socially marginalised. Liberation theologians Thinker/View Key ideas Examples Criticisms Gustavo Gutierrez Two kinds of liberation- social and spiritual. The kingdom begins when injustice ends "To know God is to do justice" Ratzinger: Marxist influence corrupts theology; salvation cannot be reduced to politics Leonardo Boff The Church must be the Church of the poor; orthopraxis before orthodoxy. Emphasises Base Ecclesial communities; such as 'little kingdoms of God.' Silenced by the Vatican: accused of politicising the Gospel. Dom Helder Camara advocates for non-violent structural reform "When I give food to the poor, they call me a saint. When I ask why the poor have no food, they call me a communist." Church accused him of being a Marxist. Segundo Spiritual liberation must proceed social liberation, otherwise political activism risks despair/failure Offers a more Augustinian emphasis Criticised by radicals for watering down the movement. Pope John Paul II / Ratzinger Kingdom of God is not of this world; danger of reducing salvation to politics "Anthropocentric theologies lose sight of transcendence." seen as too conservative and blind to structural injustice. [!info] Orthopraxis It means 'right practice'- 'ortho' meaning correct/right, and 'praxis' meaning practice Boff Note that he was a Latin american laypeople who were involved in the church (they weren't officiated, so they didn't have to follow orders.) He was a Marxist. Essay Practice [!question] "Liberation theology misunderstands the kingdom of God." - Discuss Kingdom of God essay plan

title: Liberation philosophers
content: #lessonmajor Table of Contents Major points that need to be accounted for: Definitions that need to be accounted for: (see later section) Pope John Paul 2nd Marx and Restrepo Is it right for Christians to prioritise one group over another? The church's concern with liberation theology Critics Kloppenburg (always a critic) Richard McBrien Proponents Should Christianity engage with secularist atheist ideologies? Gustavo Gutierrez (VIP) Summary of my ideas Definitions Marxism's main points of interest are: Themes of my argument Does liberation theology compromise christian faith by aligning too closely with Marxism? "When I give food to the poor, they call me a saint. When I ask why the poor have no food, they call me a communist." -Brazilian Archbishop Camara Major points that need to be accounted for: Theme For Against Should the church be political? everything is political- even not involving oneself in politics REFER TO PHILOSPHERS BELOW FOR ALL OF THESE. Should the church focus on the poor? Oppression is intersectional. The poor are also most often also members of other oppressed groups- because the class system is used to oppress the oppressed. Should the church engage in political methodology? the church does not focus on ruling- because they already have a king. They are just ambassadors for the kingdom of God. Should the church engage with the state? refer to above. Should the church focus on structural sin rather than individual sin? Structural sin is the cause of individual sin. The thief only steals because he does not have enough money, etc. Should the church be more focussed on action or prayer? Jesus rarely prays in the Bible: he acts to better society instead. Definitions that need to be accounted for: (see later section) Marxism Violence (political violence/actualised violence/systemic violence) Oppression- (do research into classism) Liberation theology Pope John Paul 2nd Preferential option for the poor. "Constant concern for and dedication to categories of people who are especially beloved to the Lord Jesus." He went on to explain that the advancement of the poor constitutes a great opportunity for the moral, cultural, and economic growth for all of humanity. However, he makes it clear that: spiritual poverty can be caused by an over-emphasis on material goods and consumerism. It is right and proper for the church to concentrate on both spiritual and material matters. Marx and Restrepo Revolution begins with philosophers having solidarity with the oppressed. Marx thinks that the only way to cause change was through 'despotic inroads' (violence) The 'preferential treatment for the poor' is indebted to Marx as it awakens the conscience of those in power to force the church into a struggle against injustice. 'Words without action are empty. Revolution, even violence, may be needed in order to make the people free.' - Camilo Torres Restrepo Is it right for Christians to prioritise one group over another? Yes, it is right No, it is wrong Boff argues that God does not sit back, dispassionate and disengaged with the world, but gets involved, and sides with the poor. The vatican claims that Liberation theology manifests a dangerous preoccupation with the poor and oppressed in Latin America. Although the poor should be helped, prioritising one group is wrong. Gutierrez says that god: "takes sides with the poor and liberates them from slavery and oppression [...] the reciprocal relationship between God and the poor person is the very heart of biblical faith." Jesus' message was for all- we are all to be saved. Emphasising one group is dangerous because it forgets the universal nature of salvation. Poverty has a special status in Christianity- e.g. vows of poverty. It would be easier for a camel to go through an eye of a needle than for a rigch man to enter heaven, etc. John Paul 2 points to the idea that wealth does not shelter us from spiritual poverty. Rich people can be as unhappy as the poor. The kingdom of heaven belongs to the oppressed- notably the poor. "Blessed are you who are poor, for yours is the kingdom of God" (Luke) "but woe to you who are rich, for you have already received your comfort" (also Luke) Jesus does not idealise the poor. His aims for abundance are or everyone. He invites us to share what we have with the poor. The church's concern with liberation theology The church became concerned with liberation theology's use of Marx's theories and cardinal Ratzinger made the Church's disquiet known. Some felt that Marx's theories were the only immediate effective response but this could be dangerous. "The Marxist ideology is wrong. But I have met many Marxists in my life who are good people, so I don't feel offended." - Pope Francis Critics Kloppenburg (always a critic) He has concerns. Here they are: Liberation theology emphasis practical opposition to oppression above the message of the gospels. Therefore the spiritual messages in Christianity are sidelined to focus on political action. It emphasises structural sin over personal sin. Jesus, however, reached into people's personal lives and spoke the the individual of coming back to God through forgiveness It places too much emphasis on people delivering liberation and salvation- ultimately the kingdom of God is brought by God's intervention and salvation is a gift from God Richard McBrien It could be argued that liberation theology is so concerned about action that it has not paid sufficient attention to christian theology. In starting from action it cannot determine which actions might be right or wrong. It also defines oppression in economic terms, ignoring other kinds of oppression- e.g. sexism and racism. Proponents for starving people, liberation from personal sin isn't the most important There isn't change happening for the people in our world who live in poverty- something must be done even if we agree that salvation and liberation is first about inner spiritual change, is there still not a point in which something must be done? Should Christianity engage with secularist atheist ideologies? Yes No Christianity has always adapted to new insights and borrowing from Marxism will not corrupt the religion. Both theories have different approaches: Christianity is spiritual, Marxism is economic For example, scientific advancement has led to the reconsideration of the story of genesis. Marxism explains how workers can liberate themselves by developing a socialist society It has also led us to reconsider the healing stories in the new testament Christianity puts forward the idea of a world created by a loving God. Humans turn away from God and God's response is to seek people to bring back to him by sending his son. God can be encountered in all things- including human thought: making "christian Marxism" possible If Christianity were to adopt elements of Marxism (which isn't in biblical cannon)- it would abandon the christian worldview But even if Marxism and Christianity can be compatible, perhaps we should not adopt it wholescale. Boff thinks that liberation for Christians must draw from the Gospel and Marxism must not be a central principle. He says that Marxism focusses on a socialist system that denies God and individual dignities. "Marx is a useful companion on the way, but there is only one teacher: Jesus Christ." Bonino thinks that the Marxist scheme cannot be taken as a dogma, but rather as a method which has to be applied to our own reality in the terms of our reality Gustavo Gutierrez (VIP) Gutierrez, a Peruvian priest, mentions Marx's theories of alienation and exploitation. Not surprisingly, he warned against adopting all of Marx's teachings. Gutierrez did, however, feel that the people of Latin America had a deep rooted desire to get rid of capitalism. He felt that the Church should stand with political groups on this He felt that it is through 'praxis' that the poor are helped and that true knowledge of God comes through living with and helping the poor Praxis- the process by which a theory/lesson/skill is enacted, applied, realised, and/or put into practice. For Gutierrez, to not get involved is sinful because you are keeping the situation as it is. He feels that the church in Latin America has no choice but to speak out. "Surely the unity of the church cannot tolerate class struggle. Surely the aim is a socialist society: more just and more human." However, theologian Miroslav Volf argued theology and theory has to come first. Summary of my ideas Definitions Separating the definitions of violence into 'physical violence' (hitting someone, etc) and 'political violence' (having health insurance claims denied, refusing to give one's labour (in the form of strikes/refusal based on characteristics) which then leads to others suffering, etc) Marxism's main points of interest are: actions are what matter: changing society must be up to philosophers to not just interpret, but also act on their interpretations. Class as a system is used to oppress the poor on a systemic level The only way to overcome this is through violent revolution Post-revolution, there are directions/methods that he writes of for how the state should be run/exist this society should be atheist Liberation theology this is not one single, organised idea. The particulars tend to change based on philosophers- specifically on: if violence is acceptable when doing this (only Restrepo is a proponent) how far one should go with this (Pope John Paul II at the lower end, Gutierrez at the higher end.) ‘Liberation theology compromises Christian faith by aligning too closely with Marxism’ My main line of argument is that while liberation theology is certainly influenced by, or perhaps kickstarted by Marxism: they are fundamentally different ideologies: not even in the same category of ideology: Marxism is political methodology, meanwhile Liberation theology is an ethical idea. TLDR: it doesn't compromise christian faith because it does not align with Marxism. Themes of my argument Theme Point Violence Physical violence is not condoned by the Bible- and neither is it by the majority of Liberation theologians: because it is not in the Bible. However, political violence is condoned by both. (needs more research) Politics Some argue that the church shouldn't be involved in politics. This is a moronic idea- everything is inherently political. There is no such thing as not being political: even saying that oneself will not be political is political: because it means you will not stand in the way of injustices of others simply because it is convenient for you to ignore it. Also, saying that Jesus/the Bible wasn't political is fucking stupid. Political methodology Liberation theology's major difference with Marxism is that it does not illustrate methods of revolution- it simply points out that injustice is systemic and something must be done about that. It is more pointing out that the church should stand with those who fight against systemic injustice, rather than a methodology for how to overturn a state. Theology Some argue that Christianity should be more focussed on prayer and theology. I don't particularly see where they got this from, because Jesus certainly didn't pray that much; he acted. Whether it was riding into Jerusalem on a donkey, flipping over tables at a bank, supporting the poor and oppressed through his actions. Any prayer he does do is accompanied by action. Why would Christians not act? All of Jesus' teachings are on how to act, not how to pray. Preferential option for the poor Some argue that we should not show specific preference for the rights of the poor; because salvation comes to everyone. This is ignorant of the fact that wealth is used as a tool against the oppressed of all kinds so that they stay oppressed in a systemic manner. Women weren't allowed bank accounts until the 60's, pink tax, racist bias in hiring (meaning that people of colour can't get higher paying jobs), the american government not providing financial aid during the HIV/AIDS pandemic (because it was contracted by mostly homosexuals)- things like this meant to keep oppressed groups oppressed. This is also known as political violence. Systemic sin v individual sin Some argue that Jesus focussed more on individual sin rather than the sins that are systemic: so therefore we should do that too. This ignores the fact that Jesus lived in a time where political theory (such as the one of systemic injustice) was not widespread knowledge- and also in a time where life was incredibly different; 95% of the population were farmers or in some other manual labour; stocks didn't exist; rent didn't exist; globalism didn't exist; people only knew people who lived nearby, etc. Systemic injustice was (while still absolutely a big thing at the time) not as widespread or as inescapable as it is today. To pretend like one shouldn't adapt to the times is moronic. Also; Jesus was intended to become king- which absolutely would not have been dealing with sin on an individual level!

title: Key terms CMP
content:
Term
Definition

Biblical authority
The extent to which the Bible influences human behaviour and morality.

Theonomous ethics
Ethics is determined by God

Sola Scriptura
"by scripture alone" doctrine that holds the Bible as the supreme authority in faith and practice

Covenant
The bible is God's promise and agreement with humans, which requires good behaviour from them.

Hermeneutic circle
Method of interpretation that focusses on a continual, circular pattern of reading and understanding passages in light of the entire Bible

Heternomous ethics
Ethics are governed by several sources; the Bible, human reason, conscience

Papal encylical
Letter issues by the Pope to senior clergy on a significant topic or teaching

Magisterium
Authority of the Pope and bishops as the official and authentic teachings of the church

Natural law
Basic moral principles set by God, discoverable by human nature.

Autonomous ethics
Ethics are self-governing and discovered through human reason alone

Agape
Universal, unconditional, sacrificial love originating from God; often seen as the ideal motivation for mral action

Sacred tradition
Both the scripture and the church are authoritative in communicating revaluation in Christ.

title: Development of Christian thought essay questions
content: DCT questions Augustine and human nature “Both Augustine’s interpretation of the Fall and his doctrine of Original Sin are simply wrong!” Discuss Critically assess the view that if Augustine is right, humans can never be morally good. [40] Augustine’s view of human nature is an optimistic one. Discuss this claim. [40] Is there a distinctive human nature? [40] Death and the afterlife Is it possible to discuss when God’s judgement will take place meaningfully? [40] Could hell be eternal? Discuss. [40] “Heaven is the transformation and perfection of the whole of creation” Discuss [40] Is purgatory a state through which everyone goes? [40] Knowledge of God's existence To what extent can God can be known through reason alone? [40] Faith is sufficient reason for itself. Critically evaluate this claim. [40] To what extent can human beings have natural knowledge of God after the Fall? [40] Is natural knowledge of God the same as revealed knowledge of God? [40] Is it wrong to trust in God, when we have no evidence of His existence? [40] Jesus Jesus was only a teacher of wisdom! Discuss [40] Was Jesus was more than just a political liberator? [40] Was Jesus’ relationship with God truly unique? [40] Did Jesus think he was divine? Discuss. [40] To what extent are Christian ethics distinctive? [40] Are Christian ethics are personal or communal? [40] To what extent is acting with love sufficient to live a good life? [40] Is the Bible is a comprehensive moral guide? [40] Action Critically evaluate the view that Christians should not practise civil disobedience. [40] Is it always possible always to know God’s will? [40] Critically evaluate Dietrich Bonhoeffer’s approach to suffering. [40] To what extent has Bonhoeffer’s theology relevance today? [40] If Christ is the ‘truth’, can there be any other means of salvation? [40] “A good God could not send anybody to hell!” Discuss. Will all good people be saved? Pluralism To what extent does theological pluralism undermine central Christian beliefs? Can a Christian be a theological pluralist? [40] Inter-faith dialogue has not contributed practically towards social cohesion. Evaluate this claim. [40] Should Christians seek to convert people from other faiths? Christians should try to convert atheists. Discuss. [40] To what extent does scriptural reasoning relativise religious beliefs? [40] Gender and Theology The Church cannot change to reflect secular views of gender. Discuss [40] To what extent have secular views of gender equality undermined Christian gender roles? [40] Is motherhood is liberating or restricting? [40] To what extent is the idea of family entirely culturally determined? [40] Gender and society Critically compare Reuther's and Daly’s approaches to sexism and patriarchy within Christianity, as it has developed in the mainstream Churches. [40] Has Christianity a future? [40] Christianity is essentially sexist! [40] If God is male, then man is God! Discuss [40] Can a male saviour save women? [40] Critically assess the view that only women can develop a genuine spirituality. [40] Can God be mother? [40] Secularism Are Christian values just human values? [40] “Christianity is a major cause of personal and social problems!” Discuss this claim. [40] “Secularism presents an opportunity for the Church to develop new doctrines and practices.” Critically evaluate this idea. [40] Should Christianity continue to play a role in public life within the UK? [40] Are British values actually Christian values? Should they be? [40] Liberation Theology "Liberation theology misunderstands the Kingdom of God." Should Christianity engage with atheist ideologies.excalidraw Does Christianity tackle social issues better than Marxism.excalidraw Has christian theology engaged in Marxist theology enough.excalidraw Whether or not it is right for Christians to prioritise one group over another note that the questions of whether Christianity should engage with Marxism, and of whether it has engaged with Marxism enough, function as the same question content wise.

title: Ethics essay questions
content: Normative theories Natural Moral Law whether or not a judgement about something being good, bad, right or wrong can be based on its success or failure in achieving its telos whether or not the universe as a whole is designed with a telos, or human nature Has an orientation towards the good whether or not the doctrine of double effect can be used to justify an action, such as killing someone as an act of self-defence Whether or not natural law provides a helpful method of moral decision-making Situation ethics whether or not situation ethics provides a helpful method of moral decision-making whether or not an ethical judgement about something being good, bad, right or wrong can be based on the extent to which, in any given situation, agape is best served whether Fletcher’s understanding of agape is really religious or whether it means nothing more than wanting the best for the person involved in a given situation whether or not the rejection of absolute rules by situation ethics makes moral decision-making entirely individualistic and subjective Ethical issues Sexual ethics whether or not religious beliefs and practices concerning sex and relationships have a continuing role in the area of sexual ethics whether choices in the area of sexual behaviour should be entirely private and personal, or whether they should be subject to societal norms and legislation whether normative theories are useful in what they might say about sexual ethics Kantian ethics Natural Moral Law Situation ethics Utilitarianism

title: Philosophy of religion
content: Aristotle and Plato Critically compare Plato’s Form of the Good and Aristotle’s Prime Mover. To what extent is Aristotle’s use of the senses to make sense of reality more convincing than Plato’s reliance on reason? Mind, body and soul “There is no evidence for dualism!” Discuss. The word ‘soul’ is best understood as a metaphor. Critically evaluate this claim. Talk about a separate soul rests on a category error! Evaluate this statement. Arguments for the existence of God To what extent are a posteriori arguments are more persuasive than a priori arguments for God? It is more likely that the universe came about by chance than that God designed it. Discuss this statement. To what extent does Aquinas provide sufficient explanation for his conclusion “and this is what everybody calls God”? Discuss with reference to the Third Way. The Cosmological Argument is defeated by the fallacy of composition. Discuss. Critically assess the view that the Ontological Argument is the most persuasive argument for the existence of God. “Existence is not a predicate.” Discuss. To what extent does Anselm’s ontological argument justify people in having Christian faith? The ontological argument fails because it can be reduced to absurdity: it is obvious that perfect islands don’t exist by definition, so God can’t. To what extent is this judgement fair? Religious experience There is no way to establish the validity of religious experiences, so they are not a reliable basis for faith in God. Discuss. Are corporate religious experiences any more reliable or valid than individual experiences? Religious experience is a good pointer towards the existence of God, but it is not a sufficient basis for belief in God in itself. Discuss this statement. The problem of evil To what extent does Augustine’s theodicy succeed in defending God against the charge of allowing evil and the suffering it causes? Why would a perfect God need to put people through a ‘vale of soul-making’? To what extent is the evidential problem of evil a greater challenge to Classical Theism than the logical problem of evil?. Is it possible to successfully defend monotheism in the face of evil? Nature and Attributes of God The Christian concept of God is incoherent! Discuss. Critically evaluate the claim that Richard Swinburne provides the most useful understanding of the relationship between divinity and time. To what extent does Boethius succeed in resolving the problems of divine knowledge, benevolence, justice, eternity and human free will? God can only do what is logically possible. Discuss. Critically analyse God as timeless and eternal (atemporal) Critically analyse God as everlasting (semipiternal) Assess the claim that the universe offers no real evidence for belief in an omnipotent God Discuss critically the view that God limits his own powers for the good of humanity Religious Language Critically compare symbol and analogy as approaches to religious language. The Via Negativa is an unhelpful way of approaching religious language. Discuss. Meaningful theological discussion depends on the Cataphatic approach to language; it is impossible through the Apophatic way. Critically assess this claim. Aquinas’ analogical approaches to religious language are too limiting to support religion. Discuss. A symbolic understanding of religious language renders religious discourse incomprehensible. Critically evaluate this claim. Critically assess the claim that Religious Language is necessarily non-cognitive. To what extent can Scripture mean anything if religious language is understood to be non-cognitive? How far is Aquinas’ analogical view of theological language valuable in the philosophy of religion? #debates

title: Terms dictionary
content:
Ontology-
How one defines things
Epistemology-
the definition of reality or a theory of knowledge
Epiphenomenalism-
Epiphenomenalism is a philosophical theory on the mind–body problem in the philosophy of mind. It holds that subjective mental events are completely dependent for their existence on corresponding physical and biochemical events within the human body, but do not themselves influence physical events.
Eternal is existing outside of time
Everlasting is existing as long as time exists
Theism
refers to the view that there is a God that is omniscient, omnipotent and omnibenevolent, who created the world and who is still actively involved in the world.
Apaphatic- (A.K.A. via negativa)
saying what something is by describing what it is
Cataphatic- (A.K.A. via positiva)
saying what something is by describing what it is not
atemporal- eternal
sempiternal- everlasting
Meaningful

makes philosophical sense

Meaningless

does not make philosophical sense

Providence
God's goodness and continuing activity on behalf of his creation
Causal determinism
Every event can be explained by reference to the causes that brought it about
Middle knowledge
Idea that God knows all the possibilities of what would happen in different scenarios, but not which one will happen
fallacies
Bandwagon fallacy; assuming something is true just because many other people believe it

title: Democracy
content: There are different types of democracy. The general definition is 'ruled by the people'- so not actually very specific. The UK is a constitutional monarchy- as is France and Spain. It is kind of irrelevant, since the king has almost no power. Because democracy can be quite literally almost anything- it is wise to define the terms in your essays. Typically, questions will involve how we can 'better' democracy. This will usually include: increasing participation (therefore increasing legitimacy) (this can include discussion of non-voting participation in Pressure groups, Lobbyists and think tanks) increasing legitimacy of the mandate increasing the size of The Franchise subjective qualities- such as: -> strength of government -> increased protection of rights (which can be incredibly subjective) -> increasing the dignity of politics (i.e. not letting immoral acts go unpunished) Methods of democracy: Direct democracy: the electorate decides on policy without representatives Pluralist democracy: multiple groups, not the people as a whole, can govern, direct and manage society. Representative democracy: citizens vote for representatives to decide policy Liberal democracy- rights and freedoms are officially recognized and protected; excessive political power is limited by the rule of law Proletariat democracy- peasants/ industrial workers are in charge of society

title: Pressure groups, Lobbyists and think tanks
content:
The spec asks us to know:

How different pressure groups exert influence and how their methods and influence vary in contemporary politics.
Case studies of two different pressure groups, highlighting examples of how their methods and influence vary.
Other collective organisations and groups including think tanks, lobbyists and corporations, and their influence on Government and Parliament

A key part of UK democracy is pressure groups. The definition of pressure groups is quite wide- basically any organized group which is not the government working to influence government policy counts- which does lowkey make the opposition political parties count. But don't include that in an essay, it's a bit cheeky.
Types of pressure groups

Promotional
Sectional

Insider
Confederation of British Industry
Trade unions (with Labour)

Outsider
Just Stop Oil, Extinction rebellion
National education Union

Lobbying
Lobbying Act (2014)-

created a register of lobbyists. Anyone who meets the statutory definition of lobbying must sign register and account for their lobbying activities

their definition is "contacting a UK government minister or permanent secretary (or equivalents) on behalf of a third party, in return for payment."
This means that the register is only applicable to individuals or firms lobbying on behalf of a third party- meaning companies with in-house lobbyists (generally the most powerful) are largely unaffected.

an estimated only 4% of lobbyists were actually on the register.

In addition to this, there are rules of what lobbying roles former Ministers and Civil Servants can take. There are time limits in place to prevent Ministers and Senior Civil Servants from becoming lobbyists straight away. This is to try to limit the ‘revolving door’ problem.

Statistics

the annual spend on lobbying in the UK is estimated to be £2 billion
it is estimated that 4,000 people work in the lobbying industry
8/10 are from FTSE 100 companies

David Cameron and the Greensill scandal
Former PM David Cameron- upon leaving the position became a paid advisor to Greensill Capital, a company owned by a guy who had previously been an advisor to him. He received a salary and significant shares in the company.
In 2020, Cameron attempted to persuade government ministers to allow Greensill onto the list of companies getting Government insured loans. He contacted them over 45 times in the span of 3 months.
Cameron did not break the Lobbying Act (that he had introduced) because he did not technically count as a lobbyist because he was employed directly by Greensill.
He also had extraordinary influence as a former PM- and he used it for financial gain.

title: The Franchise
content: Democracy #homepage The franchise is the group of people in any country who are given the right to vote. The franchise has changed greatly over time, and is greatly contested. In 1832, the Great Reform Act was passed.  This extended the franchise to middle-income male voters over the age of 21. Women with property over the age of 30 were given the right to vote in 1918. In 1928, women were given the same voting rights as men (21 and over). In the 1960s, the voting age was lowered to 18 for both men and women. How can we reform the Franchise? There are several options. giving prisoners the right to vote. giving 16 year-olds the right to vote making voting compulsory

content: #lessonmajor Do political parties help or hinder representative democracy? The political Spectrum Left-wing ideas Right-wing ideas A positive view of the state The state should be as small as possible The government should reduce inequality and provide a welfare state Free-market and little government intervention The wealthier should pay higher taxes, and the government should nationalise key industries Low taxation and keeping industries privatised for better competition Close relationships with the trade union movement Limiting the powers of trade unions to ensure smooth operation of the market Embracing multiculturalism, and socially libertarian. Socially conservative and emphasis on the importance of a national identity and tradition. Consensus and adversary politics Consensus politics Adversary politics • Consensus politics means that thereare many philosophical and policysimilarities between the main politicalparties. The opposition may thereforebe able to support some governmentpolicies• In the 1950s the shared commitment ofthe Labour chancellor of the exchequer,Hugh Gaitskell, and the Conservativechancellor of the exchequer, R.A.Butler, to full employment and a mixedeconomy led to the invention of the term‘Butskellism’• Tony Blair embraced traditionallyConservative principles such as the freemarket and low taxation during his timeas Labour leader (1994–2007) • When politics is adversary, this meansthat the main parties are divided byfundamental philosophical and policydifferences• The opposition will routinely opposethe policies of the government sincethey are so ideologically and practicallyopposed to them• The early 1980s provides a goodexample of adversary politics sincethe socialism of Labour leader MichaelFoot (1980–83) was fundamentally atodds with the free-market reforms ofMargaret Thatcher. As Labour leader,Jeremy Corbyn (2015–20) pursuedsocialist policies that placed Labour indirect conflict with the ConservativeParty Functions Selecting candidates Providing ministers/councillors/etc Electing a leader Policy formulation Campaigning Representation mobilising consent for government actions

title: Labour
content: Old Labour The first Labour government The Wilson Ministry The third way History of Labour policy Old Labour Established in 1900 to represent the interests of the working class. Although it's membership has included Marxists, it has never been a Marxist party. Labour has traditionally been a compromise between democratic socialism and social democracy. Democratic Socialists believe that the capitalist state will inevitably be replaced by a socialist state as the working class achieves political power. Social Democrats believe that a more socially just and equal society can be achieved by reforming existing capitalist structures. The core of Labour's socialist ideology is the principle of collectivism, where we achieve more by working together for the common good than by competing for our own interests. Labour have sought to do this by: Nationalization of key industries Redistributive taxation Supporting an extensive welfare state Fostering close links since trade unions- since they both aimed to protect the interests of the working class. The first Labour government The first Labour majority government was run by Clement Atlee from 1945-51. In 1948, they introduced the National Health Service Approximately 20% of the economy was nationalized, including steel, electricity, and coal — as well as the Bank of England. The Wilson Ministry In 1965, the deputy PM announced a National Plan for economic growth that would expand the economy by 25% by 1970 It was a maintenance grant to make it easier for young poor people to attend university The open university was established to further open higher education to those from poorer backgrounds Wilson's governments also committed to the expansion of comprehensive education at the expense of grammar schools. Acts of parliament against discrimination were passed: Race Relations Act 1968, which made discrimination in the workplace illegal Sex Discrimination Act 1975 To pay for a welfare state, taxes on the wealthier increased dramatically. The top rate of taxation was 83% New Labour In the 1979 general election, James Callaghan was defeated by the Conservative Party led by Margaret Thatcher. Following the election of Michael Foot as Labour leader in 1980, the party moved decisively to the left. In the 1983 general election Labour’s manifesto committed the party to further nationalisation, increased taxation of the wealthier in society, withdrawal from the European Economic Community and unilateral nuclear disarmament. One Labour MP, Gerald Kaufman, famously referred to the manifesto as ‘the longest suicide note in history’ and Labour’s share of the vote collapsed from 36.9% in 1979 to 27.6% in the 1983 general election, handing Thatcher a landslide victory. The scale of the 1983 general election defeat shocked Labour into abandoning its most socialist policies and, under the leadership of Neil Kinnock (1983–92) and John Smith (1992–94), Labour moved towards the centre. Then TONY FUCKING BLAIR WAS ELECTED. The third way Blair loved the 'third way' principles developed by Anthony Giddens. According to Giddens, the third way represented a compromise between the extreme socialism and capitalism. It argued that Labour governments should not commit to ideological commitments such as nationalisation, redistributive taxation, class conflict, collectivism and equality. Instead, Labour should focus on the establishment of a 'stakeholder society', based on the principles of inclusion and communitarianism. Essentially, enacting policies that encourage: Wealth creation rather than wealth distribution Loosening ties with trade unions Social justice within a capitalist economy. Blair modified the Labour party constitution in 1995 so that the party abandoned its commitment to nationalisation and accepted the economic benefits of a free-market economy. The left wing of the party fucking hated him. Here's what he did: Kept the top tax rate at 40% as established by Thatcher, because 'the wealthiest in society are wealth creators' (bruh) The state was an enabler, not a provider. State schools were given greater independence and tuition fees were introduced so that students contributed to the cost of higher education Introduced tough laws such as 'anti-social behaviour orders' (ASBOs) to combat crime Constitutional modernisation- Removing most hereditary peers Incorporating the ECHR Establishing the Supreme Court Devolution Introduced a minimum wage, and increased spending on public services. When Blair resigned in 2007, Brown became PM. In response to the 2008 economic crisis, he introduced a 50 pence top rate of taxation on incomes over £150, 000, as well as a bank bailout programme. His successor, Ed Miliband, maintained it's distancing from Blairite policy by committing to the 50 p top rate of taxation, demanding an energy price freeze, and drawing a distinction between 'predatory' finance capitalism and 'producers' in the industry.

title: Party funding
content: How do parties fund election and campaign expenses? 2021-2022 short money allocation Short money 2025/26 Donations to political parties during the 6 weeks of the 2019 general election Conclusion and debate How do parties fund election and campaign expenses? in the UK, parties rely a lot on private funding this is very controversial they do have limited access to public funds to subsidize policy development and parliamentary security policy development grants allocate £2 million to all main parties so that they can employ political advisors. Short money is allocated to opposition parties in the HoC based on the number of seats they have the leader of the opposition is funded ~£800 000 for running for office - Cranborne money subsidises the work of scrutiny carries out by the opposition in the Lords These don’t cover campaign and election expenses. For those, the party relies on member subscriptions and individual donations from benefactors. The conservative party has traditionally received large donations from big businesses that see a tory government as being in their best interests. [!info] In 2019, despite the Brexit Party spending £4,150,000 (13.5% of total spending), it won no seats. The Scottish National Party received £24,929 in donations (0.1% of total spending) and won 48 seats. This suggests that the disproportionate financial influence between political parties has little impact in terms of electoral success. 2021-2022 short money allocation Party Short money Labour £6,602,347 SNP £1,117,489 DUP £195,870 Short money 2025/26 Donations to political parties during the 6 weeks of the 2019 general election Conclusion and debate [!tip] A* tip Whilst Labour were traditionally more reliant on trade unions for donations, more centrist leaders (Starmer and Blair) have sought support from businesses. They tried to assure business leaders that their policies will not harm industry. In the 2024 general election, Labour got donations from hedge fund managers, tech investors, etc. Should the state fund political parties

title: The conservatives
content: History of conservative ideas Traditional conservatism One-nation conservatism The new right Modern Conservative policy The economy (one-nation/Thatcherite) Welfare (one-nation/Thatcherite) Law and order (Thatcherite) Foreign policy (Thatcherite) Kemi Badenoch History of conservative ideas Traditional conservatism this emerged in the 1600's. It's based around the idea of wanting stability above all else. This means no violence, stable economy, and avoiding a revolution by appeasing the peasants (lol)- A.K.A keep things the same at all times. One-nation conservatism Founded by Benjamin Disraeli. He thought that conservatism must unite the nation in reverence for traditions and institutions that made Britain great. He saw society as an organic body in which stability and prosperity could be achieved through everyone appreciating their debt to each other, and not putting their selfish interests above the wellbeing of the community. He warned against Britain becoming two nations- a nation of the rich and a nation of the poor. This led to conservatives supporting extensive social reforms (such as the welfare state.) They became the most successful modern vote-winning political party and the main governing party most of the 20th century. PMs include Stanley Baldwin, Harold Macmillan, and Edward Heath (1970-74) The new right by the 1970s, the effectiveness of one-nation conservatism was undermined by large-scale industrial unrest. Trade unions were increasingly demanding higher wages, challenging the principle that a Conservative government could effectively unite all sections of society. In 1975, Maggie Thatcher defeated Heath for leadership, and established the new right- also known as 'Thatcherite' principles. The new right is a combination of neo-liberalism and neo-conservatism. it was neo-liberal because (unlike it's predecessor) it supported the free market to the extreme. essentially that the job of government was to make conditions as favourable as possible for the successful operation of the free market Adam Smith referred to this as the 'invisible hand of the market It thought that governments should do this by: Keeping taxation to a minimum reducing inflation and interest rates discouraging a 'dependency culture' created by the welfare state 4. limiting the influence of trade unions because they disrupt the smooth operation of the free market it was neo-conservative because it was strongly connected to authoritarianism- and fear of disorder (which disrupts stability) They did this through: 1. discouraging permissive and alternative lifestyles that threatened the nuclear family giving the government extensive power to fight crime and disorder protecting national interest by having a strong defence policy emphasising the nation state as the source of the citizen's security this meant that they were sceptical of the EU. [!info] Liz Truss Truss' policies (specifically, cutting the rate of taxation) were credited to Thatcherite credentials. After all, in Howe's first budget, he drove down the top rate of income tax 83%->60% and the basic rate 33%->30%. However, Thatcher wasn't all tax-cuts; she definitely balanced the budget. A later Howe budget dramatically increased indirect taxes to drive down the deficit- in contrast to Truss' 2022 claim that it was the 'right time' for the government to borrow more. Kwarteng's 'give away budget'- which cut the base rate of income tax, removed the increase in national insurance and froze corporation tax-- had more in common with Heath's budgets than Thatcher's. So although Truss may have come into office laying claim to Thatcher’s legacy, her policies had a distinctly Heath-ite flavour. Rishi Sunak's balancing of the budget was much truer to Thatcher's legacy. Modern Conservative policy The economy (one-nation/Thatcherite) The Tories tend to flip-flop between one-nation and Thatcherite on the economy: even within the same government. - Johnson's government had high public spending to level up society. - Public spending in 2021 was 42% of the economy, on par with the 1970s - (although note that some of this was definitely COVID) - To finance increased spending, Chancellor Sunak significantly increased corporation tax and national insurance - Truss' government was... a fucking mess Sunak's government responded to the recession with higher taxes and dramatic cuts in public spending- a very Thatcherite thing. Welfare (one-nation/Thatcherite) When the minimum wage was introduced by Blair, Tories claimed it was unacceptable. In Cameron's government, Chancellor Osborne introduced a 'living wage' to provide extra support for the least well paid Johnson established a new secretary of state for levelling up, housing and communities. But he also measurably privatised the NHS Cameron, Truss, and Sunak all said that they were committed to supporting the NHS. However, the Universal Credit system, which is based on more you earn= less you get in benefits suggests Thatcherism. Law and order (Thatcherite) May passed the 'Investigatory Powers Act' (2016) giving the government enhanced powers of surveillance. Johnson passed the 'Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Act' which increased police powers over public protests. The home secretaries- Priti Patel and Suella Braverman, were both critics of liberalism.. Foreign policy (Thatcherite) Johnson negotiated Brexit. he also announced a £16.5 billion increase to defence spending, the biggest boost since the end of the Cold war in 2021, the UK joined (AUSUK), a defence alliance to counter China. Truss and Sunak were similarly hawkish- providing strong opposition to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and criticising China for it's human rights record Kemi Badenoch In the 2024 election manifesto: halve migration by implementing a cap continuing the Rwanda policy national service program for 18-year-olds Afterwards: repealing the Human Rights Act withdrawing from the ECHR repealing the climate change act reversing tax changes introduced by Starmer
