title: Non-social factors
content: Campaigning Rational choice model Valance Issues Salient issues Track record Leader and party image Manifesto Voting Context model Tactical voting Protest voting By-elections Opinion polls Bandwagon effect Boomerang effect Opinion Polls Why are Opinion polls conducted? Types of opinion polls Do opinion polls affect voting behaviour? Polling data from 2017-2025 The media and voting behaviour Other non-social factors Campaigning A strong campaign can be important to mobilise voters. In the 2019 election, the Tory 'get Brexit done' message was very popular with voters. However, the existence of safe seats, state of the economy, or long-term voter trends are often more important than a campaign. Labour's sweep in 2024 was largely due to public dissatisfaction with the Conservative government, not due to their campaign. Rational choice model The rational choice model posits that voters vote based on their self-interests and policies advocated by political parties. Valance Issues Issues where there is a broad consensus among voters what is good — such as a strong economy, the NHS, or national security. The election then becomes about which party can deliver better outcomes. Salient issues Issues that are important to voters at the time, which tend to change election on election. For example — Brexit in 2019, or now immigration. Track record Track record in government or actions of a candidate. This is more of a concern for the incumbent candidate. We can see this in how the Conservatives lost horribly in the 2024 election. Leader and party image A charming leader is more appealing. Take Blair and Johnson. Or nowadays, Reform is entirely coasting by on the popularity of Farage. Manifesto The media only covers the main points or the controversial policies. Most of the time they don't matter, but take Theresa May's 'dementia tax.' Voting Context model The voting context model is similar to the rational choice model, but is more to do with the external factors of a particular election than individual's choices. Tactical voting Individuals strategically vote for a candidate or party to prevent the election of a less preferred candidate/party. Protest voting Individuals that cast their vote as a form of protest or to express dissatisfaction with the political system or other things. By-elections Elections held to fill a vacant seat in a legislative body, occurring between general elections. Almost entirely used to show dissatisfaction with the current government. (Take reform's fucking sweep in council elections.) Opinion polls Refer below. Bandwagon effect Phenomenon where the popularity of a candidate convinces others to vote for them — often based off of opinion polls. Boomerang effect Phenomenon where negative attacks on a candidate result in increased support for them. (Trump.) Opinion Polls Why are Opinion polls conducted? Understanding public opinion Shaping political campaigns Informing media coverage Supporting academic research Engaging the electorate Types of opinion polls Voting intention Leadership approval Exit polls Tracking polls (a. k. a. issue/opinion) MRP (multilevel regression and post-stratification) (predicts how a constituency votes.) MRPs predicted Johnson breaking through the Red Wall. Do opinion polls affect voting behaviour? Do opinion polls affect voting behaviour Yes No Polls can create a bandwagon effect. For instance, in the 2019 GE, polls predicting a significant Tory lead may have convinced undecided voters to back them, or convinced opposed voters to not vote, convinced a Tory victory was inevitable. Many voters make decisions based on things other than polls. The 'Red Wall' shift in 2019 was caused by long-term dissatisfaction with Labour's stance on Brexit and economic policies. Media coverage amplifies poll's importance — take Reform's current showing in the polls and showing in Media. Polls are only paid attention to by those who follow politics and elections closely. For instance, polls in 2024 showing shifts in younger voter turnout became focal on social media — and young voter turnout dropped from ~47%->~37%. Polls can mobilise voters who fear that their preferred party is trailing. For example, in the 2019 GE, polling data suggested a possible hung parliament, potentially motivating Tory voters to turn out. The majority of voters have a preference before campaigns begin, so polls have little impact. In 2019, Scotland continued to back the SNP despite polling trends. Strategic voting can be influenced by polls, especially in marginal constituencies. For example, in the 2024 GE, polling data highlighted tight races in the South East, leading calls for Lib-Dem voters to vote for Labour in key constituencies to unseat Tory MPs. Inaccurate or poorly conducted polls can be misleading. In 2024, a widely shared (but flawed) poll underestimated Labour's performance in the Midlands, creating false expectations of a conservative hold in marginal seats. Polling data from 2017-2025

title: Social factors
content:
Class
Socio-economic class
This refers to the categorisation of people based on income, occupation, and social status. Traditionally, these have been working, middle, and upper class. However, nowadays it is much more complicated.
In the UK, classes are now grouped as:

AB: Higher managerial/professional roles
C1: lower managerial/professional roles
C2: skilled manual workers
DE: semi-skilled and unskilled workers, unemployed, or retired
Obviously, the job descriptions for all of these can be very inaccurate when determining class. It's a generalist approach, not a 100% correct one.

Socio-economic class historically played a large role in voting behaviour. The commonly held views on how class affects voting behaviour are as follows:

Labour appeals to C2DE voters because it appeals to the working class by funding a welfare state and supporting worker's rights
Conservatives appeal to ABC1 voters because their policies favour low taxes and businesses
Nowadays, these assumptions aren't really correct for multiple reasons.

Factors associated with class alignment of voters

Factor
Explanation
Examples
Why it can not have an impact

Class identification
a.k.a class conciousness — how one's sense of belonging to a class can influence voting behaviour.
In 2019, some working-class Leave/Labour voters felt neglected by Labour, contributing to Tory gain.
Class identification has weakened due to broader societal changes, including globalisation (hard to think you're doing crap when you see mass genocide/starvation.)

Class dealignment
refers to weakening of traditional associations between class and party — leading to greater electoral volatility.
In 2019, Tories attracted C2 voters by focusing on Brexit. In 2024, Labour attracted Tory-leaning middle-class voters because of economic dissatisfaction transcending class identity.
While it provides opportunity for change, parties still rely on traditional bases. Although class dealignment was prominent in 2019 for Labour, they won them back in 2024, demonstrating that this is volatile.

Partisan dealignment
refers to weakening of voter loyalty to specific parties — leading to an increase in floating voters.
Tories winning in 'Red Wall' constituencies in 2019, rise in Issue-Based voting (Labour on cost of living in 2024), rise in smaller parties, more tactical voting in marginal constituencies.
it seems like this has an incredible impact. Lower party membership across the board, broad dissatisfaction with Labour and the Conservatives... yeah. Although, with membership of the Greens soaring, who knows?

Class polarisation

Working-class conservatism

Embourgeoisement

title: The media and voting behaviour
content: Introduction Dominant Ideology Theory Political leaning of mainstream newspapers The decline of print media Online presence of newspapers Assessment of the impact of print media Broadcast TV The rise of 24-hour news channels Who watches TV? The rise of opinion news Changing preferences Misinformation Statistics The media Introduction Dominant Ideology Theory DIT suggests that ideas and beliefs within a society are shaped and maintained by those in power, often to uphold existing social structures and inequalities. Newspapers They're no longer relevant and nobody cares about them. Newspapers in the UK can be broadly separated into two categories: tabloids and broadsheets. Tabloids are known for sensationalist headlines, gossip, and populism. Examples include The Sun, The Daily Mirror, and The Daily Starr. In 2019, The Sun ran eye-catching headlines attacking Corbyn's leadership and Brexit stance Broadsheets are known for longer articles, in-depth analysis, and political coverage. Examples include The Guardian, The Times, and The Telegraph. During the 2024 general election, The Times analysed Labour's economic policy in great detail. Many papers have an online presence. Political leaning of mainstream newspapers Left leaning Right leaning Broadsheet Private Eye, Guardian The Telegraph Tabloid Daily Mirror The sun The decline of print media Print media's influence has declined due to the rise of digital platforms. The Sun's circulation fell from 3 million in 2010 to less than 1 million in 2024 Younger voters use social media much more. Online presence of newspapers Most papers now have websites where they publish most of their stuff. Many focus almost entirely on digital news, now. Assessment of the impact of print media 2019 election — despite the decline, print media reinforced political divisions. The Sun's anti-Corbyn campaign solidified tory support. 2024: not much impact on younger voters. However, the Daily Mail's endorsement of Tories may have swayed older voters. Television [!info] Statistics on TV 79% of the adult population use television as their main source for accessing the news. 93% of adults aged 65+ use television to access the news. 89% of 16–24-year-olds report that their main source of news is the internet. 85% of minority ethnic people access news from the internet rather than television. Broadcast TV TV is subject to strict regulations to ensure impartiality, enforced by Ofcom. Broadcasters must provide balanced coverage of political parties Political advertising on TV and radio is prohibited. Instead, parties receive free airtime for Political Party Broadcasts (PPBs) which must also meet impartiality requirements. Print media faces no such obligations. The Sun could openly support the Conservatives in the last two elections, but the BBC and ITV are required to present balanced debates and coverage of all major parties. The rise of 24-hour news channels These channels provide continuous coverage of breaking news, political events, debates, and election results During the 2019 GE, Sky ran extended analyses on Brexit's implications By 2024, 24-hour news channels face increased competition from online platforms, but they remain key for real-time election updates. In more recent years, TV debates and interviews have become more important. See Clegg's performance in a debate before the 2010 election, possibly leading to the coalition. Who watches TV? Older demographics (50+) are the primary consumers of live broadcast news Younger demographics favour clips of broadcast shared on social media. (Something something the fact that clips will be designed to get a reaction on social media means that only the most controversial clips will go viral.) (also it's just going to go into your echo chamber.) The rise of opinion news Yeah it's GB news. They do a LOT of social media work. Also, it isn't impartial in the slightest. Changing preferences According to Ofcom, more adults are getting their news online (71%) rather than from TV (70%). Among The Kids, its even more pronounced — 88% of 16-24 use online sources, with only 49% using TV. Although the BBC still reaches 68% of adults in the UK. Assessment of importance of traditional media Broadcast continues to play a large role in shaping voting behaviour and public opinion. Agenda setting: TV frames key election issues. In 2019, the BBC and Sky prioritized Brexit coverage. Trust: despite criticism, the BBC is still regarded as more trustworthy than social media or print outlets Polarisation: the rise of opinion news may have contributed to increased polarisation, although their viewership remains small in comparison to major broadcasters. Yes, it has declined No, it hasn't Younger voters increasingly gain political information from social media. In 2024, platforms like TikTok reached a third of young Britons. During the 2019 UK general election, social media algorithms often promoted content that reinforced users’ existing beliefs, limiting exposure to diverse perspectives. Newspapers have dramatically declined in circulation in recent years. Between 2010 and 2019, major UK newspapers experienced significant drops in print circulation, prompting many to invest heavily in their online presence to retain readership. Despite the rise of social media, traditional media remains a primary news source for many voters, especially older demographics who have higher voter turnout rates. In the 2019 UK general election, traditional outlets online were the most popular for general election news, indicating that traditional media still played a significant role in informing voters. On-demand services and content apps like Netflix mean live viewing of TV (24-hour news or scheduled news programming) has decreased, leading people to not tune into TV news. By 2024, more British people got their news from the internet (71%) than from television (70%), marking a significant shift in news consumption habits. Many newspapers have successfully transitioned to digital formats, maintaining or even expanding their readership through online platforms. By 2024, newspapers like The Guardian and The Times had substantial digital subscriber bases, allowing them to continue shaping political narratives and influencing voter opinions. Citizen journalism and the curation of news content mean people are pushed the news they want and agree with and won’t search it out from established sources such as the press and broadcast TV. Traditional media outlets provide editorial standards and fact-checking that help ensure the accuracy and reliability of information, which can counterbalance the echo chamber effect of personalised news feeds. In the 2024 UK general election, traditional media continued to serve as a counterbalance to the echo chambers of social media, offering fact-checked and comprehensive coverage that reached a broad audience. New media — social media and online sources The shift from print to digital media has sped up news delivery, creating a 24/7 news cycle that’s constantly updated online. Nowadays, people mainly get their news from websites and social media platforms like Twitter. This allows them to choose their own sources of information, which can reinforce their personal biases. Social media lets politicians communicate directly with the public, bypassing traditional media channels. This has changed the way political communication works. “Filter bubbles” on social media encourage users to engage with like-minded opinions and demonise opposing ones, reinforcing partisan views. A small, vocal minority on social media can significantly influence public discourse and mainstream media agendas, contributing to societal polarisation. While social media provides instant access to information, it also fosters division and hostility, affecting how people perceive each other and political figures. Misinformation A report by the University of Oxford highlighted that organised social media manipulation campaigns were identified in 81 countries, including the UK. This was a 15% increase from the previous year. During the 2019 GE, the Tory press office rebranded it's twitter account as 'factcheckUK' during a leader's debate. Additionally analysis revealed that 88% of the Conservative Party's Facebook advertisements during a specific period contained misleading information, compared to 0% of the Labour party. Also, deepfakes. Statistics 1 in 4 say they get most of their news on political matters on social media. Social media is the primary political news source for 58% of those aged under 35, compared with 8% of those aged 55+ Echo chambers 43% of those who get their political news from social media say they often come across views online with which they disagree 16% say that they 'rarely' or never do so. 35% of those who get their news from traditional media say they often encounter views online with which they disagree 54% of social media users say they often consult a second source when looking for news, while 36% say they often do so by checking a source that they do not often use Only 53% of social media news receivers think that it is a reliable source. 44% feel that it is unreliable. Polarisation 32% of social media users have a low level of trust in the courts, compared with 26% of those who primarily obtain their political news from other sources 54% of social media users have a low level of trust in Parliament, compared with 49% of those who get most of their news from other sources Nearly one in three social media users (32%) are either very libertarian or very authoritarian in outlook, compared with just over one in four (27%) of other users 32% of social media users voted in the 2024 election for either Reform (20%) or the Greens (12%), eleven points above the figure for other users 25% of social media users hold very ‘left-wing’ views compared with only 14% of other users. But only 8% have a very ‘right-wing’ outlook, compared with 13% of other users 30% of social media users are either very sympathetic or very unsympathetic towards welfare, the same proportion as among other users Is social media's influence overstated? Yes, it is overstated No, it is understated Social media reinforces political beliefs by pushing content voters already agree with, so doesn’t change minds, justifies existing positions. During the 2019 UK general election, social media algorithms often promoted content that reinforced users’ existing beliefs on issues like Brexit, limiting exposure to diverse perspectives. Social media platforms have the potential to expose users to a wider range of viewpoints, which can influence and change voting behaviour. In the 2024 UK general election, political parties utilised social media to reach undecided voters, employing targeted advertising to present policy positions to those not firmly aligned with a particular party. Despite the rise of online news consumption, traditional media outlets remain influential, especially among demographics with higher voter turnout. In the 2019 UK general election, traditional media outlets continued to play a significant role in informing voters, particularly older demographics who are more likely to vote. Social media has become the number one source for news; 71% of all voters get their information from online sources. By 2024, more British people got their news from the internet (71%) than from television (70%), marking a significant shift in news consumption habits. This influence declines the higher up the age brackets you go, with older voters preferring broadcast media. Older voters have shown a preference for traditional broadcast media, relying on television and radio for their news consumption. The gap is narrowing as older demographics increasingly adopt online platforms for news consumption. By 2024, there was a noticeable increase in older voters engaging with news content online, indicating a shift in media consumption habits across age groups. A lot of evidence suggests that trusted and well-sourced news is important to voters, and traditional media like the press are still able to set the agenda due to targeting age groups that have higher levels of turnout. Information and news have been democratised on social media, allowing free access rather than requiring the purchase of a newspaper or subscription. Social media platforms provide users with free access to a vast array of news sources, reducing barriers to information. Traditional media outlets have maintained their agenda-setting power, particularly among demographics with higher voter turnout. Social media platforms are increasingly influential in setting the news agenda, especially among younger voters who are more active online. In the 2024 UK general election, social media trends and discussions played a significant role in shaping political discourse, particularly among younger demographics. Social media has a symbiotic relationship with traditional media, with posts and content shared on platforms like TikTok and X coming from content newspapers and broadcast media created. Content from traditional media outlets is frequently shared and discussed on social media platforms, indicating a symbiotic relationship between the two. Social media platforms also generate original content that influences traditional media coverage, highlighting a bidirectional relationship. During the 2024 UK general election, viral content originating on social media platforms often prompted coverage and discussion in traditional media outlets.

title: Constitution and federalism
content: Please note that many of these notes were transferred directly from my messy notes and I haven't taken much care to clean them up. Major notes The constitution Federalism Major questions **How democratic is the Constitution today? Is the USA still federal? how effective is the constitution today? how similar is it to the founding father's intentions? how robust is it against challenges? Misc Was the constitution every meant to be democratic? Short answer? No, probably not. the founding fathers did not like democracy, it was not their end goal. the goal was limited government/preventing a tyrannical one. Democracy, then, was their method of achieving this although they were aware of democracy's problems, so looked for a balance i.e. no tyrannical government but also stopping a populist moron being elected by a moronic population. How did they do this? the electoral college — which means electors can override a decision. This doesn't happen much nowadays; there are actual laws against being an unfaithful delegate in many states (California, for example). It does, however, result in a 'wrong-way-around' vote. such as in: 2000 2016 2 other irrelevant times An appointed senate. Senators were originally appointed by state governors: not directly elected. This was for the purposes of: continuing to reduce the impact of the uneducated allowing the more powerful house to not be impacted by the uneducated Equal representation of states in the senate (2 each) supermajorities the supreme court Also note that many groups lacked equal rights, AND that the federal constitution allows for undemocratic things to occur at a state level (gerrymandering, much, California?)

title: Federalism
content: Table of contents Why is america federal? How has federalism changed over time? 2000s federalism onwards Is the USA federal today? Each state gives the exact same powers to the central government. The way that this is different to English devolution is that for England, power is given out from in — whereas in the USA it goes in from out. In the UK, power given out is uneven. Why is america federal? Historically 13 colonies- it was easy to carry on like that The USA is very diverse in population, culture, and climate It was seen as a good way of spreading power and minimising the chance of tyranny. If there is any questions on whether something is a federal thing or a state thing- it is assumed to be a state power. The idea that power resides with the states is codified by the tenth amendment. This has resulted in the US developing a strong culture of localism and regionalism- which is common in the UK devolved bodies but less so in England. How has federalism changed over time? 1.      Dual federalism- 1790s--1930s The federal and state governments were very separate. The federal government is seen as intrusive. Tension over states rights led to the civil war over slavery. After the civil war, there is a period of reconstruction but there is still a shit ton of racist laws in the south. 2.      Co-operative federalism- 1930s-1960s In ’29, the wall street crash causes the great depression. The US economy shrunk a shit ton. Then Roosevelt took control of large parts of the economy- i.e. publicization. So he does the New Deal using the commerce clause- he is pushing it. The supreme court is anti-New Deal- but in 1937 he threatens to increase the number of court justices and flood the court with democrats. 3.      New federalism- 1960s- 2000s The federal government was being seen as inefficient- conservativism is on the rise- many white southerners and deeply unhappy about policies that aren’t racist. Then Nixon offers block grants to states to solve problems- but they don’t have to reach a goal or something. so they are given more autonomy. 4.      Who the fuck knows- 2000s-now Everyone -starting with Bush- has changed it the fuck around. 2000s federalism onwards president Development of state power Development of federal power George Bush >Gonzales v Oregon (2006)- effectively allowed state-sponsored euthanasia>Medicaid waiver given to Massachusetts to allow Governor Romney to introduce a new universal health programme. >USA PATRIOT act 2001- allowed federal government to detail people and collect information about them>homeland security- whole new cabinet department>No child left behind act 2002- allowed for uniform school testing Barack Obama >PPACA- known as Obamacare (2010)- at the state’s urging, Obamacare including power over the provision of medical insurance run by the states themselves>Texas v United States (2016) the supreme court struck DAPA (deferred action for parents of Americans) due to cost to states.>The Cole memo- the justice department said it wouldn’t enforce federal restrictions on marijuana when states had legalised it. >Obamacare>Arizona v United States- overturned a law in Arizona that increased state law enforcement power to enforce immigration laws>Obergefell v Hodges (2015)- the supreme court effectively legalised same sex marriage nationally Donald Trump >Carpenter v United States (2018)- the supreme court found that the federal government must obtain a warrant for a citizen’s cell phone location records>Executive order minimizing the economic burden of PPACA- aimed at reversing Obamacare and giving states more control >The Cole memo was rescinded>executive order stripping federal grants from ‘sanctuary cities’ (later found to be unconstitutional Joe Biden >abortion and heartbeat bills- up to the states>Covid-19 rules >Build Back Better plan- a three part plan which had big spending on Covid-19 recovery Donald Trump Idk voting 'rights'?> OMG his trying to rescind SNAP payments! >the executive order on tariffs and birthright citizenship Is the USA federal today? Yes No The supreme court seems very willing to return important decisions (like abortion) to the states. States have control over driving age, euthanasia, gun control, and marijuana. The supreme court is growing in power, meaning the federal government has more influence Election regulations remain with states There have been notable landmark legislation from the federal government that has impacted states and been upheld numerous times by the supreme court (affordable care act) Increasing hyper partisanship in federal government has resulted in gridlock- meaning states have to do more Rights are uniformly protected at federal level- such as respect for marriage act 2022. This level of protection supersedes any state-level law. While federal law supersedes state law, in instances like the legalisation of marijuana- state law has gone above federal and gone unchallenged Certain national issues demand national response- like Covid-19, the Russia-Ukraine war, or inflation.

title: The constitution
content: Table of contents What is the context of the US constitution? Vague history Messy notes Amendments How is the constitution amended? Pros and cons of this system Checks and balances Examples of checks and balances being used What is the context of the US constitution? Americans see themselves as a rebellious people- this leads to an authoritarian approach to policing- whereas the police in the UK are taught to deescalate first. People generally don’t get killed during riots in the UK. and different conceptions of justice. In the UK, murder would get life and serve 15 years. You only serve the time of your longest sentence. In the US, sentences add up. Americans care deeply about liberty. You see this in the UK with people like Jeremy Clarkson and rural farmers. In the UK, the government is paternalistic, in America it’s fuckin annoying. Justice- high expectations of what the world is like. Expectations of ‘freedom’ depends on left and right- and they are very angry about it. Americans tend to lack cynicism in comparison to brits. US kids are brought up with the American dream. You can be president! You can be anything! Yippee! (That does not fuckin happen in UK.) Vague history Pre-1500s- populated by native American tribes. They didn’t have gunpowder or smelted metal. This makes them vulnerable to European travellers. 1500-1700- many Europeans travel to the new world. The Spanish in particular plundered tribes for gold in the south. In north America the tribes are less wealthy. Settling down was more common. Virginia is the first colony established Settlers were often religious outcasts and extremists fleeing religious wars in Europe. Many were protestant 1700-56- Spain, France and Britain speedrun colonising. European settlers move in after and while subjugating the native Americans In areas with few settlers, treaties were drawn up between the natives and the settlers, but they were largely unfair 56-63- 7 years’ war. Huge global war. Britain won and became the dominant power in north America. However, it has been won by borrowing massive sums of money. The brits decide to tax the Americas because the colonies benefited the most from those debts. 63-75- 13 colonies that run down the east coast. They are individual, not a single country. They are governed partly by Westminster and most of the inhabitants would have considered themselves British 1600s- the reformation and the renaissance lead to the enlightenment. John Locke- classical liberal, protestant. He says we have three rights. It is gods will that everybody is alive. If you murder someone, it goes against god’s will. God created humans to be free. Anything that controls you (unfairly, unreasonably or unmorally) is going against gods will. Everyone has a right to property. Something in the natural world+ your labour= your property So, then the Americans are getting taxed out of their asshole. They think its shit because they can’t vote for it. A group of people dressed up as native Americans storm the Boston harbour. They kick tea into the harbour. It’s called the Boston tea party. Parliament gets mad and strips Massachusetts of its rights. A small number gather and proclaim their independence from the British empire. its not that many people. They sign a document in 1776 called the declaration of independence. Britain invades and seizes the coasts. The rebels are forced inland. They rebels are ground down and immortalised. At some point, Britain get bored and stops funding the army- who are eventually defeated. The rebels establish ‘these united states of America’ This country now needs federalism because they don’t have a national identity. What are the nature and principles of the constitution? 1. Codified constitution- constitution that is written into law 2. Judiciable constitution- can be enforced by the judiciary 3. Entrenched constitution- a provision that makes certain amendments either more difficult or impossible to pass 4. Implied powers- powers a body has that wasn’t explicitly given to them 5. Supermajority-a majority by greater than one half 6. Enumerated powers- powers specifically given by the constitution 4. A ‘necessary and proper clause’- authorizes congress to employ any means that are appropriate and plainly adapted to the permitted end (the permitted end being within the scope of federal power under the constitution) Limited government, separation of powers, checks and balances, federalism. The US constitution comes into effect in 1789. It has seven articles, about 4,500 words, with an additional 3,000 Article 1- deals with congress. Shows they intended congress to be more important than the presidency Article 2- presidency (presidency, not president Article 3- federal courts Article 4- Federalism Amendments Messy notes The US Constitution is codified - this means that it is judiciable. Only federal courts can rule on this. - So, there is two layers of the law- normal and constitutional It is designed to be hard to change - This is done by requiring supermajorities (66%) to change things. This was done in order to prevent tyranny of the majority - Some observers have suggested that this has created a ‘tyranny of the minority’ situation- where well-organised and well-motivated minority groups can undermine democracy. (this is typical of guns- about 2/3s want stricter gun control but this will never fucking happen) Look up public choice theory a lot of the Constitution is very fucking vague because the founding fathers acknowledged that America is very big, diverse, and will outlive them - Enumerated powers- powers with a number- a specific and explicit power given to an institution by the constitution - Implied powers- powers that are not explicit, but flow logically (constitution says that the president has power over the army and navy- but it doesn’t mention the air force, because it didn’t exist at the time) - There is also the necessary and proper clause- gives congress to do anything it wants to- within reason (they gave money to the unemployed through the CARES act during COVID 19) - the constitution predates political parties, but barely. So, everyone was an independent - these independents would form factions when a major issue faces the country. (like pro-war and anti-war). Once the issue was resolved, the faction would disband - worried that a 51% faction forcing itself upon the 49% faction (supermajorities were introduced for this.) - this whole situation is referred to a ‘bipartisanship’. However, this phrase has two meanings: a situation where two political parties exist a situation where two political parties must work together Amendments First amendment- freedom of speech, action and press and religion 1st — Freedom of speech, action, press and religion 2nd – keep and bear arms 3rd no soldiers in homes in peacetime (because food payments) 4th no unreasonable searches by police- police must have reasonable suspicion 5th protection and legal process, due process, compensation for property 6th fair and speedy trial, legal representation, and no hidden shit 7th jury trial in civil cases against govt action 8th no cruel and unusual punishment 9th protects unenumerated rights 10th powers not in the constitution go to the states 11th cant sue states in federal court 12th president and vice elected separately 13th abolishes slavery (terms and conditions may apply) 14th citizenship to all persons born in the USA (being a citizen means rights) 15th everyone can vote (men of colour edition) 16th govt can get taxes and not give em proportionally 17th senators are elected 18th prohibition 19th everyone can vote (women edition) 20th different term lengths and smoother transition of power 21st ending prohibition 22nd limits the presidency to 2 terms 23rd residents of Washington DC residents voting 24th no poll taxes in elections 25th presidential procedures (JFK rules) 26th voting at 18 years old 27th senator pay How is the constitution amended? Two-thirds (a supermajority) of both houses of Congress have to vote to introduce an amendment, or two-thirds of states can call a constitutional convention to propose amendments. Amendments require the formal support (ratification) of ¾ of states Proposed by a 2/3 vote in congress, ratified by ¾ of the state legislatures Proposed by a 2/3 vote in congress, ratified by conventions held in ¾ of the states Proposed at a national convention called by congress when requested by 2/3 of the states, ratified by ¾ of the state legislatures Proposed by national convention, ratified by conventions. Pros and cons of this system Pros Cons Protects smaller states from tyranny of the majority can make for tyranny of the minority hard to change — so a government can't just take away certain rights hard to change when something is outdated ensures fair checks and balances and state's rights can make a weak government (?) Checks and balances When the constitution was being drafted, three of the founding fathers wrote short newspaper articles (the federalist papers) The goal was to convince votes what the constitution should look like, particularly around controversial issues They are useful for understanding how the founding fathers intended the constitution to be used (we don’t actually know who wrote which) In paper 51, we think Madison/Hamilton is arguing for checks and balances This is because each branch of government could have it’s own selfish motivations, which could be shit for the country So the other two branches have the power to stop this So the phrase ‘checks and balances’ describes how each branch can limit and be limited in their powers This only works when there is a separation of branches Examples of checks and balances being used Check Information Judicial review In 2020, the Supreme Court ruled against the Trump administration's attempt to end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program Judicial review In 2020, in the case Bostock v Clayton County, the Supreme Court ruled that discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity is unconstitutional under the Civil Rights Act 1964. Veto power Biden vetoed a bill regarding an attempt to row back on the Buy American waiver he introduced for US government-backed charging stations Calling special sessions In 2021, Biden considered calling a special session of congress to address the looming debt ceiling crisis. Lobbying and negotation Trump lobbied for and signed the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (2017) Legislative recommendations The OMB proposes a budget to congress every year. Nominations of justices Trump nominated Neil Gorsuch, Brett Kavanaugh and Amy Coney Barret Enforcement of court decisions Trump's administration enforced the Trump v Hawaii decision (travel ban). Also, ignoring the thing to not deploy troops into chicago Legislative blockage Trump's efforts to repeal the ACA in 2017 were blocked, despite republican control in both houses Budget approval in 2021, Congress passed the American Rescue Plan, $1.9 trillion COVID relief package, following extensive modification of Biden's initial proposal Treaty ratification in 2012, the Senate failed to ratify the UN convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Confirmation of appointments Neera Tanden withdrew her nomination for director of OMB in 2021 after facing opposition Impeachment Trump was last impeached (and acquitted) in 2021 Confirmation of justices The Senate confirmed Amy Coney Barret days before the 2020 presidential election Impeachment of justices there has been 1 unsuccessful attempt to impeach a justice in the 1800s structural changes none have been recently enacted

title: Does campaign financing require reform
content:
#lessonminor
Exercise
PrimeChoice Packers LLC
They don't want Deborah to go full on with 'better treatment for farm animals' because it would cost them a lot more if Nowhere, Ohio had California-style animal rights laws.
If she takes money from them, she doesn't have to be publicly pro-industry, but she can't make any changes to the status quo.
Terms
527 s- Tax-exempt organisations created to influence electoral outcomes but that cannot call for the election or defeat of a specific candidate. They can raise unlimited amounts.

But also, they still do political things, but more subtly.

Political Action Committees (PACS) — Political organizations that can donate directly to a candidate's campaign up to $5, 000 per campaign.
Super PACS — PACs that can raise an unlimited amount and they can call for the election or defeat of a candidate. They are not, however, allowed to directly co-coordinate with candidate's campaigns.
Elon Musk founded one to support Trump. Remember when he was lottery-ing $1 million for anyone who could prove they voted Trump
Soft Money — Money donated to a political party, rather than a specific candidate, and used for 'party-building activities' rather than the direct endorsement of a candidate. It is subject to a few limits.
Hard Money — donations specifically towards a specific political candidate's campaign. This is subject to strict limits. But also you could just donate soft money closer to the election to make sure it gets spent on the candidate without going through the limits.
Cases on party funding

Case

Federal Elections Campaign Act (FECA) passed

1974
FECA reformed after watergate

1976
Buckley v Valeo

1979
Congress amends the FECA

2002
Bipartisan Campaign Finance Reform Act (McCain-Feingold)

2010
Citizens United v. FEC

2014
McCutcheon v FEC

title: Interest groups in the USA
content: #lessonmajor What are the five kinds of democracy? direct - the electorate directly votes on issues (referendums) representative- the electorate elects representatives to do government for them (also consider the delegate v trustee method: whether MPs vote based on who voted for them or based on what they think is best- it's based on the Burke-an principle- which is part of an address to his constituents in 1776) pluralist- many different groups have a say/ power is shared across society liberal- rights are entrenched in laws/ the constitution- it's a subtype of representative democracy proletariat- state is organized by the workers/ the working class How do pressure groups try to influence politicians? Terminology for US pressure groups Mandate: when a mandatory regulation is introduced, forcing a product to fulfill a certain criteria (usually safety) (i.e. the state decides what a good product is) Bailout- when a company (often a bank) has it's debts covered by public funds prevented from going bankrupt Boondoggle- a government program that may been seen as inefficient. For example, using public funds to create jobs or build infrastructure that the market will not do because it is loss-making, but it makes the business that does it a shitton of money K street- a major street in Washington DC known for having numerous pressure group HQs Revolving door- the idea that people will be hired to write laws, then be hired to get around the laws, then be hired to write new laws to stop people getting around them, ad infinitum Pressure groups USA HW

title: Electoral College
content:
#lessonmajor

Recap Questions

The first presidential debate was between Nixon and Kennedy
The Iowa Caucus (wrong- it's an interest group made up of congress members)
idk how many justices are on the UK supreme court (it's 12)
a mandate is something given by electoral success for a group to enact it's policies

Is the electoral college fit for purpose?
How are electoral college votes allocated to the states?

The EC is a system used to choose the President of the United States. Instead of simply counting all votes across the country as one total: the votes are organised by state.
Each state is given a certain number of points, known as electoral votes, based on it's population. The larger the state population, the more electoral votes it receives.
For example, California has 54, and Wyoming has 3.
Every 10 years, a census is conducted, which can result in states gaining or losing electoral votes
The way that number of votes a state receives is straightforward:
the number of senators a state has, plus the number of members of the House of Representatives it sends to congress
The number of senators is always 2.
For example, Texas has 2 senators and 32 representatives, so it has 34 electoral college votes.
Therefore, the minimum number of electoral college votes a state can have is 3.
In addition, Washington DC is allocated 3 EC votes under the 23rd amendment (1961.)
When all the EC votes are added together, they total 538:
435 from the House of Representatives, 100 from senators, and 3 from DC.
To win the presidency, a candidate must get a majority of these;
270 is the majority needed

How the EC system works

people in each state vote for which candidate they prefer.
in most states, the candidate who gets the most votes wins all of the state's EC votes.
once all the states have votes, the EC votes are added up to decide the winner.
While this is usually winner-takes-all, Main and Nebraska split their ECVs depending on how many votes each candidate received.

[!NOTE]
This system means a candidate becomes president not by winning the most votes from people across the whole country, but by gaining the most EC votes.

The process

The popular vote
Certificates of Ascertainment issued
Safe Harbour Deadline
Electors meet and cast votes
Joint session of congress counts votes
Inauguration day

The role of Delegates.
Technically speaking, the winning candidate does not win the EC votes immediately. Instead, they win a delegate who pledges to vote for them when the EC meets.

in 33 states (plus DC) there is a legal requirement for delegates to vote for who they pledged to vote for
in 17 states, there is no law about this.

title: Invisible Primaries
content:
#lessonminor
Invisible primaries aren't even primaries.
People need lots of money to do primaries, which means they need financial backers.
Some people are going to fall by the wayside because of the expensive nature of primaries.
This is the invisible primary.
How to be successful in an invisible primary

have money
have name recognition

Why do you want to win the invisible primary?
The winner gets advantage from winning the invisible primary- by being a frontrunner.
Also, the winner gets:

a huge about of money for advertising
support of major donors to get funding later on
vocal support and endorsements from major office holders
gained 'insider establishment' status because they are supported by the party leaders
a sense of inevitability about your being chosen as winner
significant media coverage

Winning the invisible primary is a huge advantage, but not a guarantee.
2020 Democratic party primary
There were 29 notable figures running for the democratic primary. Over half withdrew before the first primaries- some of which were big names but didn't manage to get momentum.

For example, Kamala Harris was one of them.
BUT Pete Buttigieg, mostly unknown guy, did really well in the invisible primary (he was clear, former soldier, and gay). He wins the Iowa caucus, despite being almost unknown beforehand.

But he came up against Bernie Sanders (who he disliked because he was a centrist)
so then a bunch drop out to support Biden in order to beat Bernie

2016 Republican Primary
Jeb Bush (yes, that Bush) won the invisible primary and is very popular in the establishment.

however, in Iowa, he only wins 1/30 delegates, with Trump winning
Jeb does something incredible embarrassing (asks an audience to 'please clap' lmaooo)
Then he snowballs backwards. and Trump wins.

2004 Republican primary
Former governor of Vermont Howard Dean ran a campaign in 2004 to try and unseat incumbent Republican President George W. Bush. After losing the Iowa Caucus to eventual nomination winner John Kerry, Dean have an infamously socially awkward 'rallying cry' to his supporters – the media fallout from this 'Dean Scream' was all that was needed to end his election bid.
Do invisible primaries play a significant role in US primaries?

For
Theme
Against
Significance

Reduces the number of candidates in the race as candidates drop out.
Do they narrow voter choice?
There may be few or no dropouts during this phase.
3rd- the vote would narrow anyway as candidates with little name recognition run out of money.

allows a candidate to establish themselves- especially if they are lesser known/funded
Outsiders succeeding
no actual voting takes place, so they could perform very differently.
2nd- outsiders succeeding is rare and usually requires money/ cult popularity- but it can still happen, so it's stronger than Choice theme.

Gives an indication, and is often proven to be the eventual winner
Do they determine the winner
They can't tell us with any certainty.
1st- it very clearly gives- at least- an indication of who will win. In the case of Buttigieg- while he was the IP winner and didn't win overall, his endorsed candidate still won.

title: Party Conventions
content: #lessonminor Recall questions Mayor Pete ran in the 2020 Democratic primary a caucus is a discussion-based election there are ~400 members of the house of Representatives (435) There are 92 hereditary peers Vice-president pick The vice presidential pick (also known as a 'running mate' before being elected) is also confirmed at the party conference. This can be a big deal because candidates often want to show party unity. The ideal candidate will be: someone who is not completely politically aligned with the President from a different part of the country to the president, ideally a swing state (or of a specific demographic) their strengths are the president's weaknesses Do party conventions have any political significance? Significant Theme Insignificant Evaluation Technical selection, delegate debates, brokered conventions. through traditional roles Primaries are what determine the winner. Also, there has never been a brokered convention It has no impact on who the winner is. Presidential campaign launch, enthuses supporters and activists. Election outcomes Limited public opinion impact, decisions are often made before the conventions, unlikely that one will be more effective than the other. People who were going to vote one way or the other (the majority) will not be swayed by the convention. Reunites a party after primary conflict, prevents divisions and weaknesses being revealed Parties uniting the party has a limited impact on voting behaviour, people vote for parties on principle rather than switching. It just means that people already within the party are more passionate- but they would have voted that way anyway. Various evidence In 2016, Trump's main rival (Ted Cruz) refused to endorse Donald after losing, telling people to 'vote with your conscience.' This led to negative media coverage The democratic Convention of 2020 agreed policies based on a Unity Task Force headed by Biden and losing candidate Sanders. Losing primary candidates Sanders, Warren, Buttigeig and the irrelevant one all endorsed Biden, showing unity. In both 2016 and 2020 voters held strong views on the candidates. In 2020, more voters had a strong opinion regarding Trump than any incumbent since 1980. By May 2020, 69% stated that they had strong opinions on Trump. This suggested fewer swing voters than previous years This, alongside the reduction of conventions due to the pandemic, suggests that conventions have limited impact on the views of voters it is swing voters who swing an election- and Biden held advantage with independents even before the 2020 convention.

title: TV debates
content:
Do US TV debates matter to US elections?
#lessonminor

Yes, they do matter
No, they don't matter

(Technically, Clinton got a majority of votes.)
Hillary Clinton 'won' each debate in 2016 according to the polls, but lost the election.

Harris 'won' the debates, and then won 48% of the vote (Trump won 50%) despite coming in very late.
Events are largely focused in swing states- TV debates are worldwide.

Because each candidate needs 15% in polls to get onto TV, it means that (in theory, but not in practice) there should be a wide range of candidates.
People will vote for whoever they wanted to win before anyway- TV debates don't change minds.

~67 million watch the TV debates- it also gets coverage on social media in clips.
The electoral college fucks everyone over babes.

After Biden's awful debate, he dropped out of the election, suggesting that they have an affect on candidate's confidence.
The kind of people who watch the debates will be interested in politics- and these people are more likely to already have an opinion.

Since 1976, there has been an expectation for candidates to take part in televised debates. Candidates who are polling at an average of 15% in national polls are eligible to take part in presidential debates. For all recent debates, this has meant there have been only two candidates — one Democrat and one Republican, with third parties failing to meet the polling requirement. Despite the hype around these debates, numerous studies have concluded, ‘When it comes to shifting enough votes to decide the outcome of the election, presidential debates have rarely, if ever, mattered.’ In 2016, Hillary Clinton appeared to have ‘won’ each debate according to polling conducted afterwards but went on to lose the election.

title: What are primaries and caucuses
content: #lessonmajor Do invisible primaries play a significant role in US primaries? Are primaries a good thing? Do party conventions have any political significance TV debates Candidates from the same party compete against each other in a public vote. In some election years, there are two primaries- one for Democrats and one for Republicans. A voter is allowed to vote in one party's primary only. In other election years, only one party holds a primary. It is unusual for anyone inside the party to challenge a sitting president who plans to run for a second term. Different states hold their primaries on different dates. Some states choose to hold their primaries on the same day as each other to maximize their influence. The most significant example of this is known as 'Super Tuesday', in which lots of states hold their primaries on the same day. Each state is given a number of 'delegates' reflecting it's population. Delegates are Party activists. They pledge to go to a meeting (the party convention) that takes place after all states have voted. Delegates vote for a specific candidate reflecting how the voters in their state voted. *By winning in a state, a candidate wins delegates (think of them as points) which are added up as candidates compete in more states. In most cases, there is a proportional rule. If a candidate achieves 20% of the vote in a state, they receive 20% of the delegates from that state. Any candidate who gets over 50% of all delegates wins- they become the official presidential candidate for that party. This is confirmed at the party convention at the end of the voting process. All delegates meet and cast their votes to make the role official. What are the different kinds of primaries? Open primary a primary that does not require voters to be affiliated with a political party to vote. Iowa, Hawaii, Wyoming, Idaho Closed primary a primary that requires voters to be registered with a political party to vote in it Alaska for Democrats, Nevada, Michigan, Missouri for Republicans Semi-closed primary voters can choose to participate in either the democratic OR the republican primary New Hampshire, North Carolina Caucus deciding the candidates for primaries with discussion in a meeting. Hawaii- open, Colorado- closed, Maine- Semi-closed These can be open, closed, and semi-closed individually Homework questions What are the three methods through which delegates can be allocated through primaries and caucuses? - Pledged: pledged delegates are democratic delegates who are required to vote for a specific candidate- the one who won the most votes in the primary, or a caucus. There are three types- district delegates, at-large delegates, and add-on delegates (who represent elected officials or party leaders) - Unpledged: AKA superdelegates. Unique to the Democrats, again. - Bound: Republican delegates who are just pledged delegates but republican - Unbound: just superdelegates Proportional- For Democrats (they only use this one) they have a formula for allocating delegates based on the statewide vote in primaries and caucuses. Candidates must receive at least 15% of the vote to get any delegates. Republicans do this too on occasion Winner-take-all: all of a state's delegates available in a contest are allocated to the candidate who receives the majority vote in a state primary or caucus Hybrid- there are many versions, but most common is majority-take-all, where delegates are won proportionally based on the statewide vote. Still, a candidate may win them all if they receive over 50 percent of the vote. Which states have the earliest primaries and caucuses and why? Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada and South Carolina all have primaries/caucuses in February. Iowa starts early because it takes a while to do (caucus) New Hampshire starts early because it legally has shotgun (primary) What is frontloading, and why does it happen? Frontloading involves individual states moving their primary or caucus day to the front of the presidential primary season calendar it happens because snowballing happens. Biden did it in 2024 to try and help himself gain momentum. OR to make sure your state has more of a say if a candidate has already become presumptive, or the candidate they wanted to vote for ran out of money/confidence/etc and dropped out What is Super Tuesday, and what was Super Duper Tuesday? Super Tuesday is the day when the largest number of states hold their primary elections or caucuses simultaneously. Because of the large number of states participating, Super Tuesday has a substantial impact on the allocation of delegates. Super Duper Tuesday was for the 2008 primaries/caucuses- ~20 states participated. When did Trump secure a majority of delegates in 2020, and how many states had not voted by that point? he became the presumptive Republican candidate on March 17th, 2020. (the republican convention encouraged other states to use winner-takes-all) around 25 states had not voted by the time Trump became presumptive candidate Strengths and weaknesses Open Primaries +> maximizes the choice of voters. anyone can vote in either party's primary. This can be very important in years where only one party has a primary because it allows voters to participate without being registered +> they can attract more moderate voters. -> subject to spoiling tactics- Republicans slowing down a democrat candidate, wasting time and resources -> why are you letting rando's vote. Closed Primaries +> prevents spoiling tactics +> protects the identity (vibe) of a party -> prevents independents from voting, which could damage electoral chances. -> unfair in years where only one party holds a primary

title: EXOP
content: #lessonmajor The executive office of the presidency. (This is why it's called the presidency: because there is many people in it.) Related to Vice-president and cabinet Random notes It's made up of about 30 different offices and departments. it started off as advisors to the president they are established to help the president make decisions and carry out their policies. Important ones to know ==the national security council ==the office of management and budget ==white house office FYI- you can't scrutinize them because they aren't elected. (some members get scrutiny, but it's significantly less than cabinet) EXOP aren't talked about at all in the constitution. They are used much more than the cabinet because it's better to give a job to an agency which gets less scrutiny- so cabinet becomes useless. Susie Wiles: White house chief of staff. Could be called the second most powerful person in the US. the problem is that EXOP can conflict with cabinet because they are doing the same job- so they do the same job twice (which is not good) Initially, FDR sets up EXOP to help deal with the great depression, because he was building all this shit and needs to get it right. It is initially quite small. Now it has ~1,800 employees the budget is voted for by congress. Franklin Delanore Roosevelt Franklin D. Roosevelt became president in 1933- right in the middle of the great depression (which was caused by the wall street crash.) he sets up lots of new organizations to help deal with it- called are the ==alphabet agencies this is called New Federalism trying to set up all these agencies is hard work, because Roosevelt lacks the staff around him. there were already ~100 government agencies rattling around- and it is a hugely disorganized mess. many of the departments and government agencies are very independent Why does EXOP exist? FDR establishes a committee to make recommendations all the loose agencies get merged into the 12 departments a new set of agencies are set up that are just staff to help the president. initially, it has around 600 staff in two agencies this then steadily expands during the cold war to 2-3000 people by 1993, it has a budget of $194 million this peaks in 2005, at $7.6 billion, mostly due to the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan the budget is currently ~$1 billion What are the problems with EXOP? Weak checks and balances from congress around 25 people must face senate confirmation from a staff of ~4,000 some areas of EXOP have scrutiny from Congressional Committees, but many who do not- particularly the WHO. (the white house office has no scrutiny in the slightest.) Weak checks and balances from the judiciary 'privilege' is a legal right that we sometimes have to not turn over information to courts. For example, e-mails between you and your lawyer when preparing your cases 'executive privilege' exists in the US. it applies when turning over information would impair the functioning of the government. this clearly sometimes applies- like when people are on terrorist lists but sometimes it's used to hide things- like Nixon with Watergate, or Trump with the Epstein list. Falling out with other departments sometimes the goals or methods of EXOP simply don't align with those of the Federal Departments (the ones led by cabinet officers) EXOP often gets projects that Departments don't get Exercise what kinds of people are in the WHO? wankers how much oversight does it get from Congress? Nish How much power does it have? Too much. What is the Office of Management and Budget?

title: Formal powers
content:
Judicial branch powers
Appointing justices

the president can nominate Supreme Court justices to the Supreme Court.
this does, however, require senate confirmation

Biden nominated Ketanji Brown-Jackson in 2022
Trump nominated Brett Kavanaugh in 2018- which got through, despite his controversial history

Obama tried to nominate Merrick Garland right before the 2016 election- but the senate, under direction of Bitch McConnell, ignored it.
Amy Coney Barrett was put through in September 2020, though- but we already knew that Trump has no honor.

all justices from Trump were put through.

Power of pardon

in 2022, Biden pardoned thousands of individuals for simple possession of Marijuana- acknowledging how a federal charge can make finding housing and jobs easier, despite no harsh crime being committed.
in January 2025, Trump pardoned 1500 January 6th rioters, despite it being incredibly controversial

title: How does the president relate to congress
content:
#lessonmajor
To what extent can the president dominate congress in domestic policy?

Dominated
Theme
Not

takes the courts to overturn them. Congress cannot. plus, Trump v. CASA Inc
Executive orders (2)
Congressional bills cannot be overturned by executive orders.

can only be overturned with a majority (Biden's EV regulations bill veto) in BOTH HOUSES.
Presidential veto (1)
can be overturned.

agenda

COVID efforts were organized and overseen by Biden.
national events (3)
Needs permission from congress to do things via the budget- i.e. power of the purse.

President can choose when to adjourn congress. Trump threatened to do so in 2020 to get his nominees through.
convening congress
Realistically, it doesn't happen that much- because it's only if both houses can't agree to a recess date.

Evaluation: Overall, the President dominates congress in domestic policy to a large extent- because although congress does have methods of overruling presidential power (overriding the presidential veto, and passing bills which the president cannot ignore) both take such a significant coordination that being able to perform both- especially in such a partisan political system- is extremely unrealistic for it to occur, and therefore makes congress have little ability to check the executive- whilst the president has many ways of checking the legislature.

To what extent can the president dominate the judiciary

Dominate
Theme
Not

nomination

executive orders
