title: Vice-president and cabinet
content:
#lessonminor
How much do the Vice-president of the USA and president matter?
The vice-president is a role that is elastic in terms of it's power. It is principally ceremonial- but the president can give the vice more power.

constitutionally speaking, the VP only has two powers

to case the deciding vote of a tie in the senate
to take on the roles/duties of the president if the president is unable to, i.e.:

the president is dead
the president is undergoing surgery (Harris for 84 minutes during Biden's)
the president is incommunicado (during 9/11, Bush had bad WIFI for the start. Dick Cheney ordered one of the planes to be shot down, but it had been taken over by a passenger rebellion so unnecessary.)

informal powers of the VP

Dick Cheney (Bush's VP) was given considerable power over energy and defense policy.
Harris was a border 'tsar'

they can be quite important in terms of the image of the white house

for Harris, it was Biden appearing progressive
J.D Vance shows a connection to white, working-class voters and veterans.
Biden (under Obama) was a sign of competence and experience besides the relatively youthful Obama.
Mike Pence represented the Christian right-wing
Harry Truman under FDR was very apprehensive about having good relations with the USSR. This was significant because he succeeded FDR.

What is the purpose of the US Cabinet?

the cabinet has no constitutional power EXCEPT under the 25th amendment

the 25th amendment gives the cabinet the power to remove the president- based on a majority vote- if they feel that the president is literally unable to carry out their duties

otherwise, the cabinet is an advisory body only.

they are called cabinet officers, not ministers

MOST of them are the head of a federal government department.

There are currently 15. Also trump recently (5/09/25) renamed the department of defense to war

some are heads of other agencies, like the CIA

all but three of them require senate confirmation, and they can also be impeached by congress

for each new federal government department to be created or abolished, an act of Congress must be passed
they are usually policy experts, not previously in politics.
It meets quite rarely. Joe Biden only held 9 cabinet meetings.
Sometimes people will attend meetings whilst not being formal cabinet officers (i.e. Musk)

title: What factors affect the amount of power that the president has
content: #lessonminor #unfinished How can the stages in the election cycle affect a president's power? Debate Stages in the election cycle Typically characterized by: Soon after the presidential election Presidents are at their most powerful and influential. They have a clear mandate- and congress will generally support them because they are popular. Mid-term elections Common to lose control of at least one house in Congress, massively reducing their ability to achieve policy goals. President must work on being persuasive. Throughout the remainder of the term Popularity often declines, making persuasion in Congress even harder. Policies goals may have not been achieved, and scandals build up. The end of a president's second term The president sometimes becomes a 'lame duck' in the last 6-12 months as everyone is focused on their successors.

title: Civil rights and civil liberties
content: #lessonmajor What is the history of immigration to the USA? Multiculturalism multiculturalists believe that certain ethnic groups are oppressed in different ways. This oppression is opposed by a belief in social advancement. Conservatives tend to reject this notion. there are considerable disagreements over both what this oppression looks like and how it should be solved. Note- factor in multiple oppressed groups, not just black Americans. Think women, LGBTQ+, Native Americans, migrants from India, Latin America, and East Asians. How do you create equality between different groups? There are three approaches to this: Social advancement should be about rights (liberal view) social advancement should be about wealth (socialist view) social advancement should be about culture (secret third thing) How successfully has racial equality been achieved in the US? there are three dominant themes to this debate: affirmative action voting rights representation Homework task- rank the three themes, justify relative importance determine which side wins for each theme write an introduction and conclusion

title: History of USA immigration
content:
#lessonminor #unfinished
Politics in the USA
1790s-1830s
•The dominant view at this time was that whites were a Herrenvolk – ‘Master folk/race’. This particularly applied to the Anglo-Saxon races of the Germans and English.
•God had created the United States by allowing them to win the War of Independence.
•The white race therefore had the God given right to settle across the continent. This theory was known as ‘Manifest Destiny’.
•The USA was a white country. Non-whites could not be citizens of the Republic. Therefore, they didn’t possess any benefits of being a citizen – namely rights.
•All white men deserved equal rights to one another.
•Native Americans were racially inferior. They could be put onto ‘reservations’, but violent resistance had to be crushed.
•Blacks were inferior to whites. And women were emotional and reliant upon men. They certainly did not have the ability to make political decisions.
1830s-1865
•A huge divide opens in the US. It is driven partly by the Industrial Revolution, with the North industrialising and the South relying on exporting cotton (which was worth more than its weight in gold!). The South’s tropical climate allowed this to happen. (Remember Clinton’s criticism of Madison and pressure groups!)
•The North wants to ban slavery, as its being seen as immoral by lots of countries. The British Empire had already begun to ban it from around 1800. Southerners disagree.
•The situation is complicated by the fact that the US is still expanding. Should new states be ‘slave-states’ or ‘free-states’? The issue of slavery is a state rights issue, not a federal issue.
•In the 1850s, the Democratic Party splits over the issue, and a new party forms that is exclusively anti-slavery, called the Republican Party.
White supremacism is still completely normal at this point. People just disagree over whether non-whites deserve to be made citizens of the Republic
•In November 1860, the Republican candidate – Abraham Lincoln – becomes US President but only carries Northern states.
•Southern states secede from the US en masse. They form a new country called the Confederate States of America (CSA).
•The USA invades the CSA. The better USA economy allows it to defeat the CSA in 1865.
•Abraham Lincoln then forces the adoption of the 13th Amendment, banning slavery. It’s know as the ‘Emancipation Amendment’.
•The 15th Amendment made it illegal to stop someone voting because of their race (provided that they were a man…)
1865-1940s
•Black People are emancipated in the South and given equal rights. However…
•Southern states hate the Northerns and consider them invaders. The Southern states do everything possible to frustrate the new equal rights laws. A terrorist group called the Klu Klux Klan is set up.
•Segregation is enforced through ‘Jim Crow laws’ (rhymes with something). Legally, Black People should enjoy equality quality public services (eg. schools) to whites, but in practice this does not happen.
•Laws are carefully designed to prevent blacks from voting, such as needing to pass a literacy tests before you can vote.
•The final Native Americans were forced onto reservations by the US Army in the ‘Indian Wars’.
•A female suffrage movement developed after the Civil War and the 19th Amendment gave women the right to vote in 1920
1940s-1960s
•Opposition to segregation in the South develops through the  National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), Rosa Parks and Martin Luther King, Jr.
•They win several legal victories, arguing that segregation is racist. They get greater Civil Rights.
•However, there is extreme violence in the South and some other cities. Racism remains deeply culturally imbedded. The terrorist Klu Klux Klan re-emerges.
•President Johnson (Dem) supports the Civil Rights Act in 1964. Democratic support plummets in the Southern states and it switches to the Republicans. The South had been known as the ‘Solid South’ for Democrats.
1960s-2000s
Bussing orders school districts to bus white children to schools in majority black areas. It began in the 1960s, but faded away in the 1980 s due to opposition from whites in the South.
•An argument develops that says that changing rights only gives equality of opportunity. What was really needed was equality of ‘results’ (meaning ‘equality of outcome’).
•A movement calling for affirmative action forms. Affirmative action means positive discrimination – where members of minority groups are given advantages over majority groups (eg. Easier access to university). The goal it to make minority groups wealthier.
•Furthermore, integration (opposed to segregation) is imposed on Southern states by the federal government.
•A feminist movement also develops in the 1960s – although the Equal Rights Amendment fails to adopted, despite being passed in Congress and being signed by President Carter.
•An LGBT rights amendment develops. Harvey Milk becomes the first openly gay official in California, but is murdered in 1978. Homosexual acts between men are legalised by the Supreme Court in southern states in 2003.
2000s-
•Affirmative action has been increasingly criticised. Several Supreme Court rulings have found against affirmative action projects since 2003.
•LGBT rights have improved – The US military policy of ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t tell’ was removed in 2011, and same-sex marriage legalised in 2015 by a Supreme Court ruling.
•The # MeToo movement against sexual assault has developed since 2017.
•President Obama worked to allow easier access for refugees to the USA.
•The white supremacy movement has begun to grow since 2016. Violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters broke out in Charlottesville in 2017. Hostility to immigration and Islamophobia has also grown.
What is immigration like today?
Key things to remember (cultural differences)
•The USA is ‘a nation of immigrants’. Many Americans’ identity comes from having dual heritage (eg. Italian-American; Irish-American). This is partly due to a belief in the American Dream – any hardworking, morally good person can become wealthy – that attracted immigrants
•The USA has become increasingly intolerant to Hispanic people and Muslims, due partly to the War on Drugs (starting in the 1970s), the War on Terror (2001) and a big dollop of bigotry – possibly due the insular nature of rural American communities and existing racial politics.
•De-industrialisation since the 1980s has created the Rust Belt. Immigrants can be perceived as threats to the security of semi and unskilled labourers. (Feeling keen? Look up the Modernisation Loser Thesis!)
Totals:
- as of 2023, 27% of the US population are either immigrants or the children of immigrants. That's about 90 million people
- around 3/4 of those are in the US legally. Hence, it is estimated that there are around 22 million illegal immigrants or children of illegal immigrants.

The US has the largest immigrant population of any country in the world
The figures in 2024:

around 1 million people legally migrated to the USA
it is estimated that about 3 million illegally migrated.
Note that the term undocumented and illegal are different but have a big overlap. Undocumented is mostly children of illegal immigrants.

Why is illegal immigration so high?

in the 1940s, the US allowed large numbers of guest workers from Mexico. They could stay to work briefly- often coming as seasonable labour. However, this was ended in 1964. Thus, many people chose to make a one-way trip

part of the problem is that the people would come and go seasonally- so many chose to go and not leave.

There was exceptional instability in Latin America in recent years- notably in Mexico and Venezuela
A law called Title 42 was used to expel new arrivals during COVID to protect the population from disease. Some people were expelled several times- but that was counted as individual people, inflating the statistics.

What has illegal immigration been like since the 1970s

border encounters by the Border Guard are used as a broad estimation to gauge the number of illegal migrants
numbers wa
There was a gradual increase form 1970-2000, a reduction

How have US presidents responded?

in the eighties and nineties, both Reagan and Clinton deployed more border agents and introduced harsher penalties for illegal migration. However, this encouraged even less seasonal migration
In 1986, the Immigration reform and control act is introduced.
Makes it illegal to hire undocumented migrants
but grants amnesty to 3 million migrants, and also does an executive order to give that to children of undocumented migrants' children
From 2000-2016
the Mexican
birth rate dropped, leading to fewer youths trying to cross
George Bush:

Deployed more border guards, citing 9/11
introduced 'secure communities' in 2008, meaning that anyone arrested automatically had their migration status checked

Barack Obama

makes it easier to get visas for seasonal work
tried to introduce the DREAM act, making it so kids who came in illegally can work (although they can't be here forever)

this is EXACTLY what George Bush tried to introduce. It failed due to a republican filibuster

in 2012, he puts out a memorandum (DACA) instructed the federal police to not apprehend undocumented immigrants who arrived as minors

in 2014, he expands this to DAPA, which applies it to parents too

This gets blocked by the supreme court in 2016

He maximises 'temporary protected status' which means that some migrants (from countries/minorities) and gives a lot of them out

He had a record number of deportations. He deports more than Trump in his first term.

Trump (first term):

he says he is going to build a wall

he only succeeds in building a fifth of it
he says he'll make Mexico pay by putting tariffs. he is stupid

He tries to phase out DACA but this is blocked by district courts
in the summer of 2017, Trump orders the Family-separation policy. Children of undocumented migrants are taken from their parents and put in care homes and the parents are deported/put in jail

Essay planning
•How many Americans have been affected?
•Does one point cause/directly-affect other points?
•If each point was individually ‘rubbed out’ of history, which one would change the USA the most?

title: How does the US supreme court protect rights
content: #lessonminor #unfinished What is public policy? When the federal government creates a law and it affects the general public. this can be done by passing acts of congress or by signing executive orders How do cases impact public policy? (Citizens United v. FEC) it led to their being unlimited campaign money (they were specifically allowing super PACs) Can policy be also Civil rights and civil liberties

title: Interpretations and debates of the SC
content: #homepage There are four major debates in this topic. The Political versus Judicial nature of the supreme court Living constitution v originalism How effectively civil and constitutional rights have been upheld by the Supreme court and the effectiveness of this The extent of their powers and effectiveness of checks and balances Evidence that is useful for all of them Case name Date Explanation Where to use? United states v. Skremetti 2025 Upheld Tennessee's ban on gender-affirming care for minors. Judicial/Political 2025 Ordered the release of $2 billion in foreign aid. Amy Coney Barret voted against Trump Trump v Casa, Inc. 2025 Curtailed the ability of lower courts to stop executive orders on a nationwide level. Checks and balances! Trump v United States 2024 Broad immunity for 'official acts' as president. Checks and balances Alexander v South Carola State Conference of the NAACP 2024 Upheld a racially gerrymandered map by setting a high evidentiary bar. Limited the scope for Judicial correction. Tiktok v Garland 2024 Congress has the right to force the sale of Tiktok due to concerns over national security. Unanimous decision. Nearly 50% of court decisions are 9-0 or 8-1 Admissions v Harvard 2023 Decided that favourable conditions of entry for African Americans was unconstitutional. Shows that they don't bow to outside pressure. Jones v Hendrix 2023 A prisoner convicted of an act which is not a crime does not have writ of Habeas corpus. immigration Creative v. Elenis 2023 Businesses can refuse to serve same-sex based on religious rights. Dobbs v Jackson women's health org 2022 Overturned Roe v Wade- pro-federalism. The court adheres to legal principles. Brown v Davenport 2022 Habeas Corpus Can only be used to challenge convictions made in which the court did not hold jurisdiction. California V. Texas 2021 Upheld the constitutionality of the ACA 2020 Employers cannot discriminate based on sexual orientation or gender identity. Directly affected public policy. Bostock v Clayton County 2020 Extended civil rights protections to LGBTQ+ employees. Based on the Civil rights act (1964) Both liberal and conservative justices supported this. June medical services v. Russo 2020 Struck down Louisiana law that imposed restrictions on abortion providers Rucho v Common Cause 2019 Federal courts have no role in regulating partisan gerrymandering Nielson v Preap 2019 Allowed warrantless searches of immigrants homes. immigration Trump v Hawaii 2018 Upheld the muslim travel ban immigration Carpenter v United States 2018 Government does need a warrant to access mobile location date, UNLESS it's a matter of national security. Supported 4th amendment rights Murphy v NCAA 2018 Overturned the PASPA, which prohibited states from authorising sports gambling. Cooper v Harris 2017 Ruled that North Carolina's redistricting was race-based, and so unconstitutional. Glossip v Gross 2015 on lethal injections (they are fine.) Obergefell v Hodges 2015 Legalised same-sex marriage. National federation of independent businesses v Sebelius 2012 Upheld the constitutionality of the Affordable Care act Undermines state authority. Political Boumediene v Bush 2008 Guantanamo detainees directly entitles to submit habeas corpus petitions to federal judges in Washington These directly went against Congressional laws- such as the AEDPA (Antiterrorism and effective death penalty act (1996) (name) V Rumsfeld 2000s Upheld Habeas Corpus Went against Department of defense appropriations act 2006. Various other points the court can only hear 60-200 cases each year, it rejects thousands of cases, letting lower court's decisions stand i.e. it does not overly involve itself The Supreme court often sides with federalism. It continually steps into public policy. The opportunity to check the supreme court is more difficult due to life tenure Trump appointed 3 justices, which have helped uphold many of his decisions. It clearly has the power to reinterpret long-established precents. The supreme court tends to not uphold privacy rights- especially for immigrants, despite it being in the bill of rights. It does uphold rights of groups not included in the constitution (Living constitution theory) it tends to reinforce due process, notably for immigrants recently (2025) courts blocked Trump's orders to send troops to Chicago, and he sent other troops.

title: Judicial ideologies
content: #table ConservativeA justice who is more likely to try to achieve rulings that produce a more limited federal government and uphold conservative ideals such as pro-gun rights and pro-life. Likely to interpret the Constitution more literally Conservative v. Liberal LiberalA justice who is more likely to try to achieve rulings that produce greater equality for all and uphold liberal ideals, which may mean a larger federal government, such as LGBTQ+ rights and gun control. Likely to interpret the Constitution more broadly Loose constructionistA justice who is more willing to interpret the wording of the Constitution broadly, which might include giving more power to the federal government Loose constructionist v strict constitutionalist Strict constructionistA justice who will stick to the wording of the Constitution as the text is written, without interpretation. This therefore includes protecting state power Judicial restraintA justice who believes in a limited role for the Supreme Court, deferring to the elected and accountable branches where possible Judicial restraint v. judicial activism Judicial restraintA justice who believes in a limited role for the Supreme Court, deferring to the elected and accountable branches where possible Living ConstitutionA belief that the Constitution is a living, organic and evolutionary document that can be changed through reinterpretationover time. Closely linked to loose constructionism Living constitution v originalism OriginalismA belief that the meaning andinterpretation of the US Constitutionare set by the original principles of the document. It should not be subjected to broad interpretation in light of modern advances

title: The Supreme Court
content: Judicial ideologies The appointment process How does the US supreme court protect rights What else is there to learn about the SC Cases for evidence SC Supreme court and rights comparative Interpretations and debates of the SC #homepage How does the supreme court ensure that the judges are independent? -          Justices are appointed for life, so they can’t be removed for the decisions they make -          Vacancies only occur if a sitting justice retires, dies, or is impeached (VERY RARE) congress can theoretically change the number of justices- but the last time they did that was in the 1800s. this prevents other branches from packing the courts -          The constitution explicitly forbids the salary of justices being lowered during their time in office. They get paid just under $300, 000 per year. It rises with inflation. With a fixed salary, justices don’t need to worry about retributive salary lowering for voting a certain way -          Justices are nominated by the president and then confirmed by the senate. This means they both don’t have all-consuming power. They are still legitimized by being approved by a legislative body -          The courts have their own power given by the separation of powers. The court can check the powers of congress and the president through judicial review. The court doesn’t have the actual power to enforce this ruling. However- this makes the three branches dependent on each other. -          The American bar association (ABA) rates the suitability of nominated justices through a panel of non-politically motivated industry experts who aim to ensure the court is composed of people who understand and carry out the law rather than the will of a political party.

title: What else is there to learn about the SC

#lessonminor #unfinished
What is Judicial activism?

this is when the supreme court rules an an issue rather than letting the president or congress solving it. This can be both liberal (Obergefell v. Hodges- on gay marriage) or conservative (Citizens united v. FEC- allowing super PACS)
Judicial restraint is when, rather than reaching decisions based on activism, judges tend to stare decisis- so, letting decisions stand. They are far more likely to use past court rulings to reach a decision. This can be liberal (whole women's health v Hellerstead) or conservative (Dobbs v Jackson)

Checks and balances

title: Ideologies Homepage
content: Socialism Socialism Liberalism Liberalism Introduction #homepage [!tip] There is no solid spectrum for ideologies- there are no opposites or true 'left' and 'right'. Attempting to view this as black and white is nonsense, even attempting to do it in colour is nonsense. You need ten fucking dimensions for this. Also, they aren't all separate, they all contain shared ideas. There are two types of ideology: Explanatory: explaining how the world works Normative: morally what 'should' happen- how society should be The only ideology that doesn't have a normative element is conservatism. Liberalism- the basic ideology is 'freedom' Classical liberals is what we call 'right wing liberals'. they believe that the state is the biggest threat to freedom, so they want smaller state Modern liberals the state gives rights, so it isn't a threat modern liberals think that since having no money means you can't do much, so it means you have less freedom so the idea is that the state can do things to give the poor more opportunities Socialism They want equality of power- everyone has an equal say in what happens with a group. The focus is now on culture, not on money. It was traditionally based on wealth, but now it's more on culture. (?) Conservatives They value stability- and to some extent protect 'sacred things.' (Like how you can't make jokes about the Holocaust.) For some, this 'sacred' idea is turned up quite far. it's a knee-jerk response for most Conservativism changes a LOT based on the time and space that it is in.

title: Liberalism
content: John Locke Historical context of John Locke Summer 1683, Charles II has been king for more than 20 years. Locke doesn't like Charlie boy — he is also somewhat linked to a plot to kill the king. He moves to the Netherlands to avoid capture. Locke was very important to British politics. He was an apprentice to the Earl of Shaftsbury, who was basically a radical Marxist. he believed that Parliament should meet a bit more often he thinks the king should have a bit less power There is only one thing that Locke hates more than the King: Catholics. Locke worries about the growing influence of Catholicism in England — when James comes in, he is a lot harsher on protestants. Locke is annoyed by this. He decides to come up with a system where people of different religions don't try to kill each other. Locke tries to do a lot of philosophy. Then in 1689, James gets overthrown and the new rulers are more tolerant. He comes back to England to write 3 books; two of which he didn't put his name on, because they were so radical. He theorised that monarchs punishing people for different beliefs is ineffective at changing their beliefs, so people should be allowed to believe what they want to believe and people tolerate that. Also, whenever certain beliefs are banned, violence happens. Locke is literally just the original 'power of friendship' guy. He writes another book on the Monarch. He said that the Divine Right of Kings (King has to do whatever they want or God will be angry at you) is... bad. He says that people should be able to choose their leaders. He says that if the ruler breaks the people's trust, the people should be able to overthrow them. This is literally the foundation of democracy. Although, keep in mind he still hated Catholics (because they were sworn to one ruler — the Pope), and didn't count Atheists. He also invested some money in the slave trade. These ideas are the foundation of Liberalism. rights tolerance freedom democracy equality of opportunity limited government rule of law Core ideas of Liberalism Individualism The idea that individuals are capable of making decisions for themselves, as opposed to requiring their 'betters' to do that on their behalf. Individuals are self-interested, rather than being concerned about wider society. However, as individuals do not exist in a vacuum, liberalism argues for tolerance of others, particularly of their political and religious views. If someone is not causing you harm, they should be allowed to continue their business. It's just 'treat others how you wish to be treated.' The change in understanding of tolerance The understanding of tolerance has evolved. Mary Wollstonecraft argued to extend tolerance to women, particularly in the case of the right to vote. In the 20th century, Betty Friedan continued this, arguing for full equality for women. Over time, different groups have been the focus of debates around tolerance. In the UK, this has included allowing Catholics and Jews to sit in Parliament, tolerance towards migrants, homosexuality, and now transgender people. Liberal denominations Whilst all liberals support the argument that the individual is more important than any collective group, modern and classical liberals have different ideas on what liberals can achieve in isolation. Classical liberals support 'egoistic individualism' that is the belief that humans are rational, and therefore self-interested, therefore self-reliant and capable of thriving on their own. society is atomistic — we are all of the atoms: separate. Modern liberals are critical of this concept, supporting 'developmental individualism', noting that personal circumstances play a big role in an individual's ability to thrive in isolation. These situations mostly refer to inequalities — such as in race, class, and gender. Whilst liberals argue in favour of a tolerant, fair society, they cannot control other's social attitudes. Consequently, modern liberals (such as John Rawls) argue that if humans are left to their own devices, inequalities will get worse. Therefore, the role of the state is to help individuals develop and thrive through opportunities. Freedom/liberty For liberals, freedom is not granted by a ruler or government, it is a natural right that humans have by virtue of being human. The state's role is to uphold this freedom by preventing harm to individuals that would impact their liberty, and to enforce contracts that individuals freely enter into with each other. Locke described this role as vital for ensuring people were free. 'where there is no law, there is no liberty' this concept antithetical to the idea of Negative freedom "Negative liberty is the absence of obstacles, barriers or constraints." (i.e. the govt. should leave you alone.) The state only exists by consent of the governed, which is also known as the social contract — which Locke believes that humans enter into willingly to help ensure that there is an arbitrator to uphold the freedom of individuals. Locke says that when a government ceases to promote freedom, the people have the right to withdraw their consent to be governed and replace the government. State The more you are left alone, the freer you are. But without a state, bad things will happen. But if the state is too big, bad things will happen. The state needs to exist in order to enforce the laws so that people can be free, but also as small as possible so the state can't infringe on anybody's rights. the state is a 'necessary evil' This is called a 'Nightwatchman State' (Locke invented this) So, the state's job is: protect us from each other protect us from foreign countries enforce contracts The government exists by the consent of the people via a 'social contract.' People would be more willing to obey a government whose authority is limited, is elected by the people, and which is restricted in it's ability to restrict rights via a constitution. Modern liberalism and the state Some liberals have adopted a more positive view of the state — because of the potential good a state can do to allow human flourishing: aka an 'enabling state'. [!EXAMPLE] Case study Around the start of the 20th century, it was clear that many in industrial Britain were caught in a 'poverty trap' — forced to work for low pay that could barely cover rent, without any means to retire or miss work because of illness. Children were also caught in this, and so they were unable to be educated and therefore broaden their prospects. As such, modern liberals questioned whether there was genuine equality of opportunity, and whether it was fair to assume those in poverty earned it through idleness. so, modern liberals called for the state to ensure genuine freedom of opportunity, and a safety net (pensions/national insurance for unemployment/welfare/benefits) for those struggling these ideas are connected to Keynesian economic theory and John Stuart Mill Rationalism [!INFO] Everyone is a rational person, so they are capable of making the best decisions for themselves. This is rationalism, which - for classical liberals - is the foundation of personal freedom and means that the government should intervene as minimally as possible Thinkers here are John Locke and Adam Smith they argue that individuals, guided by reason, can identify their own interests and act in ways that promote societal progress So therefore, we have some rights that should never be infringed the right to life is the most important one they are split on right to an abortion / right to death Some also argued that this idea advocates for laissez-faire capitalism, the main proponent being Adam Smith Adam Smith had this idea called the invisible hand of the market: Because people are rational, this means that their actions collectively create wealth and efficiency i.e. the market works because everyone is acting well within the market. This is the classical liberal idea about the economy, which is completely different from Modern liberal's ideas about the state. Equality/social justice Liberal Democracy

title: Socialism
content: You have 4 major socialist ideas. The spec only asks for three. DON'T WRITE ABOUT THE FOURTH ONE (Democratic Socialism) Revolutionary socialism (AKA. Marxism) Important distinction Marx's view of history Pre-revolution phase Nature of society Nature of capitalism Marx's theory of alienation Revolutionary phase Communists utopia Marxism definitions [!info] There is quite a wide range between Revolutionary Socialism and the Third way. Think of it like pure squash and water with a drop of squash. In the 1800s, there are a shitton of revolutions. This is considered the origin of socialism. In 1848, Marx publishes the communist manifesto whilst with his friend, Friedrich Engels. Democratic Socialism is Marxism without the violence. (This is the one that you can't talk about in the exam) Beatrice & Sidney Webb (they found the Fabian society which is still very involved with the labour party) these are two of our key thinkers Social Democracy is a compromise between socialism and capitalism. The third way is Tony fucking Blair. Marxism Important distinction We learn about Marx's ideas, not how they were carried out. The exam board does not consider soviet communism to be communism. Marx Soviet Communism Popular today in universities and some very radical trade unions seen in the eastern bloc criticised for corrupting Marxist ideas Marx's view of history Pre-revolution phase Always involves two classes- two economic groups. Today, it's the capitalists and the workers. Marx says that there is a constant cycle of creating new economic systems which still uphold oppression. Marx says that capitalism will be the last of these before communism. He uses an idea of Hegel- dialectical change- he says that the way that ideas develop is by a thesis and an antithesis challenging each other, which then creates a synthesis. Marx got taught by Hegel. He steals the idea and calls it dialectical/historical materialism- the same idea but the theses and antitheses are economic systems. this is why Marxists are atheists- because they are materialists. It's materialism (empiricism) and rationalism (idealism- like belief in God or the soul) Marx says that every society is underpinned by oppression. "The history of all hitherto existing society is the history of class struggles." For Capitalism, there are two classes; the Bourgeoisie and the Proletariat. The Bourgeoisie are those who own Capital (the means of production) or Land (the resources of production) Nature of society Marx talks about the nature of society- that being the substructure (the economic system) and the superstructure (which is both a product the substructure and what helps keep it in place) The superstructure includes education, police, religion, nationalism, media, and the legal system. the legal system enforces private ownership religion can enforce that things are individually your fault/god's will the police enforce the legal system nationalism means that people don't think that their problems are caused by the upper class, but by people of other countries He calls this false consciousness Nature of capitalism Marx believes that capitalism will inevitably collapse. there is a fixed amount of wealth in the world. the rich can only get richer if the poor get poorer/ same thing with power (technically this is untrue) to earn more profits, capitalists cut wages. this happens across the economy but workers need money to buy the capitalist's goods- so some capitalist companies go bankrupt when wages are too low. then the bankrupt capitalist joins the working class the capitalists then become a smaller and smaller class. Marx's theory of alienation Also, workers become alienated from their humanity, because they never create product from start to finish (which is vital to humanity). This is because capitalism encourages specialisation. Workers become depressed- this is akin to being a prisoner. Revolutionary phase The oppressed class will eventually realise that they are being oppressed as a group, and they will gain class conciousness. [!tip] Context for Marx's time When Marx is writing in the 1840 s, the majority of people don't have a right to vote. The phases of the revolution The workers spontaneously rise up against the capitalists Note that Marxists do hate Social Democrats, because they are compliant in the system, but they pretend to be on the side of Socialism. Workers seize control of the factories and establish democratic workers' councils. The state is seized. The state becomes a dictatorship of the proletariat — a workers' democracy where capitalists are prevented from having political power. A 'dictatorship' of the proletariat is not a traditional dictatorship, it's a dictatorship because the capitalists are locked out. Because everything is collectively owned, there is no bourgeoisie class. Therefore, there is only one class, and there is a classless society. The state performs two functions: To 'protect the gains of the revolution' — to fight against internal enemies (bourgeoisie) who could lead a counterrevolution. To prevent external threats: invasion of nearby capitalist countries — which could also be fascists. - Anarchists think that the state should be gone cold turkey To create a 'planned economy', where every industry is nationalized, and decisions about the economy are made centrally. Communists utopia Marx believed that this was inevitable, 95% of what he writes is about the pre-revolutionary phase. The post-revolutionary phase happens once the whole world has become communist Everyone will live in communes of about 200 people (hence the term communism) There will be de-urbanization because cities are a product of capitalism There is no need for a state. The state will 'wither away' according to Marx Human nature will completely change. Under capitalism, humans are selfish, competitive and materialistic, because those traits are encouraged by the superstructure. With a new superstructure, human nature will change and become flawless. [!summary] — "From each according to their ability, to each according to their need." Democratic socialism Historical context Was capitalism changing? Marx predicted that over time, wealth would concentrate into the hands of a smaller and smaller bourgeoisie. However, this guy called Eduard Bernstein argued that this wasn't happening By the 1980s, Bernstein argued that capitalism was spreading wealth, not concentrating it. This was because of **— the one that you can't talk about in essays. Don't do it.** Social Democracy Social Democracy

title: Marxism definitions
content:
Word
Definition

Bourgeois state
The police/military/laws (etc) that are controlled by the bourgeoisie and oppress the proletariat.

Class oppression
When one class uses people of another class

Armed struggle
Violent opposition to capitalism, such as a rebellion or civil war.

Dictatorship of the proleteriat
A political system where the bourgeoisie can't take part.

Vanguard party
An organisation that co-ordinates the revolution and runs the new society (Leninism)

Inequality
A lack of equality

Historical materialism
All of history is determined by economics

Bourgeoisie
The class that owns the means of production in a capitalist country.

Proletariat
The class that does not own the means of production in a capitalist country.

Social revolution
A revolution that doesn't just change the government, but the fundamental structure of society.

Capitalism is doomed
Communism is inevitable

Substructure
The economic structure

Dialectic
When two ideas oppose each other and lead to the creation of a new idea.

Surplus value
The difference between what you are paid and the value you produce, which is being stolen from you.

Five year plan
How Stalin ran the Soviet economy.

Means of production
The ability/resources to make stuff.

Alienation
When you feel separated from your humanity and other workers by capitalism.

Class conciousness
When you realise that you are a member of the proletariat and must rise up against Capitalism

title: Politics essay questions
content: UK politics UK politics Democracy To what extent is representative democracy superior to direct democracy? Is the UK experiencing a democratic deficit? Is the UK experiencing a participation crisis? Should voting be made compulsory? Should the voting age be lowered to 16? Do pressure groups promote democracy and participation? To what extent is pressure group success down to large membership? Does the UK now have a ‘rights-based’ culture? Rights are not sufficiently protected in the UK. Discuss Parties Should parties be state funded? To what extent is the Labour Party true to its core policies and ideas? To what extent is the Conservative Party true to its core policies and ideas? To what extent is the Liberal Democrat Party true to its core policies and ideas? To what extent is the Labour Party united? To what extent is the Conservative Party united? To what extent is the UK a multi- party system? To what extent are the minor parties becoming more powerful in the UK? To what extent do political parties still dominate UK politics? To what extent is the influence of the media the most important factor in determining The success or failure of political party? Electoral systems Do the advantages of the FPTP outweigh the disadvantages? Should the FPTP system for Westminster be replaced by STV? Do the positives of the alternative electoral systems in the UK outweigh the negatives? Do referendums create more problems than solutions? Do referendums improve democracy in the UK? Voting behaviour Evaluate the view that the newspaper press has major impact on voting behaviour Evaluate the view that class is no longer important in determining voting behaviour Evaluate the view that social factors are crucial in determining elections Evaluate the view that elections are won on wider political events rather than party manifestos Evaluate the extent to which general elections in the UK are lost by the government rather than won by the opposition. Evaluate the extent to which social factors determine voting behaviour. Evaluate the extent to which ‘new’ forms of media changed voting behaviour UK government The constitution Do constitutional reforms in the UK since 1997 require further change? Should Britain have a codified constitution including a bill of rights? Evaluate the argument that there are more advantages to having a codified constitution than remaining with an uncodified constitution. evaluate the view that the logical next step after devolution to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland is the devolution of further power to England. Using the source, evaluate the view that Constitutional reforms in the UK since 1997 have been weak, incomplete and require further change (Sample materials) Evaluate the claim that the concept of parliamentary sovereignty no longer exists Parliament Does Parliament carry out its functions effectively? Is Parliament sufficiently representative? To what extent is parliament an effective legislature? To what extent are the select committees the most effective form of scrutiny of the executive? To what extent are backbenchers the most effective form of scrutiny of the executive? To what extent is the opposition the most effective form of scrutiny of the executive? Evaluate the view that Prime Ministers Questions should be abolished and replaced by other forms of parliamentary scrutiny of the executive. To what extent is Parliament an effective legislature? To what extent is the House of Lords effective at scrutiny of the executive? Is the House of Lords becoming more dominant? The executive To what extent is a minister’s potential ability the most important factor in determining whether a PM will appoint them? To what extent is Cabinet government no longer important? To what extent is the PM now presidential? To what extent are the wider political and economic events the most important factor in determining a successful PM? To what extent is the PM’s ability to set the agenda the most important factor in determining a successful PM? To what extent is the PM’s popularity the most important factor in determining a successful PM? To what extent is has the concept of individual responsibility been eroded? To what extent is has the concept of collective ministerial responsibility been eroded? Evaluate the view that the conventions of ministerial responsibility no longer adequately account for the actions of ministers. Relations between the branches To what extent does Parliament retain sole sovereignty within the UK political system? To what extent is has membership of the EU eroded sovereignty of UK parliament? To what extent is the executive in the UK sovereign? To what extent is has the UK government’s control over Parliament reduced in recent years? To what extent is the influence exercised by the Supreme Court too excessive? Evaluate the view that judges should not exercise control over the power of government To what extent is the Supreme Court independent and neutral? To what extent has parliament lost sovereignty as a result of the UK’s membership of the EU US Politics Congress Evaluate the view that congress has gotten weaker over time Evaluate the view that the main factors affecting voting behaviour in Congress are the divisions within and between the political parties. Evaluate the view that US foreign policy is dominated as much by Congress as by the presidency. Evaluate the view that the procedures for electing US presidents and members of Congress are not fit for purpose. Evaluate the extent to which Congressional oversight of the President is ineffective Evaluate the extent to which the Senate in more powerful and prestigious than the House. Evaluate the extent to which Congress is an effective legislative body Evaluate the extent to which Congress is a representative institution Evaluate the extent to which political parties play an important role in Congress Evaluate the extent to which the real work of Congress occurs in committees rather than in the chambers Evaluate the extent to which Congress can check the power of the executive branch Evaluate the view that gridlock is an inevitable consequence of the US system of government Ideologies

content: Table of Contents Sexual ethics Situation ethics Utilitarianism Natural moral law Kantian ethics Sexual ethics Content Key Knowledge Key Questions Premarital Traditional beliefs and practices whether or not religious beliefs and practices concerning sex and relationships have a continuing role in the area of sexual ethics Extramarital How they have changed over time Religious Influence on Morality, Legality, and tolerance Impact of secularism whether choices in the area of sexual behaviour should be entirely private and personal, or whether they should be subject to societal norms and legislation Application of Each concept How they might help and what the issues raised might be whether normative theories are useful in what they might say about sexual ethics Situation ethics Spec point Basic explanation How does it relate to sexual ethics Fun extras Agape Love is all that matters in ethics. He thinks the 10 commandments don’t matter, only love does.Agape is a selfless love Polyamory – to not be adulterous. As long as the partner is still loved, adultery doesn’t matter (?) On the other hand, forms of polyamory could be selfish, prioritising the self by having multiple partners rather than being devoted to one personSex work, is this selfless? Definitely selfish on both sides, exploitative and not actually love. Lust instead.Homosexuality and Christianity – Fletcher may think that it doesn’t matter whether someone is homosexual or not, as long as it is true and pure love. This may contradict Christian ideas – especially Catholic The four working principles 1.       Pragmatism: it is based on experience rather than on theory2.       Relativism: it is based on making the absolute laws of Christian ethics relative3.       Positivism: it begins with belief in the reality and importance of love4.       Personalism: persons, not laws or anything else, are at the centre of situation ethics Polyamory: evaluated by whether multiple relationships genuinely foster love, honesty and care rather than harm. Not “always wrong” - depends on honesty, consent etc. If relationships are grounded in agape (selfless love), they can be morally valid. The dignity and happiness of individuals matter more than traditional monogamy rules.Sex work:Judged by whether it protects workers’ dignity and safety. Context matters – exploitation is wrong but consensual safe sex work can be morally acceptable. If motivated by care (e.g. providing for a family) it can align with love. Protecting workers’ rights and safety is most important. The six fundamental principles 1.       Love is the only intrinsically good thing2.       Love is the ruling norm in ethics3.       Love is justice distributed4.       Love wills the neighbours good regardless of if you like your neighbour5.       Only the end justifies the means6.       Love decides on each situation as it occurs — without a set of laws to guide it This follows for all sub-topics that could be asked in sexual ethics:Because there are no laws and morals are decided upon from situation to situation, as long as the decision abides by the first 5 principles, it is always ethical.Whether something is ‘loving’ is that which you have to define for yourself. Is pain loving? Is the end loving — can ends be loving in a capitalist system which demands money? Is it entirely focussed on ‘loving’ over any other moral laws_? What even is love in any given situation_? All of which are subjective. Could talk about the Lavender Brown hair thing: she did it for money, as is the case with 99% of sex work. Is that loving?Could talk about pornography. People sharing it for joy with each other — means (sexual trafficking, immoral acts) could be argued to not matter? Or perhaps is the end if we define the end as widespread immoral sexual acts — then not ethical? Conscious -Fletcher: conscious a verb not a noun; a term that describes attempts to make decisions creatively-> helps us figure things out-process of figuring out what the loving thing to do in a situation is-it is not a ‘thing’; not a set moral compass Polyamory- is it truly the loving solution in a given situation?-Some engage in polyamory to satisfy another partner’s desire for multiple relationships, not necessarily maintaining their own happiness-> this is more harmful than loving--> jealousy and insecurity are often introduced in poly relationships Talk about the tragedy of Jerry (Love Without Limits)- feels neglected, insecure (compared to Joe sexually)-> unfair treatment towards Jerry from Heidi Utilitarianism Specification How it can be applied Scholars Criticisms Act utilitarianism -polyamory:  - sex work: - BDSM: - homosexuality: - Bentham  - Peter Singer -issues with calculation and measuring pleasure -issues with liberty/ rights + justifying immoral actions what it is (calculating the consequences of each situation on its own merits) and its use in promoting the greatest amount of good over evil, or pleasure over pain -judge an action based on whether it produces the most amount of pleasure compared to other actions - Hedonic calculus Can be used by asking: - Does this act maximise pleasure and minimise pain?  - Is it consensual, safe for the involved  - Is the more pleasure than pain and is it short-term or long-term Bentham J S Mill what it is (calculating the benefit or harm of an  act through its consequences) and its use as a  measure of individual pleasure Rule utilitarianism -polyamory:  - if polyamory is transparent and consensual, may increase happiness for those involved - if rules of honesty are broken, instability and harm to children/ families may result - rule utilitarianism would endorse polyamory only under a general rule on consensual transparency, since deception reduces overall utility - sex work: - “sexual activity should not exploit or harm” - positive utility: legalised, regulated sex work can reduce harm (STI’s, trafficking) - if unregulated, risks exploitation + long-term unhappiness - BDSM: -  - homosexuality: J.S Mill - Mill’s conception of society us of individuals each pursuing what seems good to them, their only universal bond being the wrongness or illegality of harming others what it is (following accepted laws that lead to  the greatest overall balance of good over evil,  or pleasure over pain) and its use in promoting  the common good to make things illegal because they go against religious morality must be rejected bc it has been the foundation of religious persecution -as long as there is consent amongst all those involved -harm principle: people should be free to do as they like as long as they don’t harm others (this includes consensual sexual behaviours which are private) Utility Judge sexual acts by their consequences (happiness and suffering) The use of the significant concept of utility (seeking the greatest balance of good over evil, or pleasure over pain) in teleological and relativist approaches to ethics Natural moral law Specification Points Key Knowledge How it can be applied to the case studies Telos Origins of the significant concept of telos (the ultimate purpose) in Aristotle and its religious development in the writing of Aquinas Polyamory: Relationships should cultivate flourishing so it can be seen as problematic if its undermining trust but if its mutual among all partners then it's okay. You could also reject it because it undermines the purpose of a marriage leading to procreation and spiritual unity. Sex work: Sex work doesn’t build virtue as having relations becomes more of a business transaction. It also is against the telos of sexuality which is procreation, but it may also be a positive way to prevent worse things. Pornography: It encourages lust which limits human flourishing and does not reach the telos of virtue. Removes sexual pleasure from its telos BDSM: If it isn’t cruel and cultivates virtue then it’s telos is okay. But it can also distort the natural telos of sex Homosexuality and Christianity: wouldnt be judged whether it fosters flourishing or friendship The Four Tiers of Law Eternal Law: the principles by which God made and controls the universe and which are only fully known to God Divine Law: the law of God revealed in the Bible, particularly in the Ten Commandments and the Sermon on the Mount Natural Law: the moral law of God within human nature that is discoverable using reason  Human Law: the laws of nations Polyamory: EL/DL – Marriage is one man, and woman, as polyamory contradicts divine order NL – Undermines stable family unit à against primary precept of living in society Sex work: EL/DL – Condemns lust and exploitation NL – Reduces sex to pleasure/profit à against primary precepts of reproduction and unity HL – often illegal or heavily regulated, seen as harmful to social order Pornography: EL/DL – Condemns lust, objectification NL – Sex detached from procreation à misuse of sexuality HL – Legal in many places, but regulated; tensions with moral law BDSM: EL/DL – Seen as misuse of body, contrary to chastity NL – if consensual, may not directly perpetuate the primary precept of reproduction, but risks harm à against preservation of life HL – permitted if consensual, but restrivted if harmful Homosexuality and Christianity: EL/DL – Traditional Christian teaching condemns homosexual acts; some modern interpretations emphasise love and fidelity  NL – same-sex acts frustrate reproduction à considered wrong HL – legalised same-sex marriage in many societies; diverges from traditional NML stance The Precepts The 5 primary precepts are: preservation of life, ordering of society, worship of God, education of children, reproduction. Other knowledge: - what they are and how they are related   - the key precept (do good, avoid evil)   - secondary precept Polyamory: 789 Sex work:  Pornography: BDSM: Doesn’t contribute to an ordered society as its violent, could promote violence to others  Homosexuality and Christianity: Doesn’t produce children or preserve life as homosexuality doesn’t often lead to children Kantian ethics Key terms Sexual ethics case studies applied to Kantian ethics Duty - acting morally to reach good without worrying about the consequences (deontological). Polyamory - you have a duty to your partner  Polyamory disrupts this Hypothetical imperative - a command to act to achieve a desired result. ‘If’ ... ‘Then’. Sex work - you are using someone. If they do this then I will feel this. Sex work is not allowed. Categorical imperative - a command to act that is good regardless of consequences. à formula of the law of nature à formula of the end in itself à formula of the kingdom of ends Homosexuality and Christianity - Kant would argue that homosexuality doesn’t seem universalisible, since if everyone were homosexual then the species could not continue and then no one would exist to follow the duty to be homosexual. If the maxim were to ‘follow your own orientation’, then it would seem universalizable. Three postulates – Freedom, Immortality, God. BDSM -  Kant would disagree with BDSM and that we cannot consent to such acts. This is because –  Nature of law - we should follow a duty that we think everyone should do and follow. This is unlikely  Treat everyone to an end to themselves - Both must be committed to such acts and individuals should not be used for one's satisfaction. Must be equally agreed upon. (violent acts removed human dignity)  Kingdom of Ends - committing to something we think everyone should do. This is controversial.

title: Social Democracy
content:
timeline
		title History of Socialism
		1848 : Marxism
			 : Karl Marx, Friedrich Engels
		2004 : Democratic Socialism
			 : Elizabeth something
			 : Eduard Berstein
		2005 : Social Democracy
			 : Corbyn
		2006 : The Third Way
			 : Tony BlairWhere does Social Democracy emerge from?
It majorly starts in the 1930s as there are a lot of economic problems:

hunger
wall street crash
absolute poverty en masse
Unemployment (in part caused by the wall street crash)
war debt
illness — poor public health because: people can't get treated 🡺 their disease spreads 🡺 more people have the disease and can't get treated 🡺 vicious cycle.

How does the Labour government try to change this?

nationalising businesses
setting up the welfare state and the NHS
tax the rich heavily to put it into nationalized companies
